(14) Was the Airservices Australia Executive aware that following the heightened security measures following the tragic events in the United States in September 2001, contractors have not been able to enter Airservices facilities located within military establishments such as the RAAF base at Canberra airport.
(15) Did Airservices Australia consider this information to be relevant to its consideration of the viability of outsourcing the technical and engineering functions of the NAS; if so, how.

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
Mr Anderson
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: Airservices Australia (Airservices) has advised the following:

(1) On 20 September 2001, Airservices' Executive considered a decision whether to proceed with a detailed analysis to determine whether its technical, and engineering and maintenance support services were available in the market, the extent of competition and what approaches might be taken by external suppliers to provide engineering and maintenance support to the National Airways System. This information would then assist Airservices' Executive to make a decision after the detailed analysis whether outsourcing would be viable and therefore the work should be contested in the market. How this analysis would be undertaken included consideration about using a Request for Proposal to collect information. The Executive meeting also resolved that prior to any decision being taken on the need for a RFP, management actively pursue discussions with unions to identify a range of viable alternatives and report back to the Executive as a matter of urgency. This process is still ongoing.
(2) Not relevant as no decision to approach the market has yet been made.

(3) I am advised Airservices Australia does have a guideline document titled Airservices Market Testing Process Guidelines and those guidelines are being applied by Airservices. In light of the current status outlined in question 1, all relevant parties have been informed.
(4) Yes.
(5) Yes.
(6) Airservices has not entered into any commercial relationship at this time, nor has it taken such a decision.
(7) I am advised that Airservices was only considering a decision about whether to proceed with detailed analysis of the market. Refer to question 1.
(8) Refer to question 7 and question 1.
(9) Refer to question 1.

(11) Yes, Airservices did receive a report on the property function in November 2001. I am advised that Airservices' Executive does not consider the property report to be relevant to current deliberations.
(12) I am advised that this failure occurred on 16th July 2001. The relevant members of the Airservices' Executive were aware that this failure had occurred.

(13) Yes, Airservices' Executive were aware that contractors cut the cables carrying the tertiary air ground communications more than 48 hours prior to the failure. However, this was not relevant to deliberations outlined in question 1.

(14) I am advised that Airservices' security staff have not received any reports that Airservices' contractors have been denied access to enter Airservices' facilities located within military establishments. Arrangements with the RAAF are such that Airservices' contractors can gain access with appropriate security arrangements.
(15) Refer to question 1.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 13 February 2002:

question.para: (1) How many times in each of the past 5 years have the runway lights at Sydney Kingsford-Smith Airport (KSA) failed and what was the reason for each failure.
(2) Has the Australian Transport Safety Bureau investigated any of these lighting failures; if so, were any safety recommendations issued; if so, what were they and have they been acted upon.

(3) What is the age of the lighting system, when was it installed, what is the cost of replacing the lighting system and are there any plans to replace the system; if so, when is it scheduled to occur.
(4) Has the Government or the airport owners received any complaints about the safety of the lighting system; if so, from whom and what was the response to the complaints.

(5) Is the Civil Aviation Safety Authority (CASA) responsible for the regulation of airport lighting; if so, (a) how many times in each of the past 5 years has it inspected or audited the lighting system at KSA, (b) did it identify any safety or operational deficiencies and (c) is CASA now satisfied that the lighting system complies with all safety requirements.

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
Mr Anderson
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The following is the number of runway light failures recorded on the Australian Transport Safety Bureau (ATSB) aviation safety database for each of the last five years:
1997 - One failure, possibly due to a drop or surge in mains power.
1998 - Two failures. One failure was due to cable burn out. There was no reason recorded for the other failure.
1999 - Two failures. One failure resulted from severed cables cut by earth moving equipment. There was no reason recorded for the other failure.
2000 - No failures.
2001 - Two failures. One failure occurred due to cable fault. The other failure resulted from a fire in the lighting room.
2002 - No failures.
(2) In 1998, the ATSB (as the Bureau of Aviation Safety Investigations) investigated a lighting failure at Sydney Airport due to cable burn out. A safety recommendation was not issued.
(3) The airport ground lighting system at Sydney Airport is an aged asset with most of the system up to 30 years old.
The majority of the primary cables were installed in the late 1960's. In recent years these areas of the system have suffered the most frequent failures.

A $32 million three year programme to replace key sections of this system is currently under way. It will involve the replacement of all older sections and upgrading of cabling and control systems. This programme is also being implemented with a view to operational requirements of future larger aircraft use of the airport and will be completed in 2005.

(4) The ATSB received one Confidential Aviation Incident Report (CAIR) in 2000 concerning the safety of lights at Sydney Airport. The CAIR reporter stated concern about the possible confusion between taxiway-taxiway intersection lights and taxiway-runway intersection lights. The ATSB advised Sydney Airport Corporation Limited (SACL) of the CAIR and SACL responded advising a plan had been formulated to decommission the lights until runway guard lights were installed.
The Government and SACL have received no other complaints about the safety of the lighting system in the last five years.
(5) Yes. The Civil Aviation Safety Authority is responsible for the regulation of aerodrome lighting.
(a) CASA has audited SACL twice per year over the last five years in accordance with the Aviation Safety Surveillance Plan (ASSP). Of the last 10 audits that have been conducted, 7 included lighting.

(b) It would require a significant expenditure of resources to provide the level of operational detail as requested by Mr Ferguson, however CASA can confirm that all Non Compliance Notices issued to the operator have been acquitted.

(c) CASA is satisfied that SACL have appropriate systems in place to ensure that the lighting system is regularly inspected to detect and record any deficiencies, and any deficient sections of lighting are repaired and/or withdrawn from service.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Finance and Administration, upon notice, on 13 February 2002:

quote.para: In 2000-2001, what was the total sum spent by all Commonwealth agencies in newspaper display advertising for (a) employment advertisements, (b) tender notices, (c) information regarding inquiries and hearings to parliamentary committees and (d) other invitations for submissions on matters of public interest.

talker.name: Costello, Peter, MP
Mr Costello
talker.role: Treasurer

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Finance and Administration has supplied the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: The Department of Finance and Administration does not collect consolidated whole-of-Government information of this nature.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, upon notice, on 14 February 2002:

quote.para: (1) How many personnel does his Department employ throughout Australia for the specific task of reviewing and assessing visa applications for asylum seekers.
(2) How many asylum seekers does his Department estimate are currently held in detention or are awaiting the processing of their visa applications.
(3) On average, how many visa applications from asylum seekers does each departmental staff member have to review and assess each month.
(4) How many personnel were employed by his Department for the specific purpose of reviewing and assessing visas from asylum seekers in (a) 1992, (b) 1993, (c) 1994, (d) 1995 and (e) 1996.
(5) On average, how many visa applications for asylum seekers would a departmental staff member review and assess each month in (a) 1993, (b) 1994, (c) 1995 and (d) 1996.
(6) Was there a downturn in staff numbers within his Department between 1996 and 2002; if so, what was the extent of that staff downturn.
(7) What measures are in place to ensure that departmental personnel are accountable for processing of asylum seekers' visa applications within a specific time period.

(8) Have any reports, memoranda, or other documents been presented to him by departmental personnel that provide recommendations to hasten the overall length in processing time for asylum seekers' visa applications; if so, (a) what are the recommendations and (b) when where they presented to him.
(9) Is he able to say what is the average processing time for an asylum seekers application in New Zealand.
(10) Is he aware of any incidents involving departmental staff being unable to access any remote asylum seeker detention centre within Australia.
(11) What is the longest recorded period that any detained adult male asylum seeker has had to wait in detention whilst his application for asylum to Australia was being processed.
(12) What is the longest recorded period that any detained adult female asylum seeker has had to wait in detention whilst her application for asylum to Australia was being processed.

(13) What is the longest recorded period that any detained minor asylum seeker has had to wait in detention whilst his or her application for asylum to Australia was being processed, and what is the age of this minor now.

talker.name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
Mr Ruddock
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) As at 27 June 2002 the Department employed 79 case managers throughout Australia for the specific task of assessing visa applications for asylum seekers. There were also some 44 trained Case Managers on stand-by.
(2) As at 11 July 2002, there were 1,159 detainees of whom 27 were awaiting a primary Protection Visa decision from the Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs (DIMIA).
(3) There are wide variations in processing times due to the complexities of some cases. Currently, productivity is in the order of 110 to 120 applications decided per Case Manager per annum.

(4) It is not possible to provide accurate staffing figures for the program years 1992 to 1995. However, during the 1995/1996 financial year there were up to 160 Case Managers working on protection visa processing.

(5) In 1993/94 funding assumptions were based on Case Managers finalising 45 cases, (incorporating family groupings), per annum. At the time there were around 1.3 persons per case. Through the 1990s improved processing procedures have resulted in 110 - 120 persons per Case Manager being processed per annum;

(6) Departmental records indicate there were up to 160 trained Case Managers working on protection visa processing during the 1995/1996 program year. Case Manager numbers were reduced in subsequent years to reflect the reduced workload. However, an increase in the workload from 1999 onwards resulted in Case Manager numbers again being increased. In 2000/2001 there were some 100 Case Managers working on protection visa processing, with an additional 37 staff on call from other areas of the Department as required.

(7) Timely processing is the responsibility of State Managers within DIMIA. Additional measures are in place to continually oversee processing of all protection visa applications from applicants in detention. Regular high level teleconferences chaired at Secretary or Deputy Secretary level and attended by State Directors responsible for protection visa processing consider all aspects of processing of boat arrivals in detention down to the individual case level.

(8) Since 1999, my Department has been constantly reviewing, streamlining and strengthening the protection visa process to ensure speedy and rigorous processing of protection visa applications made by unauthorised boat arrivals. Examples of how procedures have been streamlined are:

· the commissioning of ID/nationality fraud, language analysis and re-entry/residence checks as early as possible after the individual enters detention in order to expedite this aspect of any subsequent protection visa assessment;
· integration of security checking work into initial interviews conducted by DIMIA on arrival of the individual in detention;
· establishment of streamlined medical checking arrangements. These checks are needed should a visa grant be contemplated and are commenced as soon as the individual enters detention;

· overhauling arrangements for deployment of Immigration Advice and Application Assistance Scheme (IAAAS) providers and protection visa decision makers to Immigration Reception and Processing Centres (IRPCs) to ensure speedy high volume processing of refugee claims;
· provision of specialised training and detailed country research to support speedy and reliable decision making on the nationalities arriving by boat;
· establishment of a boat processing management team in Western Australia and in DIMIA Central Office to oversee all aspects of processing;

· continuing to process straight forward cases within 4 to 6 weeks of receipt of the Protection Visa application. Delays beyond this time are due mainly to factors such as the disposal of identity documentation by asylum seekers en route to Australia. These are largely outside the control of DIMIA and the Australian Government; and
· ensuring sufficient numbers of suitably trained case managers are available at all times to process boat arrivals as a priority and without delay.
My Department continues to scrutinise the process to identify any areas in which we can refine and further enhance our processing arrangements.
(9) This is a matter which the honourable member may wish to raise with the New Zealand Government.

(10) There are occasions where access by visitors and all non essential personnel to an IRPC may need to be suspended because of safety and security concerns at the time. Apart from such instances, I am unaware of any occasions where departmental staff were unable to access remote detention centres. At the time of the Ansett Airlines collapse, there were some temporary logistical issues associated with departmental officers travelling to some of the detention centres. These issues were minor and generally addressed by making alternative travel arrangements;

(11) The longest recorded period that any adult male asylum seeker has had to wait from the time of detention, through the application process, review and judicial review stages, until all protection visa processing was completed, was 5.5 years, (2021 days). The original protection visa application was processed by my Department within 8 months from time of lodgement to primary decision. The individual then sought Refugee Review Tribunal (RRT) review of that decision and subsequently pursued litigation over the RRT decision to affirm the Department's finding that he was not owed refugee protection. This litigation upheld the RRT decision. Immigration detention ceased 36 days after litigation was completed;

(12) The longest recorded period that any adult female asylum seeker has had to wait from the time of detention, through the application process, review and judicial review stages, until all protection visa processing was completed, was 5.4 years (1998 days). The original protection visa application was processed by my Department within 4 weeks from time of lodgement to primary decision. The individual then unsuccessfully challenged that decision at the RRT. A family member of the individual subsequently applied for a protection visa and, following an unsuccessful review application, pursued litigation over the RRT decision to affirm the Department's finding that he was not owed refugee protection. This litigation was finally resolved in the family member's favour. Immigration detention ceased 29 days after litigation was completed; and

(13) The longest recorded period for any minor asylum seeker in detention was 1998 days. This minor would now be 12 years old, is the child of the above female and was included in the same application. Immigration detention ceased 29 days after the family member's litigation was completed.

subdebateinfo.title: Airservices Australia: Sydney Terminal Control Unit
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 175)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 11 March 2002:

question.para: (1) Has Airservices Australia identified any cost savings that can only be achieved by moving the Sydney Terminal Control Unit (TCU) to Melbourne and cannot be achieved with the Sydney TCU in situ; if so, what are these savings and how will they be reflected in lower charges to Airservices Australia's customers.

(2) Has Airservices Australia identified any operational improvements that can only be implemented by moving the Sydney TCU to Melbourne and cannot be achieved with the Sydney TCU in situ; if so, what are these operational improvements and how will they be reflected in improved service to the aviation industry.

(3) If Airservices Australia believes that savings can be made from moving remote facilities to Melbourne, has it also considered moving the Air Traffic Management Group from Canberra to Melbourne; if not, why not.

(4) Would the move referred to in part (3) have the potential to not only reduce costs, but also allow the Airservices Australia management team to have a much closer working relationship with both field staff and customers.
(5) What benefits to the Australian aviation industry does Airservices Australia expect will result from consolidating TCU facilities.

(6) Has Airservices Australia advised that TCU consolidation will allow improved service delivery and greater integration and standardisation of air navigation services; if so, (a) what does this mean, (b) how will it benefit the Australian aviation industry and (c) why cannot these same benefits be delivered without relocating the Sydney, Adelaide and Perth TCUs to Melbourne.

(7) Has Airservices Australia advised that should TCU consolidation go ahead, it expects an increase in service levels to the aviation industry through improved operations because of less fragmentation, increased standardisation and optimisation of operating procedures, more efficient transition between Enroute and TCU and the potential for reductions in air navigation costs; if so, (a) what is meant by improved operations because of less fragmentation, increased standardisation and optimisation of operating procedures and more efficient transition between Enroute and TCU and (b) how will these changes lead to an increase in service levels and a reduction in air navigation costs.

(8) Has Airservices Australia advised that should TCU consolidation go ahead, cost savings will be achieved through reduced management overheads and infrastructure, reduced maintenance and technical support and spare holding, improved equipment utilisation, optimisation of operational procedures and consistency of service; if so, (a) what management overheads and infrastructure will be reduced, (b) what maintenance and technical support and spares holding will be reduced, (c) what equipment utilisation will be improved, (d) what is meant by optimisation of operational procedures and consistency of service, (e) how will this lead to cost savings by Airservices Australia and (f) by what sum does Airservices Australia expect charges to the aviation industry will be reduced if these cost saving measures are implemented.

(9) Are communication and radar facilities used to control Sydney traffic located either on the airport or in close proximity to the control centre; if so, and the control centre is moved to Melbourne, (a) will controllers be over a thousand kilometres from these radar and communication facilities, (b) will this increased distance introduce more links in the data transfer chain that will connect Melbourne-based controllers to Sydney-based facilities and (c) how will Airservices Australia ensure that this increased potential for data link failures will not affect the safety of aircraft flying over Sydney or the residents who live under their flight paths.

(10) Is it the case that, at present, should Sydney tower be rendered unusable for any reason, it would only take a few minutes for contingency arrangements to be put in place and if the TCU was rendered inoperable for any reason, two consoles in the tower could be reconfigured in a matter of minutes and used by TCU controllers to provide air traffic control services to airborne Sydney traffic; if so and the Sydney TCU was located in Melbourne, (a) would this capability, among others, be lost and (b) how does Airservices Australia plan to overcome this degradation in disaster recovery ability should consolidation go ahead.

(11) Should an air traffic control facility suffer a catastrophic failure, is it true that, at present, adjacent areas can provide assistance, such as the use of their radar and communication facilities, that greatly improves the chance of a successful recovery; if so, and Airservices goes ahead with its consolidation plans, will this disaster recovery option be lost.

(12) If a consolidated Melbourne centre was rendered inoperable through facility failure or some other catastrophic event, (a) would half of Australia's airspace be uncontrolled, including airspace over residential areas of Sydney, Canberra, Melbourne, Adelaide and Perth and (b) how does Airservices Australia plan to address this issue so that disaster recovery margins are not reduced by consolidating four centres into one.

(13) Are TCU controllers responsible for providing all air traffic control services, including emergency services, to airborne traffic within 45 nautical miles of the primary airport while tower controllers are only responsible for aircraft on the aerodrome and aircraft immediately prior to landing and immediately following takeoff; if so, (a) is it important for the TCU controller to have detailed knowledge of local geography, weather patterns and terrain, in case an emergency occurs within 45NM of Sydney and requires assistance from the TCU and (b) if TCU consolidation goes ahead, (i) how will the local knowledge possessed by current controllers at Sydney airport be replicated if those controllers are moved to Melbourne and (ii) will a loss of local knowledge impair the ability of remotely located TCU controllers to resolve the emergency situations.

(14) Has Airservices Australia's legal department alerted senior management to the fact that an intimate knowledge of local terrain in a controller's area of responsibility may be considered an essential element of their job; if so, did this advice also alert senior management that if local knowledge is considered essential, the TCU consolidation plans may be jeopardised; if this advice was received, how will Airservices Australia address its legal department's concerns should TCU consolidation go ahead.

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
Mr Anderson
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: Airservices Australia (Airservices) has advised the following:

(1) Yes. Airservices has undertaken a study into a proposal to consolidate the Sydney TCU to the Melbourne Centre. This study is part of a broader program examining the feasibility of consolidating all Airservices remote TCUs to the major Centres in Melbourne or Brisbane.

The anticipated benefits result from being able to remove overheads associated with managing a stand alone facility at Sydney including costs associated with building and equipment maintenance, reduced and more flexible staffing arrangements and fewer senior management positions. These benefits will result in lower costs and hence lower prices to industry.
While Airservices accepts additional efficiencies are achievable were the TCU to remain in Sydney, they are not of the scale which could be achieved were the TCU to be relocated to Melbourne.

(2) Yes. It is expected that operational benefits will accrue from the co-location of the Melbourne and Sydney TCU facilities associated with operational procedures, management and staffing arrangements and technical service agreements, increased streamlining and standardisation of service, reduced infrastructure costs, reduced spares holding costs and simplified communications arrangements. Many of these benefits cannot be realised in situ.
(3) The Canberra TCU was moved to Melbourne in 1994. The Canberra ATM Group has a national function.

(4) Business centre management has close relationships with staff and customers. The ATM Group management role should not be focused on any particular location, if it is to have a truly national perspective.
(5) See answer to questions 1 and 2 above.
(6) Yes.

(a) Integration will mean efficiencies in areas such as testing, maintenance and software management. Also staff and equipment can be readily deployed to provide services with reduction in idle time that necessarily comes with remote facilities. Standardisation of services means that the way services are delivered to the industry will be more consistent and delivered more as a continuum to flights.
(b) It will benefit the Australian aviation industry through improved service from a more streamlined interface between the industry and Airservices.
(c) See answer to questions 1, 2, and 6(a) above. These benefits also apply to the relocation of the Adelaide and Perth TCU's.
(7) Yes.

(a) Fewer individual TCUs, integrated management oversight of operational and non-operational functions resulting in a more streamlined and standardised approach to industry. Co-location of TCUs will allow for a single point of operational management oversight of enroute and approach functions with the potential to combine some functions during some periods of the day.
(b) See answer to questions 1, 2 and 6 above.
(8) Yes.

(a) TCU consolidation will result in savings from the current management structures being absorbed into the retained Centre management structure. The current buildings in which excess TCU's are located will be decommissioned resulting in savings to the infrastructure needed to maintain and service those buildings.

(b) TCU consolidation will result in savings to building maintenance and servicing, and will reduce the current number of technical and support staff needed to maintain operational facilities. Total equipment spares holding will be reduced by having current stand-alone facilities consolidated and making use of spares holding capacity in consolidated Centres.

(c) Consolidation will reduce duplication and lead to improved usage of a wide range of equipment and facilities (eg simulators, consoles, test equipment) used by operational and non-operational staff.
(d) See answer to questions 6 (a) & 7 (a) above.
(e) See answer to questions 1, 2 , 6 and 7 above.
(f) This will be finalised at the end of the current consultation.
(9) Yes.
(a) Yes.

(b & c) The number of links would be similar, but the transmission of most of the processed data would be over much shorter links. Redundancies in modern modes of transmission (satellite, terrestrial) have also minimised the risks of system failures.

(a & b) This is dealt with in national contingency and business resumption plans. Should a decision be made to proceed with relocation of the Sydney TCU, contingency and business continuity arrangements would be available to at least the same level of assurance as those currently existing.
(11) Any future arrangements would ensure satisfactory recovery options are available either on site or at another location.
(12) (a) No. Contingency plans already provide for recovery arrangements in the event of the failure of the Melbourne Centre.
(b) See answer to (a) above and questions 9, 10 and 11.

(a) Local knowledge is important but can be achieved through familiarisation visits and ongoing briefings. Local knowledge is much more significant for tower controllers, who provide visual reference for all the current TCUs. The TCU consolidation proposal does not impact on the Sydney Tower.

(b) (i) Should a decision be made to relocate the Sydney TCU, Airservices will encourage as many Sydney controllers as possible to relocate to Melbourne to assist in maintaining the necessary amount of local knowledge.
(ii) The level of local knowledge that allows emergency situations to be resolved will be maintained through the above measures.

(14) The legal advice to which the Honourable Member refers was prepared in relation to a particular case which was settled by Airservices Australia's insurers out of court. It expressed no opinion on the broader issue of TCU consolidation.

Airservices Australia's TCU consolidation plan will be the subject of a safety case for the Civil Aviation Safety Authority's approval. If it is found the consolidation plan cannot be safely implemented it will not proceed.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Family and Community Services, upon notice, on 14 May 2002:

question.para: (1) How many Centrelink benefit reviews are outstanding in northern Tasmania.
(2) What is the expected delay period between a review becoming due and the completion of that review.
(3) How many medical officers are employed by the Minister's Department in the northern Tasmania region.

talker.name: Anthony, Larry, MP
Mr Anthony
talker.role: Minister for Children and Youth Affairs

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Family and Community Services has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) In light of Question 3, the following information about medical reviews is provided:

entry.para: Reviews issued but not yet finalised as at 27 May at Launceston CSC

answer.para: (2) Dependent on the payment type, customers have up to 13 weeks in which to return a review questionnaire.
· Medical Reviews can take variable times to complete, dependant on factors such as whether an assessment by a specialist provider is required, or where further information is required.
· In clear cut circumstances review action may be completed by Centrelink within 7 days of receipt of a review form. In other cases it may take several weeks to finalise a review.
(3) Neither Centrelink nor Department of Family and Community Services employ medical officers. Any medical services required are provided by contracted specialist providers.

talk.start.para: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 14 May 2002:

quote.para: (1) What is the average cost of litigation up to and including hearing for (a) applicants (b) respondents and (c) other parties in dissolution proceedings in the Family Court of Australia.
(2) What is the policy rationale for the interests of the child being represented by persons independent of one or both parties, that is, in the hands of the State.
(3) What factors are understood to be behind the near fifty per cent of all marriages in Australia ending in divorce.
(4) What measures, if any, is the Commonwealth Government taking to redress the high incidence of divorce in Australia.
(5) What measures, if any, is the Family Court required to take in mitigating or preventing divorce from occurring.

talker.name: Williams, Daryl, MP
Mr Williams
talker.role: Attorney-General

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) As far as I am aware, there is no information available that would enable an assessment of the average cost of dissolution proceedings. Costs incurred by parties to proceedings would depend on the length of time taken by the court to resolve the issues in dispute between the parties and the fees charged by any legal representatives of the parties.

(2) The policy rationale for the appointment of a separate representative is to promote the best interests of the child. A separate representative acts as an independent and impartial representative for the best interests of the child and makes submissions to the court about those interests. The appointment of a separate representative ensures the safeguard and protection of children involved in family law proceedings. The court will consider appointing a separate representative for the child when it has concerns about the capacity of the parents to look after their child's needs and act in their best interests.
The court's criteria for the appointment of a separate representative, whilst not intended to be exhaustive, is as set out by the Full Court in Re K (1994) FLC 92-461, are:
(i) In cases involving allegations of child abuse, whether physical, sexual, or psychological.
(ii) In cases where there is an apparently intractable conflict between the parents.
(iii) In cases where the child is apparently alienated from one or both parents.
(iv) Where there are real issues of cultural or religious difference affecting the child.
(v) Where the sexual preferences of either or both of the parents or some other person having significant contact with the child are likely to impinge upon the child's welfare.

(vi) Where the conduct of either or both of the parents or some other person having significant contact with the child is alleged to be anti-social to the extent that it seriously impinges on the child's welfare.

(vii) Where there are issues of significant medical, psychiatric or psychological illness or personality disorder in relation to either party or a child or other person having significant contact with the children.
(viii) In any case in which, on the material filed by the parents, neither parent seems a suitable custodian.

(ix) In any case in which a child of mature years is expressing strong views, the giving of effect to which would involve changing a long standing custodial arrangement or a complete denial of access to one parent.

(x) Where one of the parties proposes that the child will either be permanently removed from the jurisdiction or permanently removed to such a place within the jurisdiction as to greatly restrict or for all practical purposes exclude the other party from the possibility of access to the child.
(xi) Where it is proposed to separate the siblings.
(xii) In custody cases where none of the parties are legally represented.

(xiii) In relation to applications in the court's welfare jurisdiction relating in particular to the medical treatment of children where the child's interests are not adequately represented by one of the parties.

(3) As far as I am aware, it is not possible to establish with certainty those factors which cause marital dissolution. However, studies have revealed those factors which can be associated with divorce in Australia. I am aware of a study published by the Australian Institute of Family Studies in 1999 that reported that approximately 71 per cent of all men and women perceived issues such as communication problems, incompatibility and infidelity as the main reason for marriage breakdown. Abusive behaviours were mentioned as the main reason by 16 per cent of these respondents, while 13 per cent noted external pressures (such as financial problems, work/time, physical/emotional health issues and family interference).
(4) I note that you previously asked a similar question on 13 February 2002 [Question on Notice Number 57] and that I responded to you on 12 April 2002. I provide this additional information.

The Marriage Amendment Bill 2002 is currently before Parliament. The range of reforms primarily relate to enhancing the Marriage Celebrants Program. These reforms are particularly important for the Government's Stronger Families and Communities Initiative in that they will broaden and enhance the role of celebrants to include the provision of information on pre-marriage and other relationship services. This aims to ensure that celebrants play an important role in developing longer lasting family relationships and, ultimately, stronger communities within Australia.
(5) Section 43 of the Family Law Act 1974 sets out the broad principles to be applied by the Courts in exercising jurisdiction under the Act. These include:
(a) the need to preserve and protect the institution of marriage as the union of a man and a woman to the exclusion of all others voluntarily entered into for life;
(d) the means available for assisting parties to a marriage to consider reconciliation or the improvement of their relationship to each other and to their children.

Further, where proceedings for a dissolution of marriage have been instituted, or financial proceedings or proceedings under Part VII of the Act (dealing with children) are instituted by a party to a subsisting marriage, the judge and legal practitioners have a duty to consider the possibility of a reconciliation of the parties. If reconciliation appears to be a reasonable possibility, the judge may adjourn the proceedings or, if the parties agree, interview them in chambers to assist in a possible reconciliation. A court can also advise parties to attend counselling, mediation or arbitration when it believes this may assist them.

talk.start.para: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 14 May 2002:

question.para: What share of petrol taxation and excise raised by the Commonwealth Government since 1996 is attributed to Victorian motorists and what share of this revenue has been returned to that State in the form of dedicated road funding.

talker.name: Costello, Peter, MP
Mr Costello
talker.role: Treasurer

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: Excise on petrol is paid by licensed excise manufacturers and importers on a national basis. Accordingly, the share of excise raised by the Commonwealth that is attributed to motorists in any given State is not available.

Excise on petrol is not hypothecated for road funding but forms part of the Commonwealth's general revenues to fund its spending programmes. Details of the Commonwealth Specific Purpose Payments for roads can be found in Budget Paper No. 3.

talk.start.para: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 14 May 2002 —

quote.para: What sum of legal aid funding has been provided to Victoria since 1996 and what share of federal funds goes directly to legal services within the electoral divisions of (a) Wills and (b) Deakin.

talker.name: Williams, Daryl, MP
Mr Williams
talker.role: Attorney-General

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Funds are provided under the Commonwealth Legal Aid Program to the Legal Aid Commission of Victoria for Commonwealth legal aid matters. These funds are used by the Commission to provide legal aid services in Commonwealth matters across Victoria. Whilst it is not possible to identify how much of the funding is provided to the electoral divisions of Wills and Deakin, there are regional offices of the Commission located at Melbourne, Preston and Ringwood which provide a range of services throughout these electorates.
(2) The level of funding provided under the Commonwealth Legal Aid Program to the Legal Aid Commission of Victoria for Commonwealth legal aid matters for the years in question is as follows:

(3) In addition, the Commonwealth funds 126 community legal services across Australia to provide a range of legal and related services under the Commonwealth Community Legal Services Program. Community legal services purchased from organisations are intended to target the most disadvantaged members of the Australian community. There are currently 31 community legal centres located in Victoria providing generalist and/or specialist legal services to the community.
In Melbourne there are specialist centres providing State wide legal services, which would be available to residents in the electorate of Deakin and Wills. These are:
1. Disability Discrimination Law Advocacy Service
2. Environment Defenders Office
3. Welfare Rights Unit
4. Women's Legal Service Victoria

(a) The Coburg Brunswick Community Legal and Financial Counselling Centre provides generalist legal services as well as financial counselling. The electorate of Wills is located within the geographical catchment area serviced by this Centre. The level of funding provided by the Commonwealth to the Centre for the years in question is as follows:

(b) The Eastern Community Legal Centre provides generalist legal services. The electorate of Deakin is located within the geographical catchment area serviced by this Centre. The level of funding provided by the Commonwealth to the Centre for the years in question is as follows:
