talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 14 May 2002:

question.para: (1) Further to the answer to question No. 109 concerning Bankstown Airport, will his Department merely be recommending or will it be a condition of the lease to the private operator that a full environmental impact statement into the upgrading of Bankstown Airport be undertaken.
(2) Why was the Master Plan for Bankstown Airport not prepared in accordance with the Airports Act and when was it due prior to the extended deadline of 30 September 2003.
(3) Why did Bankstown Airport not establish a consultative committee by April 2000 in accordance with the environment strategy for the airport.

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
Mr Anderson
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Under the provisions of the Environmental Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999, it is the Minister for the Environment and Heritage who has the ultimate responsibility for determining the nature of the environmental assessment required for the upgrading of Bankstown Airport. This determination would only occur after the airport is sold and in response to a formal upgrading proposal by the private sector owner.

(2) Prior to the extended deadline, the Bankstown master plan was to be submitted by 30 June 2002 or within 12 months of being sold to private ownership. The deadline for the submission of a draft master plan for Bankstown Airport was extended on the expectation that, with the prospective sale of the airport, a new operator at Bankstown Airport would wish to have a major input into future development plans.
(3) I refer the Honourable Member to my response to part 4 of question 109.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, upon notice, on 14 May 2002:

quote.para: (1) In 2000-2001, what has been the cost to airlines for unauthorised air arrivals placed in detention centres.
(2) What was the cost to each airline to return unauthorised air arrivals back to their country in 2000-2001.
(3) What has been the average time that the unauthorised arrivals have remained in detention.
(4) How many unauthorised air arrivals in 2000-2001 lodged immigration applications.

(5) In 2000-2001, how many unauthorised air arrivals had successful migration outcomes and of these, (a) how many were successful protection visa applications and (b) from which countries did they originate.

talker.name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
Mr Ruddock
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) The Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs (DIMIA) does not keep separate figures for detention costs for airlines. The average cost for an unauthorised air arrival in a detention centre in 2000-2001 was around $134 per day.
(2) Airlines are responsible for returning unauthorised air arrivals and the associated costs. DIMIA is not aware of these costs.

(3) The majority of unauthorised air arrivals do not go to a detention centre. Of the 1,508 unauthorised air arrivals refused entry in 2000-2001, 87% were removed within 72 hours. However, those that seek protection in Australia may potentially remain in detention while their application and appeals are finalised. During 2000-2001, 383 unauthorised air arrivals were in a detention centre and the average time this group remained in detention was 99.63 days.

(4) The only valid visa application that an unauthorised air arrival can lodge is an application for a protection visa. In 2000-2001, 192 unauthorised air arrivals lodged protection visa applications.
(5) In 2000-2001 (a) 134 protection visas were granted to unauthorised air arrivals and (b) the country of nationality of those granted appears in Table 1.1 below:
Table 1.1: Unauthorised air arrivals granted protection in 2000-2001 by citizenship

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, upon notice, on 14 May 2002:

quote.para: Further to the answer to question No. 1572 (Hansard, 30 August 2000, page 19792) and suggestions that penalties for carriers that bring unlawful non-citizens to Australia may be less comprehensive at seaports than at airports, (a) what review or reference has been set up to look into the situation, (b) what are the names of persons nominated on the review body, (c) have submissions been called from interested parties; if not, has it been considered and (d) what are the time frames for reporting back on this issue.

talker.name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
Mr Ruddock
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (a) I indicated in my answer on 22 June 2000 that I would look into the matter of penalties for carriers that bring unlawful non-citizens to Australia by sea.
(b) I asked my Department to consider this matter as part of an internal review of immigration processes for persons arriving in Australia by sea.
(c) I understand that in relation to this matter my Department sought comment from the Departments of Transport and Regional Services, the Attorney General and the Australian Customs Service.
(d) I have considered the recommendations of the review and have asked for further advice on some matters.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 14 May 2002:

question.para: (1) Have all airlines flying to, from and within Australia agreed to participate in the Governments proposal to have on board air marshals; if not, (a) which airlines have not agreed, (b) why not and (c) what will the Government do about it.
(2) How many airlines are participating in the arrangements.
(3) Has each airline agreed to pay the costs associated with air marshals; if not, (a) which airlines have not agreed, (b) why not and (c) what will the Government do about it.
(4) What is the annual cost to each or any airline to have air marshals on flights for security purposes.
(5) Will the Government reimburse or pay the airlines for any part of their costs in providing this aviation security measure.
(6) Is it a fact that air marshals are mainly flying in the business or first class sections of aircraft; if so, why.
(7) What proportion of flights to be made by air marshals will be on (a) international and (b) domestic sectors.

(8) Are the airlines required to pay Goods and Services Tax and other government charges on tickets they fund for air marshals, if so, (a) what are the details of each tax and charge paid and (b) what revenue has the Government raised to date from these tickets.
(9) How many air marshals have been trained to date and at what cost.
(10) How many air marshals will be trained by the end of 2002 and at what cost.
(11) What is the anticipated annual operating cost to the Government for the air marshal program.

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
Mr Anderson
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) and (2) I am advised that this question will be answered by the Attorney-General.

(3) Qantas and Virgin Blue have agreed to meet the costs associated with the carriage of Air Security Officers for the calendar year 2002. Ansett had also agreed to meet these costs prior to its collapse.
(4) I am unable to answer the honourable member's question, as I am not privy to the costs each airline bears in supporting the Air Security Officer program.
(5), (6) and (7) I am advised that this question will be answered by the Attorney-General.

(8) As the airlines provide seats `free of charge' for Air Security Officers there is no Goods and Services Tax payable. Currently my Department is preparing amendments to the Air Passenger Ticket Levy (Collection) Regulations to exempt Air Security Officers from this charge and the Australian Customs Service is considering how it will provide relief under the Passenger Movement Charge Collection Act 1978, which impacts upon international flights. With regard to those charges that are levied by airports, the respective operators have been requested to consider waiving those charges that may relate to the carriage of Air Security Officers.
(9), (10) and (11) I am advised that this question will be answered by the Attorney-General.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Justice and Customs, upon notice, on 14 May 2002:

quote.para: (1) Have all airlines flying to, from and within Australia agreed to participate in the Government's proposal to have on board air marshals; if not, (a) which airlines have not agreed, (b) why not and (c) what will the Government do about it.
(2) How many airlines are participating in the arrangements.
(3) Has each airline agreed to pay the costs associated with air marshals; if not, (a) which airlines have not agreed, (b) why not and (c) what will the Government do about it.
(4) What is the annual cost to each or any airline to have air marshals on flights for security purposes.
(5) Will the Government reimburse or pay the airlines for any part of their costs in providing this aviation security measure.
(6) Is it a fact that air marshals are mainly flying in the business or first class sections of aircraft; if so,why.
(7) What proportion of flights to be made by air marshals will be on (a) international and (b) domestic sectors.

(8) Are the airlines required to pay Goods and Services Tax and other government charges on tickets they fund for air marshals, if so, (a) what are the details of each tax and charge paid and (b) what revenue has the Government raised to date from these tickets.
(9) How many air marshals have been trained to date and at what cost.
(10) How many air marshals will be trained by the end of 2002 and at what cost.
(11) What is the anticipated annual operating cost to the Government for the air marshal program.

talker.name: Williams, Daryl, MP
Mr Williams
talker.role: Attorney-General

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Justice and Customs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: (1) All major Australian domestic airlines have agreed to carry Air Security Officer (ASO).
(2) There are currently two airlines participating in the arrangements.
(3) Refer to House of Representatives Question Number 351 asked of the Minister for Transport and Regional Services.
(4) As above.
(5) The Government and the airlines are sharing the costs of the program.
(6) I am unable to answer the honourable member's question for reasons of operational security.
(7) Due to the operational sensitivities associated with this question, it is inappropriate to detail specifics. ASO deploy on a threat-based arrangement, targeting those routes most at risk.
(8) Refer to House of Representatives Question Number 351 asked of the Minister for Transport and Regional Services.

(9) Due to operational sensitivities, it is inappropriate to be specific about the number of ASO that are currently trained and flying operationally. $6.5 million has been provided in 2001/02 financial year to fund the establishment of the program. $17.75 million has been allocated to the program for the 2002/03 financial year. The program is on schedule to deliver the full complement of ASO in the timeframe agreed with Government and industry.
(10) Approximately 110 officers will be trained by the end of 2002.
(11) The anticipated annual operating cost to the Government for the ASO program is $17.75 million.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Family and Community Services, upon notice, on 15 May 2002:

quote.para: (1) Has Centrelink withdrawn its one-day per week presence in Castlemaine.
(2) Are most Centrelink clients unemployed, disabled or pensioners on low incomes and is travel to Bendigo a major financial and physical burden for them.
(3) Will the Minister reinstate the Centrelink service in Castlemaine.

talker.name: Anthony, Larry, MP
Mr Anthony
talker.role: Minister for Children and Youth Affairs

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Family and Community Services has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: (1) Services to customers in Castlemaine have recently been upgraded. Some Centrelink facilities not previously available at Castlemaine are now accessible through the Centrelink Agent at the Castlemaine District Community Health Centre (CHIRP).
Previously a limited visiting service was available to Job Seekers one day a week (Thursday) and to Pensioners and Families one day per week (Tuesday).
The need for staff to travel from Bendigo meant that this service was available only from 9:30 am to 3:30 pm.
The service was limited to customers making their initial claim for payment and only twelve people could be accommodated per week.
Centrelink customers now have access to local service 5 days a week from 9:00 am to 4:30 pm.

This is provided by staff of CHIRP who have been trained to provide information and assistance in Centrelink business and through a facilitated video interview with Centrelink staff for business that is more complex or needs access to the customer's personal record.
The new arrangement allows up to 30 interviews per week by Centrelink staff on a broader range of services than previously available.
CHIRP staff assist in excess of 200 customers per week.
The complexity of Centrelink business meant that, under the previous arrangements, it was not possible to provide access to a person with specialised knowledge of a customer's service needs.
The new arrangement allows Centrelink to tailor service to the customer's needs through a specifically skilled staff member who has been providing personalised service to the customer.
Centrelink provides a high quality, personalised service to their customers. It works in partnership with community organisations to achieve this.
(2) The arrangements are designed to provide a full range of services to the people of Castlemaine without requiring them to travel to Bendigo.

(3) Centrelink will not take any action to reduce the benefits to the people of Castlemaine that have been provided through the enhancement of Centrelink services there. Local Centrelink staff will respond to customer feedback and continue to work with the community to ensure ongoing improvement to services throughout Central Victoria.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 15 May 2002:

question.para: (1) Further to the answer to question No. 31, how can asset sales to reduce debt be considered responsible fiscal management.

(2) Can fiscal management of debt in Australia be recovered through taxation revenue, rather than reliance on sale of capital assets to service its debt; if so, is he able to provide details of (a) the Commonwealth debt, (b) Commonwealth revenue for 2002-2003 and (c) the shortfall; if so, what are those details, if not, why not.
(3) With respect to his answer to part 2 of question No. 31, is there a budget allocation for the construction of Sydney West Airport at Badgerys Creek.

(4) With respect to his answer to part 4 of question No. 31, if no budget for the construction of Sydney Airport is allocated, can he explain where future funding will come from in the construction of Sydney West Airport and how will this money be raised.
(5) Will he clarify what is meant by incentives.

(6) Will he clarify what relevance the first right of refusal has to any positive power, if any, the Commonwealth has with respect to ensuring that the second Sydney Airport is built so as to alleviate the airport pressure of Sydney Airports aircraft noise and aircraft movement needs.

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
Mr Anderson
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The sale of Sydney Airport has allowed the Government to reduce Commonwealth debt by $4.233 billion, after repaying the debt of Sydney Airports Corporation Limited. This will reduce public debt interest payments by around $250 million every year.

(2) Details of the Commonwealth's receipts, payments, net debt and net interest payments are available from Statement 13 of 2002-03 Budget Paper No. 1. Questions on taxation policy should be directed to the Treasurer.

(4) Any future funding arrangements for the possible development of a second airport would be a matter for negotiation between the Commonwealth, the owner of Sydney Airport and any other relevant stakeholders at that time.
(5) Incentives would be any measures that might encourage the owner of Sydney Airport to respond positively to the Government's wishes in relation to a second airport.

(6) Under the terms of the right of first refusal regarding a second Sydney airport, the Commonwealth retains the power to build and operate a second Sydney airport in the future if the owner of Sydney Airport chooses not to exercise the option to develop and operate a second Sydney airport, when or if that option is offered by the Commonwealth.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Ageing, upon notice, on 15 May 2002:

question.para: (1) Is Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) funded by the (a) State Government if the MRI service is for inpatients only and (b) Federal Government for other purposes; If so, what are the details of the Commonwealth funding arrangements for MRI services and what services are covered.
(2) When will the next round of offers for new licences for MRI services be announced.
(3) What is the distribution of MRI services in NSW.
(4) Is there a lack of a MRI licence for Concord Repatriation General Hospital, NSW; if so, when will Concord Hospital be entitled to a MRI licence.

talker.name: Andrews, Kevin, MP
Mr Andrews
talker.role: Minister for Ageing

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Health and Ageing has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) State Governments are responsible for meeting the costs of MRI services for public in-patients. MRI services provided to public outpatients and privately referred patients on eligible units are funded by the Commonwealth Government.

(2) The MRI services funded by the Commonwealth Government are listed in Group 15 of the Diagnostic Imagining Services Table of the Medicare Benefits Schedule (MBS). The funding arrangements are consistent with other items on the MBS - eligible patients who receive MRI services on eligible units are eligible for MBS rebates to assist in meeting fees charged by the doctor.

(3) There is no formal commitment to any new licences for MRI services. An independent advisory body, the MRI Monitoring and Evaluation Group (MEG), has been set up to monitor access to Medicare funded MRI services and provide advice to the Government on the need for additional MRI services in Australia. It will make recommendations to the Federal Government later this year. If a need for additional MRI units is identified, a tender process may be undertaken targeting specific areas identified by the MEG.
(4) There are currently 26 Medicare eligible MRI sites in NSW. These are located at the addresses below:
. St Vincents Private Hospital and Clinic
. Royal North Shore Public Hospital
. Sydney CT and MRI Centre
. Prince of Wales Hospital
. RPAH Medical Centre
. Royal Prince Alfred Hospital
. North Shore Radiology
. Crows Nest Sports Imaging
. Hornsby MRI
. Westmead Hospital, Department of Radiology
. New Children's Hospital, Westmead
. Castlereagh Radiology, Westmead
. Rayscan Imaging, Liverpool
. Penrith Castlereagh Radiology
. St George Public Hospital
. Gosford Radiology
. Hunter Valley Imaging
. John Hunter Imaging, John Hunter Hospital
. Castlereagh Radiology,Tamworth
. Port Macquarie Base Hospital
. Coffs Harbour Radiology, Coffs Harbour
. IRG Medical Imaging, Wollongong
. Wagga Medical Imaging, Wagga Wagga
. Mayne Health/MIA, Orange
. Wentworth Area Health Service, Nepean Public Hospital, Penrith
. South Western Sydney Area Health Service, Liverpool Public Hospital

(5) Concord Repatriation General Hospital is not a Medicare eligible provider of MRI services. Advice received from the MEG indicates that there are sufficient MRI services available in metropolitan Sydney. It is not possible to indicate when Concord Hospital would be entitled to a MRI licence.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Family and Community Services, upon notice, on 15 May 2002:

quote.para: (1) Was an advertisement placed in the Hills Gazette community newspaper during February 2002, recommending that people receiving Family Tax Benefit or Child Care Benefit contact the Family Assistance Office (FAO) call centre to update any changes to their income estimate.
(2) Did the advertisement suggest that updating an income estimate could be done by calling the FAO call centre.
(3) Was a contact phone number for the FAO call centre provided in the advertisement.
(4) What sum did the advertisement cost.

talker.name: Anthony, Larry, MP
Mr Anthony
talker.role: Minister for Children and Youth Affairs

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Family and Community Services has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: (1) Yes, the advertisement was part of on-going activities aimed at reminding customers of their obligation to maintain an up-to-date income estimate, and to contact the Families Assistance Office (FAO) whenever their income or circumstances change.

(2) The advertisement suggested that families could update their estimate through a range of channels including: by phone Monday to Friday between 8am and 8pm, local time; in person at any Centrelink Customer Service Centre, Medicare Office or ATOaccess site; or via the World Wide Web at www.familyassist.gov.au.

(3) No, the contact number was not included in this advertisement as one of the objectives was to advise customers of the options available - other than by phone - for contacting the FAO to update their income estimate or change in details. The FAO phone number is well known to Centrelink customers.
(4) The cost of the advertisement in the Hills Gazette was $553 Inc GST.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 15 May 2002:

question.para: (1) Has his Department allocated funding for any purpose to the Atherton Tablelands region in (a) 2000-2001, (b) 2001-2002 and (c) 2002-2003.
(2) Did he or his Department publicly or privately call for expressions of interest for project funding in the Atherton Tablelands region.
(3) On which dates has his Department received funding applications from any government, community or lobby group representing the Atherton Tablelands region.
(4) What funding allocations were these groups seeking, what sum was sought and to which programs did they relate.
(5) What sum was granted to the Atherton Tablelands in response to any applications and to which programs did they apply.
(6) What criteria, if any, were applied to the applications received for funding.

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
Mr Anderson
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) (a) (b) and (c) Yes

(2) Applications for funding under Research and Development Programmes for Rural and Regional Australia were publicly announced through the media in May 2000. Advertising and media releases were prepared and distributed. Regional newspapers were specifically targeted in this exercise, including the Cairns Post.

(3) and (4) Black Spot Programme nominations from groups representing the Atherton Tablelands region were received in the Department following consideration by the Queensland Black Spot Consultative Panel, which met on 3 March 2000; 18 December 2000 and 20 May 2002 (see below).

Under the Research and Development Programmes for Rural and Regional Australia (RDPRRA) two applications for projects involving the Atherton Tablelands Region were received. The first, from the Cairns Region Economic Development Corporation, on 20 June 2000, the second, from the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation on 26 April 2001 (see below).
The total amount applied for by local government, community or lobby groups for the Sustainable Regions Programme was $3,845,575 (see below).
Expressions of Interest for the Sustainable Regions Programme received by the Atherton Tablelands Sustainable Regions Advisory Committee (ATSRAC):
Funding allocations sought were:
· Cairns Region Economic Development Corporation - $50,000 to undertake a study which would lead to opportunities for inter industry cooperation in the Cairns region - RDPRRA

· Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation - $45,000 to develop an integrative community-based regional development framework to guide communities from the identification of critical issues and the understanding of key drivers of change to the evaluation of appropriate strategies for desired future regional development - RDPRRA.

This entity has received funding in 2000-01, 2001-02 and will do so in 2002-03. The funding allocated to the FNQ ACC is provided under the operational funding for Area Consultative Committees under the Regional Assistance Programme.
Sustainable Regions Programme - $347,728 allocated to Golden Circle Limited (April 2002) over three years. Other projects are under active consideration by the ATSRAC.
(6) (a) The criteria for choosing projects to be funded from Research and Development Programmes for Rural and Regional Australia were:
· Feasibility of the project;
· Impact of the initiative/magnitude of opportunity (degree of innovation);
· Quality, effectiveness and scope of the partnership;
· Contribution by and general support of the local community, industry and government agencies;
· Generation of ongoing community development in Australian conditions;
· Generation of ongoing community resource;
· Ability of applicant to conduct the project; and
· Extent of public and private benefits to the local community/region/industry/nation.

(b) The standard Black Spot Programme criteria, as set out in the programme's Notes on Administration, were applied to all nominations for Black Spot funding received for sites in the Atherton region.

The criteria, for each Regional Programme, that were applied to the applications received for funding are available on the Department of Transport and Regional Services Internet site at www.dotars.gov.au.

All projects for the Atherton Tablelands Sustainable Region are assessed against the Sustainable Regions Programme Project Assessment Criteria (below) and priorities established by the Advisory Committee.

para.inline: Sustainable Regions Programme General Assessment Criteria

answer.para: 1. Consistency of proposal with identified regional priorities as determined by the futures planning process and other planning processes.
2. The sustainability of the project and the extent to which it will be of benefit to the region.
3. The extent to which Commonwealth funding is needed to realise the project and the absence of relevant programmes from other Commonwealth agencies and other tiers of Government to fund the project.
4. The provision of sufficient funds and other involvement by the proponent to ensure success of the project.
5. The level of support for the proposal from within the Region, and support from other sources including other spheres of government and the private sector.
6. Demonstrated project management experience to undertake the project including the provision of a project budget and ability to meet Government reporting requirements.

7. The project does not compete directly with existing businesses, unless it can be shown that there is an unsatisfied demand for the product/service or the product/service can be provided in a new way.
8. Retrospective funding will not be permitted for any projects.
9. The project should not be inconsistent with other Federal Government policy objectives and relevant law.
10. Proposals must comply with relevant planning and environment laws.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Special Minister of State, upon notice, on 15 May 2002:

quote.para: (1) How many permanent Comcar drivers are there in each capital city.
(2) How many casual Comcar drivers are there in each capital city.
(3) For each of these categories, how many are employed in each capital city (a) under a collective agreement and (b) on an Australian Workplace Agreement (AWA).

(4) During the recent parliamentary adjournment, (a) how many casuals employed in each capital city under (i) a collective agreement and (ii) an AWA were offered employment and (b) what was the average number of hours worked by casuals under (i) a collective agreement and (ii) an AWA in each capital city.

talker.name: Abbott, Tony, MP
Mr Abbott
talker.role: Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service

talk.start.para: —The Special Minister of State has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: *Casual drivers are employed under the APS Award 1998, not a collective agreement. The figures refer to casuals under that award.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, upon notice, on 16 May 2002:

quote.para: (1) Is the Minister aware of the impact of greatly increased cost of internet access for schools in Victoria due to an increase in Telstra charges.
(2) Is the Minister aware of any school that will be reducing its usage of the internet as an educational tool as a result of this increase.
(3) What action, if any, has the Minister taken to ensure that school students have access to the internet at school, at a cost that schools are able to afford.

talker.name: McGauran, Peter, MP
Mr McGauran
talker.role: Minister for Science

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: (1) Yes, the Minister is aware of the new fee structure for Telstra's Edunet service, which applies as of 1 February 2002.

(2) Telstra advises that Victorian schools managed by the Victorian Department of Employment, Education and Training (DEET) are the second group of schools to be offered a new pricing structure. Telstra advises that DEET does not have a preferred supplier agreement with Telstra and so schools in Victoria are able to choose from a number of competing service providers. Telstra advises that, for those schools that have remained with Telstra rather than choosing an alternative service provider, there has been no subsequent drop in internet usage since the price changes.

(3) The Government has put in place a telecommunications regulatory framework designed to encourage the development of a competitive market. As a result there are now approximately 90 licensed carriers and over 600 service providers including internet service providers.

Internet access in schools is the responsibility of State Governments. It is up to State education authorities to determine the communication needs of their particular schools and then determine how best to provide for their needs. States have taken advantage of the competitive market by either going out to competitive tender to find a preferred supplier or, in the case of Victoria, offering schools the opportunity to choose from a number of providers for themselves.
The Minister, through programs run within the Communications portfolio, has introduced a number of initiatives to assist in providing internet access to schools including:
· the $50m National Communications Fund (NCF) which will support high bandwidth data services including to the education sector;
· $15m from the Networking the Nation (NTN) program was provided to assist with the cabling of Tasmanian schools;
· a pilot project for satellite internet access for students of the South Australian School of the Air was also funded by the NTN program; and
many other schools are also benefiting from NTN funding of Internet access facilities in rural towns which, the schools use.

subdebateinfo.title: Family and Community Services: Child Care
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 384)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Children and Youth Services, upon notice, on 16 May 2002:

question.para: (1) Has he seen an article in The Sunday Age on 12 May 2002 titled “Blow-out in waiting lists” that reports Melbourne child care waiting lists for children under three years of age have increased to two years at a number of centres.
(2) Is he aware of similar child care shortages in the Sydney metropolitan area and in particular the electoral division of Lowe.

(3) Has a significant sum been overpaid to child care services; if so, (a) which child care services in the electoral division of Lowe were overpaid and (b) what sum will each child care service in the electoral division of Lowe be asked to repay.
(4) What child care services in the electoral division of Lowe have had debt recovery action commenced against them and how many have subsequently closed.

(5) Is he aware that child care service provider Brunswick Cottage Child Care Centre, Five Dock, is about to close; if so, what assistance can the Government provide to allow it to remain open or have its service relocated.

talker.name: Anthony, Larry, MP
Mr Anthony
talker.role: Minister for Children and Youth Affairs

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Yes.

(2) I am aware that a number of child care centres in the Sydney metropolitan area, including in the electorate of Lowe, are operating at capacity. However, the Commonwealth Government has no limit on the number of long day care places that can be funded and new centres are able to open at any time to respond to demand and be approved for Child Care Benefit funding.

Demand for child care has increased significantly since the introduction of the Child Care Benefit in 2000, which has made child care more affordable. The Coalition Government has allocated over $8 billion over 4 years to child care (2002-03 to 2005-06). More than $4.7 billion was spent in the last 4 years (1997-98 to 2000-01) which is over 36% more in real terms than Labor's last 4 years in office.
(3)(a) The Childcare Assistance debt details and the amount of any CCB overadvances for child care centres in the electorate of Lowe are listed in the table below.

entry.para: Abbotsford Community Centre Inc Vacation Care
Active Kids Preschool Centre of Excellence - Homebush
All Hallows Oosh Care After School Care
Ardill House After School Hours Care
Concord West After School Hours Care
Concord West Before School Hours Care
Homebush Out of School Hours Asc
Homebush Out of School Hours Bsc
Homebush Out of School Hours Vacation Care
Infants Home - Long Day Care Community Based
Mary Bailey House Early Education Centre
Santa Sabina College After School Care
St Anthonys Long day care centre
St Joan of Arc After School Care
St Joan of Arc Before School Care
St Joan of Arc Vacation Care
Strathfield One Stop Child Care Service

answer.para: (b) If a service is advanced more CCB than it passes on to families as a reduction in their fees, future payments of CCB will be reduced by this amount. If a service's advance is likely to be reduced by more than 25%, the Family Assistance Office contacts the service to discuss its financial circumstances and agree on a suitable recovery rate.

Services with a Childcare Assistance debt will be asked to repay the total amount. Services can choose to repay the debt as a lump sum or as a deduction from their CCB advances. Services can negotiate a repayment plan to ensure that they remain financially viable.

(4) Whether services have had debt recovery commenced against them is listed in the table above. The Family Assistance Office's records indicate that no services in the electorate of Lowe have closed since the introduction of CCB.
(5) The Director of Brunswick Cottage Child Care Centre, Five Dock, has advised the Family Assistance Office that the centre is not about to close.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, upon notice, on 27 May 2002:

question.para: (1) Is it a fact that detainees at Woomera are allowed only to use card phones supplied by Pay-Tel Australia Ltd.
(2) Does Pay-Tel charge for calls at $1.25 a minute compared with prices ranging from 9 to 22 cents a minute using normal phone card providers; if not, what are the comparable figures.
(3) Why has his Department entered into, or allowed its contractor to enter into, a monopoly agreement for the provision of this service.

(4) If the substance of the matters raised in this question is correct why is this service that is vital to the well being of those detained being provided at a cost many times the ordinary commercial rate.

talker.name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
Mr Ruddock
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The pay phones in the Woomera IRPC are provided by Pay-Tel and the cards used in them are also Pay-Tel cards.
(2) Pay-Tel advise that their charges are based on 24hr/7day rates. These phones charge a flat call rate of $0.70 per minute Australia wide and to mobile phones, with no flagfall cost.

By comparison, I am advised that Telstra charges for public phones are based on a sliding scale depending on the distance and time of day. Their calls to Sydney and Melbourne start at lower than $0.70 and go higher than $0.70, including the flagfall, depending on the time.
With regards to international calls I am advised by Telstra “Call Pricing” that their rates per minute for public phones are $5.10 to Afghanistan, $3.95 to Iraq and $3.50 to Iran.
I am advised that Pay-Tel international call rates per minute at the Woomera IRPC pay phones are $1.76 to Afghanistan, $1.17 to Iraq and $1.17 to Iran.

(3) The Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs (DIMIA) contracted Pay-Tel in 2000 to provide pay phones at Woomera at a time when Telstra was unable to provide the required service within the specified time frame. Pay-Tel was able to install the phones at very short notice and they also had the technology and a maintenance service suitable for the centre. Time was a critical factor in determining a provider and Pay-Tel was able to meet its 5-day delivery standard.
(4) On the advice received, the substance of the matter regarding call costs is not correct.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Finance and Administration, upon notice, on 27 May 2002:

question.para: (1) Is the Government considering financial incentives to (a) reduce the crude divorce rate and (b) increase the crude marriage rate; if so, what are the details; if not, will it do so.

(2) Are functional marriages and families considered in Commonwealth financial planning as an essential factor affecting the economically sustainable maintenance of a taxpayer pool; if so, how are the crude marriage and crude divorce rates factored into Commonwealth financial planning and budgeting.

talker.name: Costello, Peter, MP
Mr Costello
talker.role: Treasurer

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Finance and Administration has supplied the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: This question does not fall within the Portfolio responsibilities of the Minister.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Finance and Administration, upon notice, on 27 May 2002:

question.para: (1) What percentage of revenue from the 2002-2003 Budget is derived from Commonwealth asset sales.
(2) What sum will be collected, or is projected to be collected, from Commonwealth asset sales of all kinds in the 2002-2003 Budget.
(3) Did the Minister indicate that (a) Medibank Private and (b) ComLand may be sold in the forthcoming financial year.

talker.name: Costello, Peter, MP
Mr Costello
talker.role: Treasurer

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Finance and Administration has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) In accordance with the information provided in Budget Paper No.1, Statement 12 (Australian Accounting Standard No. 31 Financial Statements) the cash the Commonwealth is projected to receive from the asset sales program and the sale of property, plant and equipment and intangibles in 2002-2003 is 2.4 percent of the total cash the Commonwealth will receive from operating and investing activities in 2002-2003.
(2) The Commonwealth is projected to receive cash of $4,244 million in 2002-2003 from the proceeds from the assets sales program and the sale of property, plant and equipment and intangibles.

(3) (a) and (b). No. The Minister for Finance and Administration announced that the Commonwealth will undertake scoping studies in relation to the possible sale of Medibank Private Ltd and ComLand Ltd.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Finance and Administration, upon notice, on 27 May 2002:

question.para: (1) In the 2002-03 Budget is there an increase in defence and border protection budgeting related to the `war against terrorism'; if so what is the rationale for the increase in defence and border protection budgeting.
(2) Did the Minister comment to the effect that Government ought not engage in market activity unless there is a demonstrable market failure.

talker.name: Costello, Peter, MP
Mr Costello
talker.role: Treasurer

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Finance and Administration has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) Yes, there is an increase in defence and border protection funding. Both strong defence and protecting Australia's borders are key priorities in the 2002-03 Budget.

Following the events of September 11, the Government has directed extra funding to Defence to cover the additional costs of deploying armed forces to Afghanistan and the Middle East, at an increased tempo of defence operations over and above the White Paper funding levels.

The Government has also committed to significant enhancement of Defence's counter-terrorist and incident response capabilities, and specifically to better equip the Australian Defence Force to deal with terrorist attacks which are highly planned and coordinated.
The Government has provided:
· $524 million over two years to the Department of Defence to cover the net additional cost of deploying armed forces to Afghanistan and the Persian Gulf; and
· $1,308 million over five years to upgrade security within Australia.

In addition, the Government will provide a further $1,237 million over five years, 2001-02 to 2005-06, on border protection to maintain the integrity of Australia's borders from the endeavours of international people smugglers and for the interception and processing of unauthorised boat arrivals.
(2) Yes.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Finance and Administration, upon notice, on 27 May 2002:

quote.para: (1) Does the 2002-03 Budget make provision for the sale of Sydney Basin airports; if so, what is that provision, if not, does the omission of the sale of Sydney Basin airports in the 2002-2003 Budget mean that these airports are not anticipated to be sold in the 2002-2003 financial year.
(2) Are Australia's airports strategic military assets; if not, why not.
(3) Have the majority of Australia's domestic and international airports been sold to airport lessee companies.

talker.name: Costello, Peter, MP
Mr Costello
talker.role: Treasurer

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Finance and Administration has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: (1) Yes.
It is the Government's policy not to disclose estimated proceeds from sale of assets.

The 2002-2003 Budget includes $12.3 million in additional funding for the Department of Finance and Administration to enable it to continue the program of asset sale activities, including direct costs associated with the sale of the Sydney Basin airports and scoping studies on possible future asset sales.
(2) This issue falls under the portfolio responsibilities of the Minister for Defence.
(3) Yes, leases on the Airports have been sold.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Finance and Administration, upon notice, on 27 May 2002:

quote.para: (1) Is the Minister able to say whether the Senate Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade References Committee was required in its terms of reference on the sale of Australian Defence Industries (ADI) to consider whether the sale of ADI had been conducted with prudence, discretion, integrity, skill and propriety necessary to protect Australias national interest, national security and defence relationships from compromise.
(2) By what process will the security of Australian Defence Force contractual and other relevant information be monitored by the private companies now in ownership of the former ADI interests.
(3) Were ADIs property interests sold to ComLand Ltd, a Commonwealth-owned company group.
(4) Was ADI or parts thereof sold in 1999 to Transfield Corporation; if so, what were those parts; if not, what parts of ADI have been sold and to whom and when were they sold.

(5) Is the sale of ADI consistent with the Ministers philosophy of non-essential market intervention by Government, or words to similar effect, as espoused by the Minister during his address at the Post-Budget breakfast at the Westin Hotel on 15 May 2002; if not, what was the rationale for these asset sales.
(6) In light of the Ministers repeated reference to the 11 September 2001 terrorist attacks in the USA, are the former ADI strategic military assets best held in public or private hands.
(7) Are the former ADI assets of strategic military importance; if not, why not.

talker.name: Costello, Peter, MP
Mr Costello
talker.role: Treasurer

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Finance and Administration has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: (1) The terms of reference included a consideration of these matters.
(2) This issue falls under the portfolio responsibilities of the Minister for Defence.
(3) ADI's development properties were transferred prior to the sale of ADI to ComLand Limited group of companies, which are wholly owned by the Commonwealth.

(4) All the Commonwealth's shares in ADI Limited were sold on 2 November 1999 to Transfield Thompson-CSF Investments Pty Limited, a joint venture company beneficially 50% owned by Transfield Holdings Pty Limited group and 50% owned by Thompson-CSF group now known as Thales.
(5) Yes
(6) This issue falls under the portfolio responsibilities of the Minister for Defence.
(7) This issue falls under the portfolio responsibilities of the Minister for Defence.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Finance and Administration, upon notice, on 27 May 2002:

question.para: Following the inquiry and 2001 report by the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters, what progress has been made by the Electoral Commission in respect to verifying address details for new and transferring electors.

talker.name: Costello, Peter, MP
Mr Costello
talker.role: Treasurer

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Finance and Administration has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: In February 1997 the Australian Electoral Commission (AEC) changed the way it maintains the Roll with the introduction of a register of valid addresses against which all enrolment transactions are applied.

The Address Register provides the AEC with a tool by which integrity checks can be built into its automated Roll Management System (RMANS) to ensure, for example, that a person cannot apply for enrolment at a non-existent address or a non-residential address. It also ensures that official correspondence, including postal ballot papers, are sent to the correct address. The Address Register contains approximately 6.9 million addresses which are valid for enrolment and against which all enrolment transactions are matched. Enrolment applications received for addresses that are not known to RMANS must first be investigated by Divisional staff and, if the addresses are validated, they are added to the Address Register before the elector can be enrolled. However, at the close of rolls for an election, the checks are made after the elector is enrolled.
Comprehensive Address Register Maintenance Procedures were developed and at the end of 2001 implemented in all 150 Divisions to ensure a consistent approach to the identification of addresses.

At regular intervals a range of RMANS data integrity reports is produced to detect inconsistencies in address data. These reports cover missing data fields, inactive addresses and duplicated addresses.

Land use codes are increasingly being applied to non-standard dwellings on the Address Register. These allow for the identification and verification of legitimate multiple surname enrolment dwellings, eg. nursing homes and caravan parks.

Rural road numbering which is continuing throughout the States and Territories provides identification to addresses previously without street numbers or lot numbers. The Address Register is continually being updated with this information as rural road numbering progresses.

Strong relations are needed between AEC Divisional offices and local councils, as in many cases this is the prime means of establishing new developments, redevelopments and to resolve address queries.

Physical Address Register verification work has been undertaken throughout 2001 and 2002 in Tasmania, NSW, Victoria and WA. The purpose of this is to verify existing addresses on the Address Register and to record any additional address information. This will enable more accurate and precise addressing, which in turn ensures the correct enrolment of electors, detection of incorrect enrolments (by identifying non-existent or non-habitable addresses) and subsequently results in increased integrity of the electoral roll.

A fieldwork approach is used where staff drive through areas and record data which includes the verification of land use codes, missing numbers and the identification of addresses where enrolment would not occur, such as business premises, parks and reserves. Information on actual street number ranges is also collected, including street parts and corner references.

The AEC has undertaken GIS pilot projects in NSW and Queensland. The aim of these projects was to give land parcels a true “spot on the earth” which holds promise for further definitions in addressing and verification of Address Register data. The pilots integrated the GIS technology into the AEC enrolment methodology. Both pilots were conducted in four Divisions and the AEC Head Offices in the two States. The selected Divisions covered a variety of geographic and demographic areas and inner urban, outer metropolitan and rapid growth areas and rural areas.
The results of the pilot studies and any future implementation of GIS in Divisional offices are currently being evaluated.

Along with Telstra, Australia Post, the Public Sector Mapping Agency Australia and the Australian Bureau of Statistics, the AEC, through the Electoral Council of Australia, is part of a group which examined, funded and steered a Feasibility Study into a Geo-coded National Address File (G-NAF). Centrelink has also expressed interest in G-NAF, and discussions are being finalised with all members of the G-NAF Group and Centrelink to proceed on the build of the G-NAF. The build phase is to be incremental with an estimated 21 month completion time for the national set. It is intended that all agencies use the single G-NAF Address File. The G-NAF Vision is that it becomes the authoritative national address file. Not only will the G-NAF deliver validated addresses, but there will be greater integrity in data-matching with agencies using the G-NAF.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 27 May 2002:

quote.para: Further to his answer to question No. 13 (Hansard, 14 May 2002, p. 2024), does the Government intend to put any of the proceeds from the sale of Sydney Airport towards the construction of Sydney West Airport. If so, what percentage of the funds; if not, why not.

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
Mr Anderson
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: The proceeds of the sale of Sydney Airport will be used to retire Government debt. The Government has determined that this is the most responsible approach to fiscal management.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 27 May 2002:

quote.para: (1) Further to his answer to question No. 15, part 2 (Hansard, 14 May 2002, 2024), is it the case that the answer to part 2 of question No. 15 relates directly to part 1 of question 15.
(2) Is it the case that the answer to part 1 of question No. 15 relates to part 3 of question number 2667 (Hansard, 20 August 2001, p. 29811).
(3) Does he accept that part 3 of my question No. 2667 (Notice Paper, 20 August 2001, p. 10887) did not refer to the LTOP in any way.
(4) Is it the case that the limit of 80 runway movements per hour at Sydney Airport is governed by the provisions of the Sydney Airport Demand Management Act 1997.

(5) Does the LTOP set targets for aircraft movements per hour during non-curfew periods at Sydney Airport. If so, where are those provisions found; if not, what relevance is his answer to part 2 of my question No. 15, to the issue of 80 movements per hour when he says The implementation of LTOP is a matter for Airservices Australia.

(6) Will he confirm whether the administrative responsibility for the limit of aircraft movements per hour is a statutory responsibility of Airservices Australia and not the subject of a Ministerial Direction pursuant to s.16(1) of the Air Services Act 1996.
(7) Is the statutory limit of 80 aircraft movements per hour for Sydney Airport a factor to be considered by the prospective bidders for the sale of the lease of Sydney Airport; if not, why not.

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
Mr Anderson
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) to (2) The answers are as they appear in Hansard.
(3) It should be noted that parallel runway operations are modes 9 or 10 of LTOP noise sharing.
(4) Yes

(5) No. The answer to part 2 of Question 15 sought to clarify that it was Airservices Australia and not the prospective bidders or eventual owners of the airport that would be responsible for determining modes of operation at the airport including the use of parallel runway modes.

(6) The administration of the Slot Management Scheme, including the allocation of slots, is a function of the Slot Manager for Sydney Airport. The Slot Manager is Airport Coordination Australia. The Slot Manager is appointed under the Sydney Airport Demand Management Act 1997.

(7) The new operator of Sydney Airport is aware that the sale of the airport will not change the Government's noise management policies in any way - the Government retains full regulatory control. Sydney Airport will continue to be subject to the 80 aircraft movements per hour planning cap, the curfew from 11pm to 6am and the noise sharing policy implemented through LTOP.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 27 May 2002:

quote.para: (1) Further to his reply to part 1 of question No. 26 (Hansard, 14 May 2002, p. 2028), will he guarantee the people of Sydney that the long term lease of Sydney Airport will not be sold until the Long Term Operating Plan is fully implemented; if not, why not.
(2) Can and will the LTOP be implemented before Sydney Airport is sold; if not, why not.
(3) Is the sale process of Sydney Airport independent of any duty on the Government to implement the LTOP prior to that sale; if so, why.

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
Mr Anderson
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1)-(3) I have dealt with these matters exhaustively in response to questions previously asked by the Honourable member.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 27 May 2002:

quote.para: Further to his reply to part (a) of question 28 (Hansard, 14 May 2002, page 2028), can he say why?

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
Mr Anderson
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: The effect of the Long Term Operating Plan at Sydney Airport has been to significantly spread noise impacts with a consequent reduction in the overall number of properties within the noise contours that form the basis for eligibility for insulation under the Noise Amelioration Programme.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 27 May 2002:

question.para: (1) Further to his reply to question No. 32 (Hansard, 14 May 2002, 2043), can he confirm, (a) that the Sydney Airport Curfew Act 1995 was an initiative of the Keating Labor Government, and (b) that the Sydney Airport Demand Management Act 1997 followed the attempt by the Labor Member for Grayndler to cap aircraft movements at Sydney Airport to 80 per hour as reflected in his 1996 private members bill, the Sydney Airport (Regulation of Movements) Bill.

(2) In light of the recent fatal aircraft collision at Bankstown Airport, will making Bankstown Airport available as an overflow airport for Sydney increase the risk of aircraft accidents at that airport; if not, why not.
(3) What is the projected increase in aircraft traffic at Bankstown Airport over the next ten years arising from its role as an overflow airport for Sydney Airport.
(4) Which is the busiest airport in the Southern Hemisphere and what position does Bankstown Airport hold on a list of busiest airports.
(5) What was the number of aircraft movements at Bankstown Airport for the year 2001.
(6) On what scientific basis did the Government decide not to further review Sydney's Airport needs before the year 2005.

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
Mr Anderson
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) (a) The legislated curfew was first conceived by the Hon John Howard MP when in Opposition, and it was he who introduced a private members bill to enshrine the curfew in legislation. The Sydney Airport Curfew Act 1995 came into force in December 1995.

(b) No. The commitment to cap aircraft movements at 80 was made in the Government's election policy statement for the 1996 election campaign. The legislation followed 18 months of cooperative effort to develop the Slot Management Scheme.
(2) I refer the Honourable Member to my reply to part 2 of Question 2856.

(3) The projected figures the Honourable Member is seeking are not available. However, figures relating to forecast air traffic will be made publicly available as part of the Master Planning process. Bankstown Airport is required to prepare a Master Plan, in accordance with the Airports Act 1996 guidelines, by 30 September 2003 or no later than 12 months after the transfer of the lease to a new private operator.
(4) & (5) In 2001 Bankstown Airport was Australia's busiest airport with 331,420 movements.

(6) In December 2000 the Government announced that it had concluded that Sydney Airport would be able to handle air traffic demand until the end of the decade and that it would be premature to develop a second major airport for Sydney. In that context the Government considered that a review of Sydney's future airport needs in 2005 was appropriate.

talk.start.para: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 27 May 2002:

question.para: (1) Further to his answer to part 8 of question number 56 (Hansard, 14 May 2002, page 2030), is he aware of a media report titled Three years after death sentence, Colston keeps low profile, which appeared in The Canberra Times on 7 April 2002.
(2) Can he confirm that the DPP had indicated to the press that the door was not completely closed on the Colston matter; if not, why not.
(3) Can he indicate whether the Colston case may now be re-opened by the DPP.
(4) Is he aware of remarks the DPP made to a Senate Estimates Committee in May 2001 regarding the Colston case.
(5) Can he explain the process by which new information might prompt the DPP to review the fitness of Mr Colston to stand trial.
(6) Is the DPP undertaking a process of review in respect to Mr Colston's fitness to stand trial; if not, why not.

talker.name: Williams, Daryl, MP
Mr Williams
talker.role: Attorney-General

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Yes.
(2) Yes.
(4) Yes.

(5) The DPP discontinued the prosecution of Dr Colston because he was unfit to stand trial and there was no prospect that he would become fit to stand trial. If the DPP became aware of a change in these circumstances the DPP would review the matter.
(6) The DPP has indicated previously that the DPP would, if necessary, review the matter in the future.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations, upon notice on, 28 May 2002:

quote.para: (1) Does his Department conduct seminars designed to equip employers to competently handle the recruitment and termination of staff; if so, do the seminars include topics covering (a) awards, (b) agreements and contracts, (c) unfair dismissal and suggested procedures for dismissing staff fairly.

(2) Will he instruct his Department to conduct seminars designed to equip employees to competently handle issues affecting employment and dismissal; if not, why not; if so, will the seminars include topics instructing participants on how to (a) find out what their rights are as employees, (b) lodge a claim for unfair dismissal and (c) lodge a complaint about discriminatory behaviour by their employers.

talker.name: Abbott, Tony, MP
Mr Abbott
talker.role: Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (2) These seminars are aimed mainly at employers. Employees are also welcome to attend. Employer seminars are a more effective use of tax dollars because raising the awareness of one employer can eliminate potential problems for many employees.

The Department's telephone advisory service - WageLine - provides access to instant advice if an employee has been dismissed or is being discriminated against, which seminars often cannot. The WageLine service can also provide personally tailored advice about employee rights more generally. The Department's online service - WageNet - and the Australian Industrial Relations Commission also provide general information about these topics.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 28 May 2002:

quote.para: (1) What properties in Victoria are owned by the Minister's Department.
(2) What is the address of each property.
(3) What is the current estimated value of each property.
(4) For each property referred to in part (1), what plans does the Government have to sell or otherwise dispose of the property.
(5) What method of disposal is planned for each property for which the Department is planning to sell or otherwise dispose of.

talker.name: Vale, Danna, MP
Mrs Vale
talker.role: Minister for Veterans' Affairs and Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question as follows:

quote.para: (as at 6 June 2002)

Longford Loch Sport Rd (via Sale), Buln Buln
Mt Macedon - Australian Emergency Management Intitute
Defence Science and Technology Organisation - Fishermens Bend
