quote.para: * Information relating to the Afton St property, as listed in response to Senate Question No. 136 has been incorporated into the information provided for Maribyrnong (Part Sale).
(3) Valuation detail is considered Commercial-In-Confidence and due to these considerations there are limits with respect to disclosing more detailed information.
(5) Defence properties are sold in line with the Commonwealth Property Disposals Policy, which is available on the Department of Finance and Administration website.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 28 May 2002:

quote.para: (1) What was the number of (a) general and (b) officer recruits into the (i) Royal Australian Navy (RAN), (ii) Army and (iii) Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) in (A) 1995, (B) 1996, (C) 1997, (D) 1998, (E) 1999, (F) 2000 and (G) 2001

(2) What was the total outlay in real dollars of recruitment based advertising (a) in print, (b) on radio and (c) on television in (i) 1995, (ii) 1996, (iii) 1997, (iv) 1998, (v) 1999, (vi) 2000 and (vii) 2001.

(3) What was the total outlay in real dollars of non advertising recruitment based activities for the (a) RAN, (b) Army and (c) RAAF in (i) 1995, (ii) 1996, (iii) 1997, (iv) 1998, (v) 1999, (vi) 2000 and (vii) 2001.
(4) What strategies does the Minister or the Minister's Department have in place or under consideration to increase defence force recruitment in the future.

talker.name: Vale, Danna, MP
Mrs Vale
talker.role: Minister for Veterans' Affairs and Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: (1) Data is reported by financial year (FY), not calendar year. Reliable data is not available prior to FY98/99. The numbers of general and officer recruits for FY1998/99 to FY2001/02 are shown below:
(a) General Enlistment (Full Time and Part Time)
(b) Officer Entry (Full Time and Part Time)

(2) Recruitment based advertising costs (defined as media placement costs) are not readily available for financial years prior to FY1999/2000. Recruitment based advertising outlay figures are expressed as actual dollars spent for each FY, not in real dollars. Available data ($M) is shown below:
(3) Defence Force Recruiting is conducted as a tri-service function and is not broken down into single service expenditure.

(4) Defence will continue its advertising strategy, which is aimed at attracting recruits to the Australian Defence Force as well as regaining and maintaining the Australian Defence Force Brand Image. Defence will:
· continue with process improvements to rationalise recruiting standards and introduce more flexible testing arrangements;
· evaluate a new communication strategy for outcomes and value for money; and

· continue to explore alternative recruiting options such as the current Manpower recruitment outsourcing trial in the Victorian and Southern Region and the Department of Employment and Workplace Relations trial in Queensland.
Defence is investigating:
· a new information technology platform to address several candidate management deficiencies and provide access for candidates to complete electronic inquiries and applications; and
· a delayed entry scheme to allow induction when the training pipeline is ready.
Defence has also:
· launched a new Army Reserve advertising campaign on 25 May 2002;

· instigated a Graduate Recruitment Program to target university students for direct graduate and undergraduate officer entry, to fill all officer entry avenues, other than Australian Defence Force Academy; and
· taken steps to improve the standard of the Career Reference Centres and is considering relocation of some centres to align resources with changing demographics.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 28 May 2002:

question.para: (1) What was the number of defence force personnel in the (a) Royal Australian Navy (RAN), (b) Army and (iii) Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) in (i) 1995, (ii) 1996, (iii) 1997, (iv) 1998, (v) 1999, (vi) 2000 and (vii) 2001.
(2) What was the total expenditure on staff related costs, including wages, superannuation and other entitlements, in (a) 1995, (b) 1996, (c) 1997, (d) 1998, (e) 1999, (f) 2000 and (g) 2001.
(3) What was the total expenditure for the (a) RAN, (b) Army and (c) RAAF on new equipment purchases in (i) 1995, (ii) 1996, (iii) 1997, (iv) 1998, (v) 1999, (vi) 2000 and (vii) 2001.
(4) What was the total expenditure for the (a) RAN, (b) Army and (c) RAAF on equipment maintenance related purchases in (i) 1995, (ii) 1996, (iii) 1997, (iv) 1998, (v) 1999, (vi) 2000 and (vii) 2001.

talker.name: Vale, Danna, MP
Mrs Vale
talker.role: Minister for Veterans' Affairs and Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: Note:
(1) Defence Annual Report (DAR) for the year listed at the top of the column.
(2) Where two amounts are shown as Expenditure, the difference relates to changes in categorisation between Employee and Supplier Expenditure after publication of those years' Annual Reports.

(3) Defence manages its acquisition of major capital equipment purchases through a single organisation, the Defence Materiel Organisation, and not through the separate Services. Information on the capital equipment expenditure program is available both in the Capital Budget table of the annual Defence Portfolio Estimates and Additional Estimates Statements as well as in the Notes to the Accounts relating to Specialist Military Equipment in the annual Financial Statements contained in the Defence Annual Report.

(4) With the new organisational structures in Defence, maintenance related expenditures are no longer managed solely by the three Services or along Service lines. A reasonable assessment of the quantum of maintenance related expenditure is contained annually in the Notes to the Accounts of the Financial Statements in the Defence Annual Report under the expense title of `Suppliers'. Earlier annual reports reflecting the pre-Defence Reform Program organisational structure do include a break up of this expense element by the three Services.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, upon notice, on 28 May 2002:

question.para: (1) What forms of advertising and promotion has net alert undertaken in (a) 2000-2001 and (b) 2001-2002.
(2) What was the cost of this advertising and or promotion.
(3) What forms of advertising or promotion is net alert planning in 2002-2003.
(4) What is the budgeted cost of this advertising or promotion.
(5) How many hits has the net alert website received in (a)2000-2001 and (b) 2001-2002.
(6) How many downloads have been recorded in relation to information on filters.
(7) What plans or initiatives does the Minister have to increase usage of the net alert website.
(8) What plans and initiatives does the Minister have to increase the dissemination of filters.

talker.name: McGauran, Peter, MP
Mr McGauran
talker.role: Minister for Science

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) Under the Online Content Co-Regulatory Scheme, NetAlert has undertaken a range of promotional and advertising activities including:
(a) for the period 2000-2001

· The design and implementation of a website (www.netalert.net.au) to provide information for parents and children on safe Internet use. The website was launched on 1 July 2000 and received 421 996 hits during this period.

· The design and implementation of a national toll-free Help Line and email advisory service to provide easily accessible information on how people can manage their access to the Internet. The Help Line commenced on 6 September 2000.

· The development and distribution of an information kit for Help Line callers, including fact sheets on various Internet issues. The information kit was also distributed to schools and community organisations, and through retail chains and computer stores, during the period.

· Appointing Ms Noni Hazlehurst as the NetAlert Ambassador to promote NetAlert's `safe surfing' message. Ms Hazlehurst appeared at NetAlert events and presented a series of community service announcements and `advertorials' in broadcast and print media.
· Building linkages with community organisations such as schools, libraries and parents' organisations.

· Organising and conducting an Industry Liaison Seminar Series in metropolitan and regional centres throughout Australia, advising Internet service providers (ISPs) and Internet content hosts (ICHs) of their obligations under the Scheme.
· Developing and publishing an information manual and accompanying CD-Rom for the Industry Liaison Seminar Series, and distributing the manual to ISPs and ICHs unable to attend the seminars.
(b) for the period 2001-2002

· Redesigning the NetAlert website, including expanding the content and providing relevant information for specific age groups. At 3 June 2002, the NetAlert website had received 1 106 085 hits during this period.*

· Refining the operation of the Help Line, including producing and updating a manual for the Help Line operators, setting out recent changes in the Internet industry and providing talking points for common queries.
· Continued distribution of the NetAlert information pack, including the completion of a major distribution campaign to schools throughout Australia.

· Continued promotion of NetAlert through the activities of the NetAlert Ambassador, including presenting advertisements and conducting on-air discussions with School of Distance Education participants.

· Continuing to build and foster linkages with community groups, including giving presentations at meetings and responding to requests for information for community and school newsletters, parent magazines and other publications.

· Completing the industry liaison project to inform ISPs and ICHs of their obligations under the Online Content Co-Regulatory Scheme. The two-hour seminars were presented at 27 metropolitan and regional centres.

· Conducting a series of Regional Forums across Australia to promote awareness of NetAlert in regional areas and identify Internet issues of concern to parents and students in these areas: Toowoomba and Townsville, Queensland; Dubbo, New South Wales; Gippsland, Victoria; Launceston, Tasmania; and Berri, South Australia.
· Sponsoring the inaugural NetAlert Gippsland Multimedia Festival.
· Launching with the Australian Broadcasting Authority (ABA) the results of a study into the effectiveness, from a user's perspective, of Internet content filtering software.

Detailed information on the performance of these functions is set out in reports tabled by the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts on 5 September 2000, 19 April 2001 and 13 February 2002.
(b) for the period 2001-2002 $638 807*

With the appointment of an Executive Director to NetAlert in August 2002, several of the existing advertising and promotional activities were deferred due to the development of a strategic plan for NetAlert.
(3) The NetAlert strategic plan for 2002-2003 includes the following advertising and promotional activities:
· Community events across Australia to provide parents and children with information on how to manage their Internet access. A public relations campaign will support the community events.
· A conference scheduled for Canberra with international and Australian speakers.
· Further promotion of NetAlert's safe surfing message to Australian families through a range of media.
· Further targeting of the information on the NetAlert website to community needs.

(4) NetAlert is scheduled to receive $500 000 in Government funds for the 2002-03 financial year. In addition, NetAlert has the ability to seek private sponsorship and may carry over funding from 2001-02.

(6) On 26 March 2002, NetAlert and the ABA released the jointly commissioned CSIRO report into the effectiveness, from a user's point of view, of Internet content filtering software. As of 3 June 2002, the report has been downloaded over 20 000 times from the NetAlert and ABA websites.
In addition, the NetAlert and ABA websites provide information about managing Internet access, including about Internet content filters.

(7) NetAlert is an independent company established by the Commonwealth in December 1999. Operational matters such as initiatives or plans to increase the usage of the NetAlert website are the direct responsibility of the NetAlert Board. To this end, initiatives designed to raise NetAlert's profile and increase usage of the NetAlert website are outlined in response to question 3 above.

(8) Schedule 5 of the Broadcasting Services Act 1992 requires that the Internet industry codes of practice include procedures directed at requiring ISPs to provide subscribers with the option of subscribing to a filtered Internet content service.

On 10 May 2002, the ABA registered revised Internet industry content codes of practice. Content Code 2 was modified to replace the provision allowing ISPs to determine the fee for Internet content filtering services with a requirements that ISPs provide filtering services to subscribers on a cost-recovery basis.

On 26 March 2002, NetAlert and the ABA released a jointly commissioned report into the general effectiveness of existing filtering software. The report, undertaken by CSIRO and entitled “Effectiveness of Internet Filtering Software products”, examined fourteen software products. The report found that the performance of filters may vary substantially, with a key determinant of effectiveness being the type of blocking methodology used by the product. Coupled with the existing community education activities of NetAlert and ABA, the report will assist families to choose the appropriate filtering product or service for their particular needs.
* This information has been provided by NetAlert

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations, upon notice, on 28 May 2002:

quote.para: (1) Is he aware of a recent case in New Zealand where an employee of the ANZ Bank committed suicide as a result of unrealistic targets placed upon him by ANZ Bank.
(2) Is the Minister aware that employee practices are similar for Australian employees of Australian banks.
(3) Are these appropriate practices within the banking industry.

talker.name: Abbott, Tony, MP
Mr Abbott
talker.role: Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) I am advised that in May 2002, the New Zealand Coroner handed down a report regarding the suicide of an ANZ employee. I understand that the Coroner found that the ANZ was not directly responsible for the employee's suicide. However, the Coroner also found that the ANZ”s procedures for setting and monitoring performance targets added to the anxiety and mental illness of the employee.
(2) I am advised that employees working at Australian banks are generally subject to performance management arrangements.

(3) In general terms, performance management systems are an appropriate way to reward performance and assist in the development of a performance culture. I am unable to comment on whether the specific arrangements that are in place in the banking sector are appropriate for that sector.

subdebateinfo.title: Environment: Protection, Rehabilitation and Enhancement Programs

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Environment and Heritage, upon notice, on 28 May 2002:

question.para: (1) How many applications have been made for funding under each of the funding programs through the Australian Greenhouse Office in (a) 1999, (b) 2000, (c) 2001 and (d) 2002.
(2) For each program funded through the Australian Greenhouse Office, in which federal electoral division does the application relate.

talker.name: Kemp, Dr David, MP
Dr Kemp
talker.role: Minister for the Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: The details sought by the honourable member are not readily available and would require a substantial commitment of resources to extract and collate. I have, however, provided the honourable member with details of all grants approved under Australian Greenhouse Office funding programs for the financial years 1998-99 through to 2001-02, including the relevant electorate. Further copies of the details are available from the House of Representatives Table Office.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, upon notice, on 28 May 2002:

question.para: (1) What targets does the Government have in reducing Australia's contribution to the build up of greenhouse gases.
(2) Are these targets in line with international targets and recommendations relating to greenhouse gas.

(3) What are the contributors to greenhouse gas emission and how large a contribution to total greenhouse gas emission does each of the contributors make (a) as a percentage of total greenhouse gas emission and (b) in tonnes.
(4) What plans and strategies does the Government have to reduce greenhouse gas emissions for each of the principal greenhouse contributors referred to in part (3).

(5) Do each of the plans and strategies referred to in part (4) contain targets for greenhouse reduction; if so, for each greenhouse reduction target (a) has the target been met or (b) is the target projected to be met.
(6) What reductions in greenhouse gas emissions have been made in Australia.
(7) What reductions in greenhouse gas emissions are projected for each of the next 10 years.

talker.name: Kemp, Dr David, MP
Dr Kemp
talker.role: Minister for the Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The Government is committed to working towards limiting Australia's greenhouse gas emissions to 108% of 1990 emission levels over the period 2008 to 2012.
(2) Yes, this is equal to the target assigned to Australia under the Kyoto Protocol to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC).
The sources and contributions to Australia's greenhouse gas emissions are set out in the following summary table of Australia's latest National Greenhouse Gas Inventory in accordance with the UNFCCC:

quote.para: Australia's 1999 National Greenhouse Gas Inventory

entry.para: Total Land Use Change and Forestry
FCCC Inventory* - all sectors including land clearing

answer.para: * This shows the effect of including the current (uncertain) land clearing emissions estimates in the estimate of total emissions. This table does not equate fully to the rules for assessing targets under the Kyoto Protocol.

(4) Australia's greenhouse gas emissions occur across a range of sectors in the economy. In response, the Government has developed a comprehensive range of policy approaches, including nearly $1 billion of Commonwealth programs. The National Greenhouse Strategy, announced in 1998, provides the strategic framework for advancing the Government's domestic response. Policies and measures being implemented include:

· in the energy sector, energy market reform, strategies for improving energy efficiency (such as the minimum energy performance standards for appliances and equipment), a range of renewable energy measures (including the mandatory renewable energy target under the Renewable Energy (Electricity) Act 2000), as well as an alternative fuels program for the transport sector; and

· in the land use change and forestry and agriculture sectors, programs to assist in increasing Australia's carbon sequestration capacity through forest and vegetation cover and assist agricultural industries to reduce emissions through sustainable farming practices.
Further detail on these policies and measures can be obtained from the Australian Greenhouse Office's website (www.greenhouse.gov.au).

(5) No, there are no individual targets for specific sectors. The policies and measures under the National Greenhouse Strategy are contributing to Australia's efforts to limit its emissions to 108% of 1990 levels.

(6) and (7) The following table provides estimates of net reductions in greenhouse gas emissions below `business as usual' (excluding the land use change and forestry sector) for the period 2000 to 2012.

entry.para: Estimated net reduction in greenhouse gas emissions(Mt C02-e)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Education, Science and Training, upon notice, on 28 May 2002:

question.para: (1) Did Phillips Fox Solicitors, under the Evaluations and Investigation Program, undertake “The regulatory environment applying to universities” publication released by his Department; if so, (a) when was the work commissioned, (b) what was the budget for the publication, (c) was Phillips Fox approached directly by his Department to undertake this work and (d) was Phillips Fox the only body approached to undertake this work; if so, what was the basis of the decision to do this; if not, to whom was an opportunity to bid for the work offered.
(2) When was the report completed and provided to his Department.
(3) Has his Department undertaken its own assessment of the accuracy of the report; if so, what was the outcome.
(4) What other work is the law firm Phillips Fox undertaking for his Department
(5) Is he able to say what other work Phillips Fox is undertaking for other Departments.
(6) Is he able to say what is the estimated cost of all work undertaken by Phillips Fox for the Government in (a) 2000-2001 and (b) 2001-2002.

talker.name: Nelson, Dr Brendan, MP
Dr Nelson
talker.role: Minister for Education, Science and Training

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Phillips Fox Solicitors did undertake the Evaluations and Investigations Programme (EIP) study “The Regulatory Environment Applying to Universities” which was published by my Department.
(a) Phillips Fox was informed of their successful tender for the study and report on 4 April 2001.
(b) The legal costs charged by Phillips Fox for the study amounted to $60,808, inclusive of GST. Further printing costs were incurred by the Department totalling $12,487.48, inclusive of GST.
(c) Phillips Fox was invited by my Department to provide a tender for the preparation of the report.
(d) The three firms on the Department's legal panel were invited to provide a tender for the project, these firms being Phillips Fox, the Australian Government Solicitor and Clayton Utz.
(2) The Department received the report on 7 September 2001.

(3) The report was assessed for publication, where it was stated that the publishing of the Report would facilitate discussion which may lead to the development of a national framework for university activities. It was also assessed against the project proposal objectives, and was found to meet these objectives and that the Report provided an important addition to the limited knowledge available on the issues it covered.

(4) Phillip Fox Solicitors is one of three legal services panel members providing legal advice to the Department. Under a Deed of Standing Offer between the Department and Phillips Fox legal services are provided to the Department on a needs basis.

(5) I am unable to say what other work Phillips Fox is undertaking for other Departments because the scope of the question falls outside the Education, Science and Training portfolio responsibilities.

(6) I am unable provide an estimated cost of all work undertaken by Phillips Fox for the Government in (a) 2000-2001 and (b) 2001-2002 because the scope of the question falls outside the Education, Science and Training portfolio responsibilities.

subdebateinfo.title: Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation: Organisational Structure
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 423)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Education, Science and Training, upon notice, on 28 May 2002:

quote.para: (1) Has he or his Department undertaken any studies into the organisational structure of CSIRO in the last 7 years.

(2) Have any of these studies involved recommendations that CSIRO merge with, or take over, any other organisation; if so, (a) what was the nature of each recommendation and (b) what has been the Government's response to each recommendation.

talker.name: Nelson, Dr Brendan, MP
Dr Nelson
talker.role: Minister for Education, Science and Training

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) Neither I nor my Department have undertaken studies into the organisational structure of CSIRO in the last seven years, but the issue has been touched upon by the former Chief Scientist, Professor John Stocker, and by the present Chief Scientist, Dr Robin Batterham, in reports they have delivered to Ministers. Both reports considered CSIRO's merger with, or takeover of, other organisations as part of broader remits to examine aspects of Australia's science and technology system.

In preparing his 1997 report Priority Matters, Professor Stocker considered proposals that parts or all of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO), the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation (ANSTO) and the Australian Institute of Marine Science (AIMS) be combined into a larger organisation. Other proposals took the different view that CSIRO, ANSTO and AIMS might be restructured into a number of separate bodies, each related to a different industry sector or group of users. Professor Stocker found that there was no compelling case either for mergers or restructures.

The Chief Scientist, Dr Robin Batterham, considered the possibility of a merger between CSIRO's Division of Marine Research and AIMS in his Review of Marine Research in Tropical Australia, which he finalised in 2001. Dr Batterham concluded that there was no benefit to be gained from the proposition, and that the associated proposition that a new Marine Research Centre be built in Townsville to house both most of AIMS and parts of CSIRO would lead to a net loss in regional marine research capability. He found that AIMS should continue as an organisation independent of CSIRO, and that there were no compelling reasons for folding AIMS into CSIRO, or vice versa.
(2) (a) and (b) No.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Ageing, upon notice, on 28 May 2002:

quote.para: (1) Has the Government (a) considered or (b) undertaken any studies into linking funding increases to aged care facilities to the real costs of nursing wages instead of the national wage case.

(2) Does the Government have any plans to provide additional residential care funding to offset (a) the costs of accreditation, (b) the increased costs for insurance, (c) capital works and (d) certification faced by aged care facilities.
(3) Has the Government investigated the introduction of accommodation bonds for high care residential facilities; if so, what are the Government's intentions in this regard.

(4) Has the Government undertaken any investigations into reducing time spent on documentation by aged care providers to validate the Resident Classification Scale (RCS); if so, what were the outcomes of these investigations; if no, why not.
(5) What incentives is the Government offering to the aged care sector to assist with recruitment and retention of staff.
(6) If such incentives exist, how successful have they been in recruiting or retaining nurses.

talker.name: Andrews, Kevin, MP
Mr Andrews
talker.role: Minister for Ageing

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) to (3) In the 2002-03 Budget the Government has committed $7.2 million over two years to conduct a comprehensive review of the pricing arrangements in residential aged care. The review will commence early in the new financial year and is expected to be completed by the end of 2003.

The Review will examine long-term financing options for the aged care sector and will take into account the improved care outcomes that are now required under accreditation and underlying cost pressures, including movements in nurses' and other wages, and increases in workers' compensation and other insurance premiums.

(4) I have requested that the Department of Health and Ageing examine modified or new funding models for the aged care sector to relieve the paperwork burden on nurses and provide a report of options by August 2002.

Industry is to be consulted in the development of any alternative system. The RCS Industry Liaison Group which includes industry and staff representatives will act as the Steering Committee to oversight the development of any alternative options.

(5) In the 2002-03 Budget and in response to its election commitment, the Government has provided additional funding of $211.1 million over four years ($50 million indexed each year) in increased residential aged care subsidies.

This funding has been provided pending the Review of Pricing Arrangements in residential aged care, to assist providers in meeting many of the cost pressures, including those related to nurses' wage costs.

Further, in the 2002-03 Budget, the Government provided $47.5 million over four years to encourage more people to enter or re-enter aged care nursing, especially in rural and regional areas and to fund the training of care staff in small aged care homes.
(6) It will be some time before the recent budget initiatives can be assessed in relation to their impact on the recruitment and retention of nurses in the aged care sector.

subdebateinfo.title: Health and Ageing: Home and Community Care Funding
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 425)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Ageing, upon notice, on 28 May 2002:

quote.para: (1) Does the Government have any plans to address the shortfall in Home and Community Care (HACC) funding that is being faced by providers.

(2) Is the current level of funding causing a large proportion of otherwise eligible recipients to be denied service for no other reason than inadequate funding; if so, what initiatives has the Government studied or has in place to address this problem.
(3) Are the extensive waiting lists for residential aged care placing pressure on HACC services.
(4) Does he have any plans to address the funding shortfalls in the aged care sector.

talker.name: Andrews, Kevin, MP
Mr Andrews
talker.role: Minister for Ageing

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) In the 2002-03 financial year, the Commonwealth Government's national allocation for HACC is $674.1 million, an increase of 9.5% over 2001-02. If all State and Territory Governments agree to match the Commonwealth's contribution, $1.1 billion will be available to the HACC Program nationally in the 2002-03 financial year.
(2) Growth in HACC funding by this Government far exceeds growth in the numbers of frail aged and people with disabilities needing help.

(4) The Commonwealth Government has made a substantial additional investment in aged care by introducing a number of new aged care initiatives in the 2002-03 Budget. These initiatives build on the Government's six-year record of successful aged care reform and industry growth. Through them, the Government has demonstrated the continuing importance it places on a broad range of issues affecting ageing, including ensuring that older Australians can access a broad range of high quality care options. In total, the Government will provide an additional $509.3 million in aged care over the next four years through the 2002-03 Budget.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, upon notice, on 28 May 2002:

question.para: (1) How many times have Humam Al-Abady's family been split up since they have been in detention.
(2) How many days has Humam been in solitary confinement.
(3) How many times has Humam been confined in a room without a toilet, and for how long.
(4) Were the brother and sister aged six separated from parents and older siblings, if so, for how long.
(5) Did Magistrate Stephen Vose when commenting on these children ask Humam how long will he be guarded by security guards.
(6) Was Humam advised by a doctor at Cumberland Psychiatric Centre that he would not be returned to Villawood; if so, why was he returned.

talker.name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
Mr Ruddock
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) An examination of the family's records confirms that individual members have been separated from the family group on seven occasions.
(2) Humam has never been in solitary confinement. There is no solitary confinement in any immigration detention facility.

(3) There were occasions when Humam and his family were kept under observation following suicide threats and self-harm attempts. Detainees under observation are sometimes accommodated in rooms in a separate compound that do not have toilets. Detainees are escorted to toilet facilities as required. Periods of observation vary depending on the circumstances.

(4) The two younger children were separated from their family under the care of ACM in the Port Hedland IRPC when their parents and the elder siblings were remanded in custody on 26 May 2001 for their involvement in a major incident at Port Hedland IRPC on 11 May 2001. They were reunited with their mother at Port Hedland IRPC on 21 June 2001 and with their older siblings at the Villawood IDC on 6 July 2001.

(5) According to the transcript of the proceedings between the Crown and Humam Al-Abbady and Nashwan Al-Abbady there is no mention of Magistrate Stephen Vose asking Humam how long he would be guarded by security guards.
(6) There is nothing in the consulting psychiatrist's report to suggest that advice was given to Humam that he would not return to the Villawood IDC.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Ageing, upon notice, on 28 May 2002:

quote.para: Further to the reply to question No. 67 (Hansard, 14 May 2002, page 2035) and in light of the recent collapse of UMP and recent media reports indicating a bleak profit forecast for private healthcare corporates like Maynehealth, will the government reconsider establishing a separate Commonwealth agency to monitor the servicing practices and conduct of all private healthcare corporates; if not, why not.

talker.name: Andrews, Kevin, MP
Mr Andrews
talker.role: Minister for Ageing

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Health and Ageing has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: The Government does not consider it necessary to establish a separate agency to monitor corporations involved in the provision of health services. Like all other businesses, medical corporations are subject to review and monitoring by the Australian Security and Investment Commission and the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission. Doctors' service and referral patterns are routinely monitored by the Health Insurance Commission (HIC), which undertakes enforcement action when required. The HIC's mechanisms apply to all doctors, regardless of the type of practice in which they work.

A number of major medical corporations, including Mayne Health, have also taken the step of developing a self-regulatory code of conduct to preserve the clinical autonomy of medical practitioners and to ensure that patients continue to receive high-quality services. The Code of Conduct for Corporations Involved in the Provision of Management and Administrative Services in Medical Centres in Australia was launched on 1 November 2001, and endorsed by the Government, the Australian Medical Association and the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners.

Corporations that sign the code bind themselves to respect and maintain the professional independence and clinical autonomy of medical practitioners. The code enjoins its signatories to respect medical practitioners' professional judgement with respect to diagnosis, referrals, and the number, frequency, length, complexity and style of consultations undertaken with patients.

subdebateinfo.title: Rural and Regional Australia: Regional Solutions Program
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 432)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 28 May 2002:

question.para: (1) How many projects have been approved under the Regional Solutions Programme.
(2) What is the total value of these projects.
(3) Of this total, what are the (a) details and (b) values of each project approved in each electoral division in regional NSW.
(4) How does the Regional Solutions Programme apply its guidelines to fund projects that will lead to stronger local economies and improved access to services.

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
Mr Anderson
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) As at 30 May 2002, a total of 446 projects have been approved under the Regional Solutions Programme.
(2) The total value of these projects is $43,059,230 (GST exclusive) as at 30 May 2002.
(3) See Attachment A.

(4) Applications received under the Regional Solutions Programme are assessed using the same guidelines for funding. Applications that request funding to lead to stronger local economies and improved access to services, as with all other applications submitted to the programme, need to demonstrate that:
· there is a need and/or disadvantage in the local community or region,
· the project will have significance and benefit to the local community or region,
· the outcomes of the project are sustainable,
· there is support for the project, and
· the organisation applying for funding has well developed organisational, financial and project management skills.
Attachment A

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Ageing, upon notice, on 28 May 2002:

question.para: (1) What sum has the Government received (a) since the commencement of the Health and Other Services (Compensation) Act and (b) in 2000-2001 in relation to the Act's requirement that Medicare be repaid for treatment to injured persons upon receipt of compensation.

(2) What sum has the Government received in repaid compensation benefits in 2000-2001 where an injured person is in receipt of Centrelink payments due to their injury and these repayments are repaid as a result of a personal injury compensation award.

talker.name: Andrews, Kevin, MP
Mr Andrews
talker.role: Minister for Ageing

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Health and Ageing has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) Up to April 2002, the Government has received $157,473,000 in Medicare repayments from the commencement of the Health and Other Services (Compensation) Act 1995, including $34,019,000 in 2000-2001.

(2) The Department of Health and Ageing and the Health Insurance Commission do not collect or link information regarding individuals reimbursing the Commonwealth for Medicare payments, under the Health and Other Services (Compensation) Act 1995, with information regarding Centrelink benefits.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, upon notice, on 29 May 2002:

question.para: (1) Further to the answer to question No. 128 (Hansard, 13 March 2002, page 1293), what was the recorded country of birth for all asylum seekers who have been granted a temporary protection visa (TPV) from October 1999 to the present time.

(2) According to the Government's understanding of the situation, are TPV holders and their dependants entitled to access (a) job matching assistance from Centrelink, (b) other assistance from the Job Network, (c) Commonwealth funded childcare services, (d) public school education, (e) English as a second language new arrivals programs, (f) technical and further education and (g) HECS-funded university places.

(3) Have the States and Territories sought any changes to the current entitlements of TPV holders and associated funding arrangements; if so, what are the details of the changes they have sought and how has the Commonwealth responded to their requests.

talker.name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
Mr Ruddock
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Following the introduction of the Temporary Protection Visa (TPV) in October 1999, until 31 May 2002, 8 413 people had been granted TPVs, and are citizens of the following countries:
(2) (a) to (g) TPV holders are eligible for:
. Special Benefit;
. Rent Assistance;
. Family Tax Benefit;
. Child Care Benefit;
. Double Orphan Pension;
. Maternity Allowance;
. Maternity Immunisation Allowance;
. Medicare; and
. The Early Health Assessment and Intervention Program which includes Torture and Trauma counselling.
TPV holders also have:
. the right to work; and
. access to job matching by Centrelink.

TPV holders have access to both primary and secondary public education. They also have access to tertiary education through universities and TAFE colleges. They do not however, have access to HECS-funded universities places that are made available to permanent residents and citizens of Australia.
TPV holders do not have access to Commonwealth funded childcare services, however TPV holders are eligible for Child Care Benefit.
As of 1 July 2002, TPV holders who are minors will have commonwealth government funded access to the English as a Second Language - New Arrivals program (ESL-NA).
(3) I am aware that a number of state and territory governments have raised concerns about cost shifting in relation to the provision of settlement services to TPV holders.

There has been no cost shifting to the states and territories. TPV holders are counted as part of the humanitarian program for which 12 000 places are fully costed each year, and accounted for under Commonwealth/State grant arrangements.

The Commonwealth Government does not believe TPV holders should receive services that Australian citizens and permanent residents, in comparable situations, do not receive. State and territory governments, however, do choose to fund services that the Commonwealth does not provide.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, upon notice, on 29 May 2002:

question.para: (1) Was Humam Al Abbady, a 16 year old who has been in mandatory detention for 3 years including periods of solitary, recently returned from Canterbury Psychiatric Clinic after a third suicide attempt to Villawood Detention Centre.

(2) Why did he or his officers act against the advice of a leading consulting psychiatrist employed by the Government to give expert medical advice, and return Humam Abbady to Villawood Detention Centre.

(3) Why did the Government not immediately implement the advice of the Department of Children's Services that the 3 Abbady children be removed from mandatory detention at Villawood as they are at risk of suicide according to child health specialists.

talker.name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
Mr Ruddock
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) There is no solitary confinement in any immigration detention centre. Humam Al-Abbady was discharged from Cumberland Psychiatric Hospital and returned to Villawood Detention Centre on 14 May 2002.

(2) Where specialist medical professionals provide advice to my Department that can be implemented, such as further treatment or services, that advice is followed. However, where advice is provided that relates to processing status and is contrary to the Migration Act 1958, this advice cannot be implemented.

(3) My Department gives careful consideration to any advice provided, and continues to liaise with other departments and professionals to explore the best management options for these cases. However, the Migration Act constrains my Department from implementing some recommendations or advice from medical or allied health professionals who seek the immediate release from detention for some of their clients.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 29 May 2002:

quote.para: (1) Further to the reply to question No. 27 (Hansard, 14 May 2002, page 2102), how is the Long Term Operating Plan (LTOP) for Sydney Airport substantially implemented in terms of the LTOPs 17% forecast targets for air traffic movements to and from the north of Sydney Airport.
(2) Can he confirm the most recent Airservices Australia statistics in relation to the number of air traffic movements to and from the north of Sydney Airport.
(3) Will the LTOP's 17% target for air traffic movements to and from the north of Sydney Airport be met before Sydney Airport is sold; if not, why not.

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
Mr Anderson
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) and (3) I have dealt with these matters exhaustively in response to questions previously asked by the Honourable member.
(2) Yes.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, upon notice, on 30 May 2002:

question.para: (1) How many visitor visas were issued in each of the past four financial years for full family complements involving spouses and offspring from (a) Beirut, (b) Ankara, (c) Colombo and (d) Manila.
(2) For each of these periods and posts, how many applicants claimed refugee or humanitarian status whilst in Australia.

talker.name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
Mr Ruddock
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The Department does not keep records of Visitor visa applicants in the format requested. Applicants for Visitor visas are recorded as individual applicants and not as the members of a family group.

Table A below provides details of the number of Visitor visas granted to persons at the nominated posts, during the past four financial years. The table details adults, being those persons aged 18 years and above, and children, being those persons aged under 18 years.
The Sponsored Family Visitor visa (subclass 679) commenced on 1 July 2000.

676, 679, 686 visa grants
