subdebateinfo.title: United Nations International Human Rights Treaties
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 442)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 30 May 2002:

quote.para: (1) Has the United Nations established committees to monitor the implementation of twelve international human rights treaties.
(2) Is Australia party to eight of those treaties.
(3) What steps have still to be taken before Australia becomes a party to the:
(a) 1990 International Convention on the Protection of the Rights of all Migrant Workers and Members of their Families,
(b) 1999 Protocol to the 1979 Convention on the Elimination of all Forms of Discrimination against Women,
(c) 2000 Optional Protocol to the 1989 Convention on the Rights of the Child on the Involvement of Children in Armed Conflict,
(d) 2000 Optional Protocol to the 1989 Convention on the Rights of the Child on the Sale of Children, Child Prostitution and Child Pornography.

talker.name: Downer, Alexander, MP
Mr Downer
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) The United Nations has established committees to monitor the implementation of six international human rights treaties: the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights; the International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights; the Convention on the Rights of the Child; the Convention Against Torture and other Cruel, Inhuman or Degrading Treatment or Punishment; the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination; and the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women.
(2) Australia is a Party to the six treaties listed above. Australia is also a Party to the First and Second Optional Protocols to the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights.
(3) (a) Australia would have to sign and ratify the Convention in order to become a Party to it.
(b) Australia would have to sign and ratify the Protocol in order to become a Party to it.
(c) Australia would have to sign and ratify the Optional Protocol in order to become a Party to it.
(d) Australia would have to ratify the Optional Protocol in order to become a Party to it.

subdebateinfo.title: Australian Customs Service: Saville and Holdsworth Pty Ltd
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 443)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Justice and Customs, upon notice, on 30 May 2002:

quote.para: (1) Is SHL a firm currently providing recruitment services to the Australian Customs Service (ACS).
(2) Does the contract between SHL and ACS not provide for feedback to unsuccessful applicants.
(3) Has the Minister, the Minister's office, or ACS considered the benefit such feedback would provide to unsuccessful applicants.
(4) Will SHL provide feedback to unsuccessful applicants without payment.

(5) Does SHL charge (a) $100 for a report outlining the findings of a personality measure and timed test against a relevant comparator group and (b) $332 for a report on the group based assessment program, including psychometric report.
(6) Is the ACS conforming to its responsibility as a Public Service employer to assist those who are unemployed or who are seeking employment.

talker.name: Williams, Daryl, MP
Mr Williams
talker.role: Attorney-General

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Justice and Customs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: (1) Yes. An open tender process was advertised in February 2001, and on 9 November 2001, Customs entered into a contract with Saville and Holdsworth Pty Ltd (SHL) for recruitment and selection services. Contract handover was 1 February 2002.

(2) There are three main methods of recruitment to Customs, at entry-level through the Customs Trainee or Graduate Trainee programs or general recruitment, as positions become available. All entry-level processes involve testing and assessment through SHL, however, most general recruitment involves an application and Customs interview. Feedback from SHL is only relevant to entry-level recruitment and a small number of general positions where testing and/or assessment is used as an optional service.

The contract provides for SHL's ongoing contact with applicants, including information and advice about their progress through the selection process, at any point during the selection process. A free call 1800 number is provided for applicants to contact SHL for enquiries.

The contract provides that specific feedback from SHL to unsuccessful applicants on their performance at testing or assessment centre is an optional service, available by phone or face-to-face, at a fee of $332 per hour (pro rata).
Detailed feedback from Customs selection panels is available to applicants applying for general recruitment positions and for applicants who progress to Customs interview for entry-level positions.

(3) Prior to the current recruitment services contract, when Customs has used service providers for testing and assessment services, Customs has paid an additional fee to the service provider for feedback to applicants (on a case-by-case basis).

Given Customs experience of consistently high numbers of applicants for entry-level roles in Customs, there is potential for high numbers of requests for feedback. During February - April 2002, 6305 applications were received for Customs Trainee roles, for approximately 117 positions. For these four recruitment processes alone, there is potential for 2292 applicants to request feedback from SHL on their performance at testing and/or assessment centre. This potential for high numbers of applicants requesting feedback was a major consideration in initially deciding on a user-pays arrangement for applicant feedback.

Once an applicant progresses to the Customs interview stage, Customs selection panels provide performance feedback to the applicant. For entry-level recruitment, Customs is unable to provide detailed feedback to applicants who do not make it to interview, as Customs selection panels do not have specific knowledge of their performance, just a summary of ratings by criteria.

Feedback arrangements, where applicants pay for detailed feedback and career counselling from SHL, are consistent with standard industry practice, particularly for high volume recruitment processes, such as Customs entry-level programs.
However, after consideration of the numbers of requests for feedback and related issues, Customs has decided to pay reasonable costs associated with feedback for all selection processes.

(4) Under the contract, SHL will maintain contact with applicants about their progress through the selection process, but specific performance feedback and career counselling for applicants is an optional service for a specified fee.

(5) Under the contract, feedback to applicants incurs a fee of $332 per hour, calculated on the amount of time spent in preparing or delivering the feedback. SHL has a range of feedback options available, including written reports and verbal feedback or a combination of the two.

(6) Customs upholds and promotes the APS values, providing reasonable opportunity to eligible members of the community to apply for employment, promoting equity in employment and making merit-based employment decisions. Customs advertises positions in the Commonwealth Government Gazette, on Customs website and some positions are advertised in the press. Members of the community can access Customs recruitment information via the website, email or a free call 1800 number. Customs will pay reasonable costs for performance feedback to applicants on test and assessment results. Feedback is available to all applicants who progress to Customs interview.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 30 May 2002:

quote.para: Who were the members of the crew of HMAS Supply for the three month period ending 30 September 1973.

talker.name: Vale, Danna, MP
Mrs Vale
talker.role: Minister for Veterans' Affairs and Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: Due to Privacy regulations it is not appropriate to release this information to the public.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 30 May 2002:

quote.para: (1) Are six Australian soldiers officially listed as missing in action during the Vietnam War.
(2) Was the last investigation into this matter made in May 1984.
(3) What action has the Minister's Department taken on this issue since 1984.

(4) Given the technological advances since 1984, particularly in the area of DNA identification as well as a vastly improved diplomatic and political relationship with Vietnam, will the Minister revisit this issue and order a new investigation in an attempt to locate and recover the bodies of these six Australian soldiers; if not, why not.

talker.name: Vale, Danna, MP
Mrs Vale
talker.role: Minister for Veterans' Affairs and Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: (1) There are six Australian service personnel officially listed as missing in action during the Vietnam War, four from the Australian Army and two from the Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF).
(2) Yes.

(3) As a result of recent initiatives by the Government, a meeting was held in Melbourne on 5 June 2002 between representatives of the Australian Defence Force (ADF) and Mr Jim Bourke, who is responsible for the `Operation Aussies Home' website, to discuss the recovery of the remains of missing ADF personnel in Vietnam. Also discussed was ADF policy and supporting procedures and information concerning the six missing in action cases. Information gaps relating to these personnel were identified.
A further meeting is to be held in Canberra in late June or early July 2002 between Mr Bourke and the Army History Unit and the RAAF research staff to try and determine the location of the personnel.

(4) As part of the new investigation, the Department of Defence has agreed to re-examine the possibility of assisting with the collection of DNA samples from next of kin once policy, legal and privacy issues have been resolved. Mr Bourke has advised that DNA samples have been collected and passed to the United States Central Identification Laboratory in Hawaii for registration. Department of Defence assistance with the collection of DNA samples is required in only two cases.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, upon notice, on 30 May 2002:

question.para: (1) Further to the reply to question No. 283 (Hansard, 14 May 2002, page 2143), has the Minister seen the evidence submitted to the Senate Environment, Communications, Information Technology and the Arts Legislation Committee inquiry into the Broadcasting Services Amendment (Media Ownership) Bill 2002 by (a) Dr Derek Wilding of the Communications Law Centre, (b) Mr Stephen Kimber, a former Canwest journalist, (c) Mr Charles Britton from the Australian Consumers Association, (d) Ms Alison O'Neil from regional radio broadcaster, Grant Broadcasters, (e) Professor Ken McKinnon, Chairman of the Press Council and (f) Ms Gail Hambly, Counsel for Fairfax.

(2) Did Dr Wilding reveal that the editorial separation provisions of the Bill represent a de facto repeal of the cross-media ownership laws opening the way to further concentration of media ownership.
(3) Did Mr Kimber reveal that, whilst working as a Canwest journalist he suffered blatant editorial interference under similar laws in Canada.
(4) Did Mr Britton state that the Bill was not in the interests of consumers because it would lead to a further concentration of media ownership.
(5) Did Ms O'Neil reveal that there has to be job losses if the Bill is passed.
(6) Did Professor McKinnon express serious concerns about the Bill's threat to the freedom of the press from government interference.
(7) Did Ms Hambly question the constitutionality of the editorial separation provisions of the Bill.

(8) In light of the overwhelming evidence submitted to the Senate inquiry raising very serious concerns for the public interest and Australia's democracy were the Bill to become law, will the Minister now abandon the bill; if not, why not.

talker.name: McGauran, Peter, MP
Mr McGauran
talker.role: Minister for Science

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) to (7) I am aware that these individuals put forward views on the Bill to the Senate inquiry.

(8) No. The Government made an election commitment to reform Australia's media ownership laws. Without reform, the current media ownership laws will restrict the Australian media sector to an outdated structure with little or no capacity for new players, improved competition, or the ability to respond to a rapidly evolving and converging international media environment.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, upon notice, on 30 May 2002:

question.para: (1) Has the Minister seen an article titled “No, Minister: Alston gets it wrong” written by the former Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party and Minister for Communications, Mr Neil Brown QC published in The Age newspaper on 29 May 2002.
(2) Does the Government share the view that fashioning broadcasting policy to fit in with the convenience of the media owners is the worst thing a Communications Minister could do; if not, why not.
(3) Does the Government share the view that broadcasting policy should be a mogul-free zone; if not, why not.
(4) Does the Broadcasting Services Amendment (Media Ownership) Bill 2002 benefit media owners but no one else; if not, why not.
(5) Is the Bill intended to benefit the employees of media owners and the general public; if not, why not.
(6) Does the Bill make it very easy for the media moguls to sell out to foreign interests or amalgamate with each other or do both; if not, why not.
(7) Does the Government share the view that the Australian media is the biggest single influence on forming our national identity and culture; if not, why not.
(8) Does the Bill abolish the specific ban on foreign ownership in the media and lump it in with breakfast foods or whatever else is up for sale; if not, why not.
(9) Does the Bill allow for a foreign takeover of most of our media industry; if not, why not.
(10) Does the Bill do nothing to promote competition or allow new entrants into the Australian media; if not, why not.
(11) Do the current cross-media ownership laws restrict media owners to their own television station, radio station or newspaper in the one market.

(12) Have the current cross-media media ownership laws been responsible for the Australian media having a variety of media owners, stopping media owners from being too dominant and guaranteed at least some diversity in opinion; if not, why not.
(13) Does the Bill allow exemptions or Government dispensations to the current cross-media ownership laws; if so, why; if not, why not.
(14) Does the Bill allow the Australian Broadcasting Authority (ABA) to provide exemptions or dispensations to the current cross-media ownership rules; if so, why; if not, why not.

(15) Does the Bill allow exemptions or dispensations to be made in secret and with no public scrutiny so that the public may never know the conditions to which any media takeovers are subject; if so, why; if not, why not.
(16) Does the Bill invite the ABA to keep media takeover information secret if anyone's commercial interests could be harmed by disclosure; if so, why; if not, why not.
(17) Does the Bill give four separate rights of appeal to disgruntled media companies if they lose out on any stage of the takeover process; if so, why; if not, why not.
(18) Does the Bill allow a similar right of appeal for anyone who wants to stop an amalgamation after it has been granted; if so, why; if not, why not.
(19) Does the Bill guarantee that media outlets will keep separate editorial departments after an amalgamation has taken place; if so why; if not, why not.
(20) Does the Bill allow newly amalgamated media outlets to simply share resources or co-operate as satisfying the Bill's requirement for separate editorial departments; if so, why; if not; why not.
(21) Will the Bill lead to journalists losing their jobs when amalgamated media outlets share resources; if not, why not.
(22) Will the Bill lead to giant, concentrated news services, where one night's television news becomes the next day's leftovers for press and radio; if so, why; if not, why not.
(23) Will the Minister now abandon the Bill; if not, why not.

talker.name: McGauran, Peter, MP
Mr McGauran
talker.role: Minister for Science

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) Yes.

(2) to (5) The Government made an election commitment to reform Australia's media ownership laws. Without reform, the current media ownership laws will restrict the Australian media sector to an outdated structure with little or no capacity for new players, improved competition, or the ability to respond to a rapidly evolving and converging international media environment.

Repealing the restrictions on foreign ownership and control under the Broadcasting Services Act 1992 (BSA) will improve access to capital, increase the pool of potential media owners and act as a safeguard on media concentration.

(6) Acquisitions by foreign investors will remain subject to the Foreign Acquisitions and Takeovers Act 1975 (FATA) and the Government's foreign investment policy. The Bill provides for exemptions to the cross-media ownership regime; it does not repeal the cross-media restrictions.

Restrictions on the number of licences able to be controlled by an individual organisation (two radio licences or one commercial TV licence in each licence area) and limits on audience share to 75% of the Australian population for commercial television broadcasters will remain.
(7) No. Media organisations represent one of a number of major influences on national identity and culture.
(8) and (9) See answer to part (6).
(10) See answer to part (1) - (5).

(11) No. The cross-media rules do not apply to all newspapers, only to newspapers listed on a Register of Associated Newspapers which is maintained by the Australian Broadcasting Authority (ABA). Additional commercial television broadcasting licences can be issued in a single licence area under sections 38A or 38B of the Broadcasting Services Act 1992. In the case of radio, a single owner / controller is already permitted to hold two commercial radio broadcasting licences in the same licence area.

(12) The current cross-media laws are anachronistic in a converging media environment. The measures contained in the Bill will improve Australian media companies' access to capital, facilitate investment in new technologies and ensure Australian consumers continue to have access to world-leading communications services. The current restrictions on foreign and cross-media ownership constrain the Australian media sector within outdated structures, with little opportunity to respond to the converging international media environment.

(13) and (14) Yes. Allowing the ABA to issue exemptions to the cross-media rules will improve Australian media companies' access to capital, facilitate investment in new technologies and ensure Australian consumers continue to have access to world-leading communications services.

(15) and (16) The Bill empowers the ABA to grant `exemption certificates' to applicants seeking to acquire media organisations that would otherwise represent a breach of the cross-media rules. Exemptions will be subject to applicants meeting requirements to maintain separate editorial decision-making responsibilities. The ABA must make the results of an investigation available for inspection on the Internet, unless it is satisfied that the publication of the results could reasonably be expected to prejudice substantially the commercial interests of a person, and the prejudice would outweigh the public interest in the publication of the results.
The Bill requires that holders of an exemption certificate publish organisational charts and editorial policies for affected organisations on the Internet.

(17) and (18) The Bill includes complaint processes for applicants and non-applicants. If the ABA refuses to grant an exemption certificate, the decision is reviewable by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal (AAT).

Under Part 11, Division 1, Section 147 of the BSA, if a person believes that another person who is providing a broadcasting service has committed an offence against the Act or the regulations or breached a condition of a licence or a class licence, the person may make a complaint to the ABA about the matter.

(19) (20) and (22) The Bill empowers the ABA to grant `exemption certificates' to applicants seeking to acquire media organisations that would otherwise represent a breach of the cross-media rules. Exemptions will be subject to applicants meeting requirements to maintain separate editorial decision-making responsibilities.

Before issuing an exemption certificate, the ABA must be satisfied that the conditions proposed in the application are sufficiently specific and detailed, and that they will be adequate for the applicant to continuously meet `the objective of editorial separation' for the set of media operations concerned within a time period specified by the ABA. The legislation notes that requirements for editorial separation will not prevent the sharing of resources or other forms of cooperation between jointly-controlled media operations, provided that the requirements above continue to be fulfilled.

(21) The Explanatory Memorandum indicates that some `consolidation' of the media sector could occur; however, the actual employment effects are difficult to predict. Provision for adequate local news coverage for regional broadcasters subject to a cross-media merger could be expected to have a positive impact on journalist employment in regional areas.
(23) No. The Government made an election commitment to reform Australia's outdated media ownership laws.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, upon notice, on 30 May 2002:

question.para: (1) Further to the reply to parts (3) and (4) of question No. 262 (Hansard, 14 May 2002, page 2127), why did the Howard Government not spell out to the people of Australia before the last Federal election that, in supporting exemptions from existing cross-media rules, it intended to introduce legislation into the Federal Parliament to change Australia's cross-media ownership laws to allow a media proprietor to own newspapers, television stations and radio stations in the one licence area.

(2) Further to the reply to part (6) of question No. 262, can the Minister name any other commercial media owner in Australia who has as much influence in the print media or print and electronic media as Mr Rupert Murdoch or Mr Kerry Packer; if so, who.

(3) Further to the reply to part (7)(a) of question No. 262, (a) why does the Broadcasting Services Amendment (Media Ownership) Bill 2002 propose that a person or organisation could be granted an exemption certificate from existing cross-media laws, effectively, in secret; (b) does the Bill propose that a disaffected media owner or media organisation could appeal against an adverse decision in relation to a refusal to grant an exemption certificate and (c) does the Bill propose that no one can appeal against a media owner or media organisation being granted an exemption certificate; if so, why and is this in the public interest and good for our democracy.

(4) Further to the reply to parts (8) and (9) of question No. 262, does the Bill propose that a media owner or media organisation could be allowed to own newspapers, television stations and radio stations in the one licence area; if so, why and is this in the public interest and good for our democracy.

(5) Further to the reply to part (10) of question No. 262, will the Minister introduce stand alone legislation to change Australia's media-specific foreign ownership laws to allow more media owners to operate in Australia; if not, why not.

talker.name: McGauran, Peter, MP
Mr McGauran
talker.role: Minister for Science

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) The Government's election policy clearly stated its intention to reform Australia's media ownership laws, and detailed the proposed new system of exemptions, subject to undertakings on editorial independence and minimum levels of local news, that would replace it.

(2) Proprietors of commercial media in Australia include News Limited, Publishing and Broadcasting Limited (PBL), John Fairfax Holdings Ltd, The Seven Network Ltd, Southern Cross Broadcasting Ltd, Rural Press Ltd, Daily Mail Group (DMG) Radio Australia, Austereo Ltd, and APN News & Media.

(3) (a) The Bill empowers the Australian Broadcasting Authority (ABA) to grant `exemption certificates' to applicants seeking to acquire media organisations that would otherwise represent a breach of the cross-media rules. Exemptions will be subject to applicants meeting requirements to maintain separate editorial decision-making responsibilities. The Bill requires that holders of an exemption certificate publish on the Internet organisational charts and editorial policies for media outlets operating under the certificate.

The legislation also requires that the ABA maintain a Register of active cross-media exemption certificates, including the conditions to which the cross-media certificates are subject. The Register must be made available to the public for inspection on the Internet. Information which could reasonably be expected to substantially prejudice commercial interests will not be included in the Register where this prejudice would outweigh the public interest in the publication of the information.

(b) and (c) If the ABA refuses to grant a certificate, only applicants may apply to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal (AAT) for judicial review of the decision. An ABA decision to grant a certificate would also be reviewable under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977 (the ADJR Act), on the application of a person aggrieved by the decision. (Under the ADJR Act, an aggrieved person includes a person whose interests are adversely affected by a decision.)

Existing complaint processes in the Broadcasting Services Act 1992 (BSA) will continue to apply, under which a complaint may be made to the ABA, including by a member of the public, if it is suspected that a breach of licence or other regulatory requirements has occurred. These processes ensure an appropriate level of accountability by broadcasters and their controllers.

(4) Yes, subject to the conditions of the `exemption certificate' and compliance with the Trade Practices Act 1974 (TPA) and the Foreign Acquisitions and Takeovers Act 1975 (FATA). Limitations on the control of commercial television and radio broadcasting licences will also continue to apply. These restrictions limit the number of licences a person may control in a single licence area (two radio licences; or, subject only to subsections 38A and 38B of the BSA dealing with single and two station markets, one commercial TV licence in each licence area). The restrictions also prohibit a person from exercising control of commercial television broadcasting licences whose combined licence area population exceeds 75% of the population of Australia. Mergers and acquisitions in the communications industry will continue to be regulated under provisions of the TPA, including the substantial lessening of competition test.

(5) No. The Government is committed to reforming Australia's media ownership laws in a manner that will both encourage competition and ensure that a diversity of opinion and information is maintained. Without reform, the current media ownership laws will limit the Australian media sector to an outdated structure with little or no capacity for new players, improved competition, or the ability to respond to a rapidly evolving and converging international media environment.
Removal of foreign ownership restrictions and changes to the cross-media laws are both necessary to improve the regulatory framework and increase diversity and competition.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Ageing, upon notice, on 3 June 2002:

question.para: Are (a) migrants or (b) holders of class 309 visas or any other spousal visas, arriving in Australia after July 2001 and over thirty years of age, eligible for an exemption to the two per cent for every year over the age of thirty Lifetime Health Cover surcharge when taking out private health insurance; if so, why; if not, why not.

talker.name: Andrews, Kevin, MP
Mr Andrews
talker.role: Minister for Ageing

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Health and Ageing has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (a) A migrant arriving in Australia after July 2001 and over thirty years of age is eligible for an exemption to the Lifetime Health Cover (LHC) surcharge when taking out private health insurance if that person is the holder of a protection visa. Holders of protection visas have until the first anniversary of the day they become eligible for Medicare in which to take out hospital cover without incurring an LHC penalty. A migrant who is not the holder of a protection visa is exempt if he or she was an applicant for a permanent visa or permanent entry permit before 30 September 1999 and was granted a permanent or transitional visa before 1 July 2002 and if granted the visa outside Australia, enters Australia as holder of that visa before 1 July 2002, and applied to the Minister before 1 July 2002 for an exemption under the hardship provisions.

(b) A holder of a subclass 309 visa or any other spousal visa arriving in Australia after July 2001 and over thirty years of age is eligible for an exemption to Lifetime Health Cover surcharge when taking out private health insurance if that person was eligible under the general migrant provisions above, or that person applied for a Partner Provisional Class UF Subclass 309 visa and Partner Migrant Class BC visa before 30 September 1999, and entered Australia as holder of a Partner Provisional visa before 1 July 2002, and remained an applicant for a Partner Migrant visa, and applied to the Minister before 1 July 2002 for an exemption under the hardship provisions
The exemptions noted in (a) and (b) above are provided for in sections 5(c) and 10 of Schedule 2 to the National Health Act 1953.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, upon notice, on 3 June 2002:

quote.para: (1) Are all decisions of the Refugee Review Tribunal (RRT) still published; if not, what criteria determine which decisions will not be published and who decides this.
(2) For each of the past 3 years, how many decisions have been made by the RRT and how many decisions have not

talker.name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
Mr Ruddock
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) No. Section 431 of the Migration Act 1958 provides that the Registrar must ensure the publication of any statements prepared under subsection 430(1) that the Principal Member thinks are of particular interest.
On 31 May 1999, the then Acting Principal Member issued guidelines, as to what statements (decisions) were of particular interest, in the following terms:
“Direction pursuant to subsection 420A(1) of the Migration Act

Pursuant to subsection 420A(1) of the Migration Act 1958 (the Act), I, Peter Nygh, Acting Principal Member of the Refugee Review Tribunal, direct that for the purposes of subsection 431(1) of the Act the following statements prepared under subsection 430(1) of the Act are of particular interest:

Statements representing a broad cross section of decisions having regard to factors such as the country of reference, the outcome of the review, whether there is detailed consideration of legal principles, and whether the factual circumstances are complex or unusual, or whether they are common to a large number of cases.
Statements which would require extensive editing for the purposes of subsection 431(2) are likely to be difficult to follow and therefore not of particular interest.”

The person occupying the position of RRT Bulletin Editor chooses the decisions which are to be published, in accordance with the Direction above. The RRT Bulletin is a publicly available document which contains, amongst other things, summaries of selected decisions.
(2) The following information is provided for the financial years commencing 1 July 1999, up to 31 May 2002.

subdebateinfo.title: Australian National Audit Office: External Audit Services
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 454)

talk.start.para: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 4 June 2002:

question.para: (1) Has Arthur Anderson ever provided external audit services for or on behalf of the Australian National Audit Office (ANAO); if so, in relation to which Departments or agencies.
(2) What was the tender process involved in choosing Arthur Anderson in each case identified in part (1).
(3) Have any ANAO staff who were involved in the tender process, subsequent to the tender being awarded, benefited from a contract of employment with Arthur Anderson.

(4) Have any staff involved in the HIH/FAI affair participated in any external audit services performed by Arthur Anderson for or on behalf of the ANAO; if so, has the work been adequately and appropriately addressed by senior executive staff to ensure that the audit was undertaken with the appropriate level of diligence and rigour that public accountability requires.

talker.name: Howard, John, MP
Mr Howard
talker.role: Prime Minister

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: I am advised by the Australian National Audit Office as follows:
(1) Details of audit services provided by Arthur Andersen are set out at Attachment A.
(2) In each case the tender process was restricted to the `Big 5' Accounting Firms.

(3) One staff member who was involved in the tender processes for both Australian Postal Corporation and Medibank Private in 1998 left the ANAO on leave without pay on secondment to Arthur Andersen in October 2000 and returned to the ANAO in December 2001.
This staff member was also involved with the expressions of interest sought for contract-in resourcing for Centrelink/DFACS.
(4) Yes. Over the past few years, approximately 100 Arthur Andersen staff have worked on ANAO projects. Of these, six were engaged on the HIH audit.
Insofar as the ANAO project managed audits are concerned, the agreements require that audit services shall be performed in accordance with the following:
(a) in a manner that displays a demonstrable understanding of the role of the Auditor-General;

(b) in a manner that exhibits a clear understanding of statutory audit obligations, including those under the Commonwealth Authorities and Companies Act and the Financial Management and Accountability Act and the Auditor-General Act as applicable, and any other relevant legislation and in a manner that fully complies with those obligations;
(c) to a standard that represents best industry practice for equivalent services;
(d) to achieve best value for money for the Commonwealth in the provision of the Audit Services;
(e) to ensure that the Commonwealth is fully and accurately informed on all matters which are the subject of the Audit Services; and
(f) in a manner which ensures compliance with the Contractor's obligations under the Contract.

The ANAO quality assurance processes ensure that the Contractor's work is reviewed to ensure that the audit work is professional. The Contractor is required to provide a description of the methodology, the quality control processes and quality assurance policies and procedures employed by the Contractor throughout the audit engagement. At the completion of the audit, the relevant Partner of the firm is required to `sign-off' that the audit has been completed in accordance with the ANAO Auditing Standards. The Standards require, amongst other things, all working papers are subject to quality control and assurance procedures. Also the firm has to declare that is has not undertaken audit or other services in relation to the client or related entitles which have not been approved under the Audit Agreement. If such other services have been approved they must not give rise to any conflict of interest and the fees relating to such work have not given rise to any economic dependency, which could jeopardise the firm's independence.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Ageing, upon notice, on 4 June 2002:

question.para: (1) On what basis did the Minister approve an average 3.4% increase to premiums for those with health insurance through MBF as part of the latest round of premium increases.
(2) In making assessments on premium increases for health insurance, does the Minister take into account the services and medical procedures covered by funds.
(3) Is the Minister aware that MBF has conducted a review of its levels of cover and subsequently reduced its levels of cover.
(4) Is the Minister also aware that MBF has removed a long standing discount for premium payments made by direct debit; if so, does that removal constitute a premium increase.

(5) When assessing requests by health funds for premium increases, does the Minister make it a requirement that, where premium increases are approved, the levels of coverage for the fund are maintained?

talker.name: Andrews, Kevin, MP
Mr Andrews
talker.role: Minister for Ageing

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Health and Ageing has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) All requests for premium changes are considered in accordance with statutory requirements. The Minister is empowered under subsection 78(4) of the National Health Act 1953 (the Act) to declare that a premium change shall not come into operation if she is of the opinion that the change:
. would or might result in a breach of the Act or of a condition of registration of an organisation;
. imposes an unreasonable or inequitable condition affecting the rights of any contributors; or
. might, having regard to the advice of the Private Health Insurance Administration Council, adversely affect the financial stability of a health benefits fund.

The Minister is also empowered under subsection 78(4A) of the Act to declare that a premium increase shall not come into operation if she is of the opinion that the increase would be contrary to the public interest.
(2) The Minister for Health and Ageing considers all the requirements of the Act as set out in (1).
(3) Yes.
(4) Yes, the Minister is aware that MBF has removed a discount for premium payments on one of its products. No, the removal does not constitute a premium increase.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 4 June 2002:

question.para: (1) Are there plans to sell off part of the historical Maygar Barracks in Camp Road Broadmeadows; if so, (a) what is the time line for sale and (b) what size allotment is to be sold from the site.
(2) Will the Commonwealth consider giving some of the land proposed for sale back to the local community.
(3) How did the Commonwealth obtain the land where the present barracks stand.

talker.name: Vale, Danna, MP
Mrs Vale
talker.role: Minister for Veterans' Affairs and Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) Yes.
(a) Financial Year 2002/03
(b) 10 hectares of the Maygar Barracks site will be retained by Defence, and the remaining 50 hectares identified for disposal.

(2) The Commonwealth Property Disposals Policy states that Commonwealth Property, having no alternative efficient use, is to be sold on the open market at full market value. There are no provisions in the Policy to give some of the land to the local community.
(3) The property was purchased by Defence in 1915 from a local land owner.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations on 4 June 2002, who has referred this question, upon notice, to the Minister for Transport and Regional Services:

quote.para: (1) What regions have been identified to be pilot sustainable regions under the Regional Assistance Program.
(2) What is the allocation of funding to each region under the program.
(3) What is or was the purpose of each grant.

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
Mr Anderson
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: I would like to clarify that the pilot regions are not under the Regional Assistance Programme as referred to in the Honourable Member's question, they are under the Sustainable Regions Programme.
(2) Six of the regions will receive up to $12m, Atherton will receive up to $18m and Wide Bay Burnett will receive up to $8m.
(3) The purpose of the programme is to:
· Provide a national approach to supporting designated regions across Australia undergoing major change;
· Assist regions undergoing major economic, social and environmental change to build a viable foundation for the future; and
· Promote a whole of government approach to regions by Commonwealth Government agencies.
· In designated regions the Federal Government will assist locally based Advisory Committees established under the programme to:
· Formulate and test future development options for the region;
· Identify and support specific activities to promote sustainable development;
· Support community leadership in the development of local solutions;
· Foster new ideas, community energy, drive and self reliance; and
· Forge partnerships between the private sector and all three spheres of government.
