talk.start.para: asked the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, upon notice, on 4 June 2002:

quote.para: (1) What funding from the Natural Heritage Trust has been provided within the electoral division of Calwell.
(2) In each case, what (a) was the nature of each grant and (b) sum of Commonwealth funding was provided to each program.

talker.name: Kemp, Dr David, MP
Dr Kemp
talker.role: Minister for the Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) As at 5 August 2002, a total of $2,042,715 in funding has been directed to 24 projects via the Natural Heritage Trust and related programs within or including the electoral division of Calwell.

(2) These projects may be located (a) solely with the electoral division of Calwell, or (b) across a number of electoral divisions, including Calwell, as is often the case with large-scale projects. A list of projects is attached.

The term “related programs” refers to programs existing prior to the establishment of the Trust. Funds budgeted for these programs were additional to the Natural Heritage Trust, with delivery and administration of the programs undertaken through the Trust.

entry.para: Recovery Plan preparation for the Sunshine Diuris or Fragrant Doubletail (Diuris fragrantissima). This species occurs west of Melbourne and is now only known from 1 site in the wild. RP preparation is expected to take 12 months (subject to seasonal conditions) and will involve genetic and habitat/relocation studies, surveys and writing of the plan.

Recovery Plan preparation for the endangered orchid- Caladenia amoenia (Charming Spider-Orchid). This project includes clarification of habitat requirements and genetic variance of populations, surveys, management actions- fencing, weed control and ex-situ breeding, and writing of the Recovery Plan. The long-term aim is to secure the known wild populations, locate further populations, and reintroduce the species to areas of its former range. The project, including Recovery Plan preparation, is expected to take 12-18 months to complete.
ISP #20 Assessment of Analgesic/1080 bait combinations for Humane Predator Control

Two potential analgesics, suited for inclusion with 1080 baits have been identified by VIAS. A one year study is proposed to assess the potential of these bait additives to address the `possibility' of pain. This is proposed to be undertaken in collaboration with the major welfare agencies and non-government organisations.
Western Plains Grasslands Research Plan Phase 2

The project will conduct a series of experimental trials involving Western Plains Grassland sites (Laverton North, Derrimut and BHP Petroleum). Trials will involve experimental burns, various methods of weed control, the effects of light grazing as a management tool. Rare and threatened species in selcted experimental areas will be monitored for population numbers, reproduction and mortality. Forbs (Common Everlasting, Lemon Beautyheads and Scaly Buttons) will be planted at experimental plots.
N407 - Purchase and co-operative management of Craigieburn grassland

This proposal is to acquire the Craigieburn grasslands, a property that has nationally significant ecological values including 5 nationally significant species and a threatened ecological community. The proposal involves a combination of purchase of some 333 ha for permanent reservation as a protected area, and cooperative management of a further 112 ha of contiguous grassland which will remain in private ownership and be managed in accordance with formal cooperative management agreements.

The project will implement an essential action plan of the Port Phillip and Westernport Regional Catchment Strategy, by developing action plans in each of the Westernport, Dandenong, Maribyrnong and Werribee catchments, based on priorities established under the Regional Catchment Strategy.
N419 - Purchase of Plains Grassy Woodland property, Grampians

Before 1750, Plains Grassy Woodland was widespread across the State, covering over 4 million hectares, mostly within the Victorian Midlands, Victorian Volcanic Plains, Riverina and Mallee IBRA regions. These areas were particularly suitable for agricultural activities, a consequence of which most areas in the State have been substantially cleared. Only about 3% of the original coverage remains Statewide, substantially within the Victorian Midlands IBRA Region. The proposed land purchase is an area of mature-age Plains Grassy Woodland which is of comparatively high quality. This is unique as most other sites have been intensively managed for timber harvesting and show a minimal age structure. As such, it will be a significant addition to Victoria's protected area system. The land abuts the Grampians National Park and will be added to the Park.
Eastern Barred Bandicoot Recovery in Victoria
A single years implementation (1998) of a recovery plan (1997-2000) for the Eastern Barred Bandicoot in Victoria.
Spider Orchid (seven Caladenia species) Recovery Plan (preparation and interim action)

Prepare recovery plans for seven nationally threatened Caladenia Spider Orchids endemic to Victoria and implement urgent interim recovery actions for Caladenia formosa, C. fragrantissima ssp orientalis, C. lowanensis, C. thrysanochila, C. versicolor, C. xanthichila.
Permanent Protection of Threatened Habitat - Port Phillip

Employment of a person to proactively encourage landholders with areas of regionally significant native vegetation to put in place Conservation Covenants to ensure their longterm protection. Acceleration of the Trust for Nature land covenanting program, targeting priority areas. The aim is to achieve the permanent protection of 2,000 hectares of remnant vegetation on private land in the Port Phillip region. The aim is to have at least half of this protected land being the rarer, high priority vegetation types in the region: Grasslands, Plains Grassy Woodlands, Swamp Scrub and other riparian vegetation and ephemeral wetlands.
Field assessment of target and non-target effects of predator baiting

This project is field-testing a simple and inexpensive field bait marker (Rhodamine B) to assess the impacts of predator baiting on non-target species, determine the target efficacy of poisoning campaigns, and evaluate alternative bait deployment methods. An important aspect of the project will be an evaluation of the feasibility of aerial distribution of baits. Aerial baiting, while successful and cost-effective in WA, requires formal assessment of target efficacy and non-target impacts before it can be considered for use in other regions of Australia.
Preliminary assessment of analgesic compounds for 1080/analgesic combination in baits for humane predator control (1998/99 - 3rd year of project)

To assess whether adding an effective analgesic to 1080 baits to remove the possibility of a painful death for foxes from 1080 baiting. The death of an animal as a result of 1080 poisoning appears slow and stressful however, whether the animal is suffering from extreme distress or pain is unknown. Previous research from this project has shown that drugs d1 and d2 together may manage both potential anxiety and pain as well as minimising the duration and extent of convulsions. Further research needs to be done to investigate the merit and potential efficacy of using these drugs in combination.
Development of a Rapid Field Test for Measuring the Serological Status of Wild Rabbits to RCD
Development of a rapid field test for measuring the serological status of wild rabbits to RCD to allow more effective management of RCD.
N424 - Increasing comprehensiveness of the Victorian Volcanic Plains IBRA through strategic land purchases - Burrah Burrah

This property, which is available for sale now, is an inlier to Grampians National Park. The property contains a herb-rich woodland/claypan ephemeral wetland mosaic, which is the only known location for this floristic community combination in the State. It also provides habitat for the Brolga and Great Egret. The property also contains redgum woodland, an indicator of good agricultural land. This is why the property was originally alienated from the Grampians National Park. The property is surrounded by the Park on three sides and also adjoins Public Reserve and Crown Land.
N425 - Acquisition in the Victorian Volcanic Plains IBRA - McNaughtons

Part of 19021 Contains an extensive area of a Red Soils Grassland (low rainfall) (VH) and smaller areas of Grey-Brown Soils Grassland (low rainfall) (VH), Low rainfall Plains Grassy Wetland (VH), Gorge Shrubland (VH), Creekline Tussock Grassland (VH) and possibly Grassy Woodland Complex (limestone exposures)(VH).

Seeks funding to establish a catchment-wide communication network using demonstations on BMPs and on-ground works to tackle the land-use issues with land managers in the Werribee catchment. This project will result in a catchment-wide communication network assisting over 2000 individual rural landholders form a landcare network to tackle sustainable agriculture issues. It is important to develop an effective community network to be able to comprehensively address the important land & water degradation issues away from the Werribee River. In the first year the project will concentrate on establishing links to the individuals through meetings, demonstrations of BMPs and identify their needs for natural resource management. The project will use this information to help members of the Network implement on-ground works for sediment, and nutrient runoff, salinity and erosion in the catchment high priorities.
Development of an Alert list for Birds
This project combines both the categorisation of species and development of an early warning system.
Indochinese coastal awareness and care project

This project is an extension of the “Community Education and Protection of Shellfish and Marine Animals in Port Phillip Bay” which our Association has successfully carried out in 1995/96. Through such pilot project, we discovered that further understanding of Indochinese people about the role of human impact on the Bay's living systems, as well as the vital role that human can play on rectifying the damages via responsible attitudes and actions such as educational promotions and cleaning. This project is aimed to provide educational visits to the Bay and educational centres such as the Gould League, and to involve clean up days on the Bay.
N432 - Acquisition - Purchase of Blacks Creek - 221 hectare grassland property, Skipton, Victoria.

221 ha of native grassland in the Victorian Volcanic Plain. These grasslands have been substancially cleared for grazing and cropping and are a priority for conservation in the NRS. The property is one of a series of hight quality sites of Volcanic Plains Grassland in the V V P IBRA region and will contribute to a significant network of both private and public reserves managing native grasslands for conservation. The purchase will add to under-represented ecosystems on the V V P. The presence of nationally significant plant species and linkages to other grassland sites makes this property a valuable acquisition for the NRSP. There was once 1.5 million hectares of grasslands on the Plain - currently there is only about 8000 ha and these are scattered fragmented parcels. The site contains about 70 species of indigenous plants, with 2 nationally significant. See Assessment for more details.
Plants of the Southern Sandbelt: Revegetating Bayside Melbourne

Revegetation and landscaping projects using indigenous plants often suffer from inappropriate selection or use of plants. This project aims to produce a book providing crucially lacking information about how to use local, native plants in the bayside area of Melbourne to achieve revegetation and landscaping goals. The expected outcome is greater success of community and industry based projects, leading in turn to greater community support of such projects in the future. Increased habitat creation and community awareness will be other important outcomes of this project.
N434 - Acquisition of `Ridge Paddock' a Plains Grassy Woodland/Grassland property, Woorndoo, Victoria

This project aims to purchase 127 ha of Plains Grassy Woodland/Grassland in the Victorian Volcanic Plain for addition to the NRS. Plains Grassy Woodlands and Grasslands have been substantially cleared or modified throughout southeastern Australia and are priority ecosystems for addition to Victoria'a protected area system. The property adjoins an existing nature reserve'Cobra Killuc', and its purchase and addition to this reserve would create one of the largest protected areas in the VVP bioregion (over 630ha combined). The site contains a number of threatened flora species and provides habitat for the nationally threatened Golden Sun Moth, Plains-wonderer and potential habitat for Eastern Barred Bandicoot. Its location near other smaller grassland sites highlights its significance. Purchase of this property will help to ensure that victorian volcanic Plain grassy ecosystems are comprehensively represented in the NRS.
N436 - Acquisition of wetland ecosystem, Nerrin Nerrin, Victoria

This project aims to purchase 70ha of shallow and deep freshwater marsh wetlands in the Victorian Volcanic Plain IBRA for addition to the NRS. These ecosystems have been substantially drained or modified throughout southeastern Australia and are priority ecosystems for addition to Victoria's protected area system, in accordance with NRS criteria. This property contains two of the five wetlands that make up the nationally significant Nerrin Nerrin wetland system. The presence of 16 threatened flora and fauna species and species covered under JAMBA/CAMBA agreements, highlights its significance. Purchase of this property will help to ensure that Victorian Volcanic Plain wetland ecosystems are comprehensively represented in the NRS.
Fencing of Significant Native Grassland Sites within the City of Brimbank

Native grasslands are one on the highest priority ecosystems to protect in Victoria, and particularly in the Metropolitan west of Melbourne where remnants are threatened by urban and industrial development. This project is seeking assistance from Commonwealth to protect and fence Council owned grasslands in the inner Metropolitan City of Brimbank
Land Degradation Incentives across Port Phillip

This project seeks assistance to add to the Land Protection Incentive Scheme and tackle the many hundreds of individual properties in hot spot areas for erosion (Region wide) and salinity fencing or recharge (Westernport Region). The project conducted as a Devolved Grant along the same lines as the LPIS, already has a number of small proposals offering to improve the situation for erosion and some salinity recharge in a favourable cost-share approach. The project has three components, all contributing to general stewardship of land; (a) assist those selected properties already listed in the attachment; (b) advertise for further erosion proposals to address erosion and select those according to the criteria and (c) advertise for recharge fencing proposals in the Westernport catchment where there is a recently completed salinity plan. Many of the main degraded areas are not yet under some form of Group. This project seeks to address the gaps, and enable some consideration of being a catalyst for stewardship in

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 4 June 2002:

quote.para: (1) Has it been 8 months since the Sydney Airport Community Forum met to discuss the impact of aircraft noise on the residents of Sydney.
(2 What is the date of the next meeting.

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
Mr Anderson
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) The last meeting of the Sydney Airport Community Forum was held on 14 August 2001.

subdebateinfo.title: Internova Travel Pty Ltd: Employee Entitlements
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 472)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations, upon notice, on 4 June 2002:

question.para: (1) Further to the answer to part (3) of question No. 54 (Hansard, 14 May 2002, page 2045), what steps, if any, is he taking to determine the extent of the unpaid wages.
(2) What administrative action is he or his Department taking to ensure that proper settlement payments are made to the former employees of Internova.

(3) Further to the answer to part (3) of question No. 54 and in light of the fact that Internova is not a former Ansett group company and therefore was never subject to the provisions of the Special Employee Entitlements Scheme (SEES) for Ansett Group Employees, are steps being taken to ensure that those estimated 540 former Internova employees are given industrial entitlements similar to those of former Ansett employees equivalent to the SEES provisions; if so, when; if not, why not.

(4) Was any Government supervision or scrutiny made of the sale of Traveland to Internova, in light of what now appears to be a commercial transaction involving the sale and transfer of a strategic national travel agency to a company that was ab initio fundamentally incapable of providing that service; if so, what supervision was undertaken; if not, why not.

talker.name: Abbott, Tony, MP
Mr Abbott
talker.role: Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) On 26 March 2002 the liquidator of Internova Travel Pty Ltd provided my department with verified data on the level of unpaid entitlements, including wages, owed to the former employees of Internova Travel Pty Ltd.

(2) Following the provision of verified employee entitlement data by the liquidator of Internova Travel Pty Ltd and checking by my department, funds have been advanced under the General Employee Entitlements & Redundancy Scheme to the liquidator of Internova Travel Pty Ltd.

(3) Former employees of Internova Travel Pty Ltd have been assessed for assistance under the General Employee Entitlements & Redundancy Scheme consistent with the terms and conditions of the industrial instruments applying at the date of their termination.
(4) These matters are not my portfolio responsibility.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 3 June 2002:

question.para: (1) How does the arrest of 72 year old human rights intellectual Siamak Pourzand and the gaoling of Iran's best known human rights lawyer Mehrangiz Kar reflect on the Government's belief that the moderate Khatami faction is ascendant in Iran and that engagement with the regime will undermine the dominance of Ayatollah Ali Khamenei and his hard line clerics.
(2) Is the Australian Embassy aware of where Mr Pourzand is imprisoned.
(3) Is he able to say whether Mr Pourzand has been sentenced to eight years in prison, or has Mr Pourzand been sentenced to eleven years in prison plus 199 lashes for various moral offences.
(4) Are the additional charges of “warring with G-d” still pending; if so, will Mr Pourzand face the death penalty.
(5) Is he able to say how many democratic activists and pro reform journalists are in gaol in Iran.
(6) Is he also able to say whether the Siamak Pourzand case shows that the policies of Iran's would-be reformers are losing the debate in Iran.

talker.name: Downer, Alexander, MP
Mr Downer
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The progress of reform in Iran is slow and subject to occasional setback. We regularly discuss with the Iranian Government the need for increased transparency of process and adherence to the development of civil society. We raise regularly human rights concerns with Iranian officials, including the case of Mr Pourzand. Dr Mehrangiz Kar is currently released on bail and is residing in the United States.
(2) Press reports indicate that police officials transferred Mr Pourzand to Evin prison in northern Tehran on around 7 May 2002.
(3) Mr Pourzand was initially sentenced to 11 years but the prison term has apparently been commuted to eight years.
(4) There has been no official statement confirming that Mr Pourzand faces any additional charges.

(5) According to news reports, at least six journalists and 30 others are currently in Iranian gaols for crimes of a political nature. Charges remain extant against a considerably higher number, who have not yet been tried or sentenced.

(6) The state of the reform movement in Iran can be seen in the increasingly open discussion of matters previously considered taboo, the willingness of individuals and the Parliament to defend publicly political and economic reform objectives and the recent bill in the Parliament banning torture. This signifies a marked shift in atmosphere which has been evident since President Khatami's first election as President in 1997. The case of Mr Pourzand is of concern, but it would be simplistic to state that it alone represented the state of the reformist program in Iran.

talk.start.para: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 5 June 2002:

question.para: (1) At my request pursuant to standing order 150 did the Speaker write to him on or about 14 May 2002 seeking reasons for the delay in his answering, amongst other questions, my question No. 11 which appeared on the Notice Paper on 13 February 2002.

(2) Is he aware of the criticisms of the Government's Broadcasting Services Amendment (Media Ownership) Bill 2002 expressed by the former Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party and Minister for Communications, Mr Neil Brown QC, in an article titled “No, Minister: Alston gets it wrong” published in The Age on 29 May 2002.
(3) Has he spoken with Mr Brown about the opinions expressed in the article; if not, why not.
(4) Will he ask the Communications Minister to speak to Mr Brown about the article; if not, why not.
(5) When will he answer question No. 11.

talker.name: Howard, John, MP
Mr Howard
talker.role: Prime Minister

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Yes.
(2) Yes.

(3) and (4) No. Mr Brown's opinion is one of a number that has been expressed in relation to the Broadcasting Services Amendment (Media Ownership) Bill 2002. It would be impractical for me, or the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, to discuss media policy with every person who has expressed an opinion.
(5) I am advised by my department that the answer to the honourable member's question was lodged on 12 June 2002 and appeared in Hansard on 17 June 2002.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 5 June 2002:

quote.para: Is he able to say whether the Iranian Government has banned more than 50 newspapers, confiscated satellite dishes, shut down privately owned Internet service providers and murdered dissident intellectuals since President Mohammed Khatami took office.

talker.name: Downer, Alexander, MP
Mr Downer
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: Since President Mohammad Khatami took office, the Judiciary has suspended or closed over 50 newspapers and magazines in Iran (some have subsequently been allowed to recommence publication). There are currently more than twelve daily newspapers published in Tehran, representing a mix of editorial views. Illegal satellite dishes have been confiscated and privately-owned Internet service providers which did not have proper permits were closed down. A number of dissident Iranian intellectuals were murdered in 1998 and 1999. Members of the Intelligence Ministry who were responsible for the murders were arrested, tried and convicted. The Minister for Intelligence at the time of the murders resigned from the cabinet.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Trade, upon notice, 5 June 2002:

question.para: (1) Has his attention been drawn to trade negotiations between the European Union (EU) and the Islamic Republic of Iran and claims that Iran's foreign trade is highly controlled by hardline Islamist factions through Bonyads or revolutionary foundations.
(2) Is he able to say whether the Bonyad known as the Imam Reza Foundation controls $20 billion in assets and the Matyrs Bonyad controls close to $15 billion dollars.
(3) Is he able to say whether the Bonyad foundation directors are appointed solely by the hard line Islamist faction led by Ayatollah Khamenei.

(4) Is he able to say whether one of the beneficiaries of the Bonyads stranglehold of foreign trade was the former head of the Revolutionary Guards Mohsen Rafiqdust, head of the Bonyad called Foundation of the Oppressed.
(5) Is he able to say whether the Foundation of the Oppressed has been involved in a decade long campaign to divert the earnings and profits of trade to nuclear and biological weapons.
(6) Is he able to say whether the Bonyad known as The Martyrs Foundation has delivered the profits of foreign trade to subsidise suicide bombings in Israel and Turkey.
(7) Is he able to say whether the Bonyad known as the 15th Khordad Foundation is still offering a multimillion dollar reward for the murder of British author Salman Rushdie.
(8) Does the Islamist dominated regime exempt the foreign trade Bonyads from taxes whereas private enterprises in Tehran are subject to 50 different taxes
(9) Is it a fact that hardliners such as the opponent of President Khatami, the former president Hashemi Rafsanjani, control the multimillion dollar pistachio trade.

(10) Is he also able to say whether the reformist cleric Hadi Ghabel questioned in a 24 March 2002 sermon in Isfahan how those close to the leaders of the regime have taken over the states treasury, wasting unlimited public funds on acquiring firms and buildings for themselves all over the world while simultaneously, girls in Tehran engage in prostitution in order to make a living for themselves and their families.
(11) Does Australian and EU trade to Iran disproportionately pump more money into the wallets of the reformists adversaries.

talker.name: Vaile, Mark, MP
Mr Vaile
talker.role: Minister for Trade

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Yes.

(2) Available estimates suggest that the value of the Imam Reza Foundation could be around US$20 Billion. Estimates of the value of the Martyr's Foundation vary. There is no way to determine with accuracy the value of the assets of either foundation.
(3) Yes.
(4) Mr Mohsen Rafiqdoost is the former head of the Revolutionary Guards. He was replaced as head of the Foundation of the Poor and the Dispossessed in July 1999.
(7) Yes.

(8) Most of the Bonyads are classified as charitable foundations and are therefore considered tax exempt. In early 2002, the Iranian Parliament asked the Supreme Leader to review this position, suggesting that Bonyads provide their financial reports to the Government in order to assess whether they had tax obligations arising from their economic activity. Iran's taxation laws for private enterprises are complex and involve different levels of tax.
(9) I understand former President Ayatollah Hashemi Rafsanjani has significant interests in the pistachio trade.
(10) Hojjat ol-Islam Hadi Ghabel regularly criticises the conservative leadership of Iran. I am not aware of the specific comments to which you refer.

(11) Australia has a legitimate commodity trading interest with Iran and in 2000-01 had a trade surplus of $727.6 million with it. I am not in a position to say who is the end recipient of revenue generated by bilateral trade with Iran. I cannot comment on EU trade with Iran.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, upon notice, on 6 June 2002:

question.para: (1) Is he able to say whether the US has agreed to accept any people who have sought asylum in Australia and who are now held in detention facilities outside Australia's mainland.
(2) Has Australia agreed to resettle Haitian and Cuban nationals who have sought asylum in the US; if so, are these people being redirected from the country of first asylum.

(3) Are there any plans for Australia to resettle Cuban or Haitian nationals who have sought asylum in the US; if so, would such arrangements meet Australia's obligations under the UN 1951 Refugee Convention?

(4) With which countries is Australia consulting in regard to the possible resettling of asylum seekers detained by the Australian Defence Force in offshore detention centres and what has been the outcome of these consultations.
(5) How many detainees are currently in detention at the (a) Nauru, (b) Manus Island, (c) Christmas Island and (d) Cocos Island facilities.
(6) How many detainees are currently in detention in mainland Australian facilities and how many are in each facility.
(7) What is the country of origin of each detainee referred to in parts (5) and (6).

talker.name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
Mr Ruddock
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The Government, at both ministerial and senior official levels, and UNHCR are in discussion with a number of resettlement countries seeking resettlement outcomes for those in offshore processing centres who are found to be refugees. The United States is one such country.

(2) In line with our commitment to international responsibility-sharing, Australia agreed to resettle one Haitian family and one Cuban family who had been intercepted in waters off the United States and found by the US authorities to be in need of protection.

(3) The Government has no plans at present to resettle in Australia more people who have sought asylum in the United States, although we would consider further requests in the spirit of international responsibility-sharing. Australia's obligations under the Refugees Convention are geographically limited to refugees in Australian territory. Our resettlement program goes beyond any international obligations and reflects Australia's desire to assist refugees who are in greatest need of resettlement as a durable solution to their plight.

(4) Persons in offshore processing centres are not detained by the Australian Defence Force. The immigration status of persons in processing centres in Papua New Guinea and Nauru is a matter for the countries concerned. Discussions are continuing between the Government and several other countries on the resettlement of people in offshore processing centres who are found to be refugees. In addition to the 59 asylum seekers accepted in May, the Government of New Zealand has indicated its willingness to provide a significant number of resettlement places in the near future. Australia also will accept its fair share.

(5) The immigration status of persons in offshore processing centres in Papua New Guinea and Nauru is a matter for the countries concerned. In relation to the offshore processing centres, the populations are (a) 1,095 (as at 18 June 2002) and (b) 340 (ditto). In relation to Australian centres, the populations are (c) 77 (as at 10 June 2002) and (d) 0 (ditto).

(6) On 10 June 2002 there were 1,384 non-citizens in immigration detention on the Australian mainland. Forty-two were in the Maribyrnong Immigration Detention Centre (IDC); 54 in the Perth IDC; 135 at the Port Hedland Immigration Reception and Processing Centre (IRPC); 235 at the Woomera IRPC; 273 at the Curtin IRPC; 509 in the Villawood IDC; and 136 at other facilities (e.g. hospitals, prisons, private apartments) or in transit.
(7) Note: countries of origin represented by fewer than five asylum seekers or detainees are omitted to protect individuals' identity.

As at 18 June 2002 the stated countries of origin of asylum seekers in the Nauru processing centre are Afghanistan (751 people), Iraq (296), Palestinian Authority (27), Iran (15) and Sri Lanka (5). In respect of those at the Manus Island processing centre the countries of origin are Iraq (318), Turkey (6) and Bangladesh (6).

As at 10 June 2002 the stated country of origin of detainees in mainland detention facilities were as follows. Maribyrnong IDC: Afghanistan (5), Iran (5); Perth IDC: Norway (6), Palestinian Authority (5), United Kingdom (5); Port Hedland IRPC: Iran (49), Afghanistan (29), Palestinian Authority (13), Sri Lanka (12), Iraq (6), Bangladesh (5); Woomera IRPC: Iran (99), Afghanistan (97), Iraq (27), Palestinian Authority (5); Villawood IDC: China (120), Indonesia (55), South Korea (39), Iran (26), Philippines (22), India (20), Fiji (17), Bangladesh (16), Iraq (13), Malaysia (12), Thailand (11), Nepal (9), Tonga (9), Pakistan (7), Korea (so stated) (6), Russian Federation (6), British National Overseas (5), Samoa (5), Sri Lanka (5), stateless (5), United Kingdom (5), unknown (5); other facilities and in transit: Indonesia (27), Afghanistan (18), China (9), Iran (9), Vietnam (9), Iraq (5), New Zealand (5), Papua New Guinea (5).

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, upon notice, on 6 June 2002:

question.para: (1) How many street posting boxes have been removed by Australia Post since 1 January 2000 from the postcode areas of (a) 6018, (b) 6019, (c) 6020, (d) 6021, (e) 6022, (f) 6029, (g) 6060, (h) 6061 and (i) 6062.
(2) What plans does Australia Post have to remove street posting boxes in the postcode areas of (a) 6018, (b) 6019, (c) 6020, (d) 6021, (e) 6022, (f) 6029, (g) 6060, (h) 6061 and (i) 6062.

talker.name: McGauran, Peter, MP
Mr McGauran
talker.role: Minister for Science

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, based on advice received from Australia Post, has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) Australia Post has not removed any street posting boxes from the nine postcode areas listed since 1 January 2000.
It has relocated and temporarily removed street posting boxes within some of the postcode areas listed since 1 January 2000, the details of which are as follows:
(a) 6018 -1 box relocated,
(b) 6020 -1 box temporarily removed and re-installed,
(c) 6021-1 box relocated, and
(d) 6061-1 box temporarily removed and re-installed and 1 box relocated.
(2) Australia Post plans to remove one street posting box from postcode area 6018 in the next 12 months.

A four-week review of the box located in the grounds of Edith Cowan University revealed that customers were posting an average of 16 articles per day, which is well below the prescribed, acceptable level of usage of at least 25 articles per day.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, upon notice, on 6 June 2002:

quote.para: (1) What funding from the Natural Heritage Trust has been provided within the electoral division of Stirling.
(2) In each case, what (a) was the nature of each grant and (b) the sum of Commonwealth funding provided to each program.

talker.name: Kemp, Dr David, MP
Dr Kemp
talker.role: Minister for the Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) As at 5 August 2002, a total of $6,279,417 in funding has been directed to 36 projects via the Natural Heritage Trust and related programs within the electoral division of Stirling.

(2) These projects may be located (a) solely with the electoral division of Stirling, or (b) across a number of electoral divisions, including Stirling, as is often the case with large-scale projects. A list of projects is attached.

The term “related programs” refers to programs existing prior to the establishment of the Trust. Funds budgeted for these programs were additional to the Natural Heritage Trust, with delivery and administration of the programs undertaken through the Trust.

entry.para: The plan aims to decrease the chance of extinction of this species by doubling the population and creating at least three wild populations. Actions include management of two Nature Reserves where the species currently lives, population monitoring, captive breeding and translocations, rehabilitation of land for inclusion in one of the Nature Reserves, and education, pubicity and sponsorship.
Ecological communities (WA agricultural areas) Interim Recovery Plans (preparation)

The project builds on earlier work (funded by the National Reserves System Cooperative Program and CALM) which established a list of 110 possible Threatened Ecological Communities (TECs) occurring in the South West botanical province of WA, almost all restriced to that region. Recovery actions for over 70 suspected threatened ecological communities have not been able to be categorised or recovery actions identified because of lack of information. The project aims to identify and assess these TECs, to draft Interim Recovery Plans for them, and to promote their conservation and assist landholders to aid in their recovery.

Project renamed Development of Integrated Conservation for 6 Critically Endangered WA Orchids. This proposal will continue study into reproduction, propogation and translocation of six threatened orchids in WA all Critically Endangered. Species include Caladenia busselliana, Drakea isolata, Caledenia viridescens, Caledenia winfieldii, Epiblema grandiflorum var cyanea and Pterostylis sp 9 (Northhampton). The proposal aims to address three key areas for six orchid species by; - Collection of seed and fungal symbionts which are effective for germination; - Development of mass-propagation methods to facilitate the transfer to soil and habitat of the target species; and - Undertake translocations of orchids to recovery sites and safe sites.
N724 - Purchase of Perth to Gingin ironstone, a critically endangered community

Under this project the WA Department of Conservation and Land Management (CALM) will seek to acquire, through land purchase a range of freehold and leasehold properties which fill gaps in the existing reserve system and in particular those in high priority IBRA regions and contain examples of threatened ecological communities or taxa and vegetation complexes inadequately represented. Several parcels of land have been identified for purchase and include the Perth to Gingin Ironstone Association, a critically endangered plant community located on the southern Swan Coastal Plain and a parcel of undisturbed remnant vegetation adjacent to the Bendering Nature Reserve within the high priority IBRA region of the Avon Wheatbelt.
The Swan-Avon Integrated Catchment Management Progam

To enhance urban and rural community well being within the Swan-Avon Catchment by the development of a sense of community interdependence and participation in planning for sustainable economic development of the landscape in a way that protects biological diversity, maintains ecological processes and ensures benefit for present and future generations.
West Midlands Sustainable Systems Project Officer
Project officer to work with farmer groups to develop and encourage the adoption of farming practices which enhance productivity and sustainability in the West Midlands.
Foreshore Condition Assessment in the Swan Catchment
This project aims to undertake foreshore condition assessment for a number of tributaries of the Swan and Canning Rivers where catchment groups are currently planning rehabilitation activities.
Swan Hydrogeological Resource Base and Catchment Interpretation

This project will draw together all hydrogeological data in the Swan catchment, prepare maps at scales appropriate to the decision making process of land managers and complete descriptive reports of this information. Seminars and workshops will be run with catchment groups in priority catchments for groups to receive hydrogeological advice and explanation of products.
Community Revegetation on the Swan/Canning River System
Employ a project officer to provide a support structure for existing rivercare groups and to link other river users into rehabilitation projects.
South West River Restoration Training and Demonstration Programme (Extension of 973801)
Preparation of a restoration manual and establishment of a demonstration site for river restoration techniques based on 'soft engineering' and revegetation.
Development of Pinus Pinaster Genetic Deployment

The project will select improved material and techniques for large scale planting of Pinus pinaster for salinity control and farm income diversification in the 400-600 mm rainfall part of the wheatbelt of Western Australia.
N721 - Purchase of Southern Ironstone Community
The are sought for purchase is 12.5 has of Sussex Location 2650, on the southern Swan Coastal Plain, about 20km sout-west of Busselton, and about 200km south of Perth.
N737 - Purchase of land (TEC) Tumulus spring community

To acquire 9ha of the threatened Tumulus (organic mound) springs in the Bullsbrook area of the Swan Coastal Plain. These springs are one of 33 threatened ecological communities in the south west botanical province of WA.
N735 - Purchase of land (TEC) Muchea Limestone at Gingin
To acquire 60ha of land adjacent to the existing 'Muchea Limestone Nature Reserve'. The effort will improve the conservation status of the endangered Muchea Limestone community.
N736 - Purchase of land (TEC) Southern Ironstone near Busselton
To acquire 26ha of endangered Busselton ironstone community. Of the 26ha, 18ha represents 20% of the remaining uncleared remnant of this community. The community is rich in threatened flora species.
N734 - Purchase of land (TEC) Herb rich saline shrublands at Gingin

To acquire only 5ha of endangered 'herb-rich saline shrublands on clay pans'. This is one of 33 threatened communities identified in the South West Botanical Province. This area is one of 16 known to exist. Only four are currently protected in reserves.
Conservation Status of Rare and Poorly Known Western Australian Flora (confirmation of 200 taxa considered to be critically endangered)

The proposal will undertake survey to confirm the conservation status of poorly known flora likely to be critically endangered. Approx. 200 taxa will be selected which are possibly critically endangered and are considered highest priority for confirmation of their conservation status. The primary outcome of this project would be the listing of taxa on State and ANZEC threatened flora lists along with their IUCN ranking. Those ranked as critically endangered can then be targeted for immediate recovery action. Previous work on selected priority flora indicates further loss of significant numbers of taxa unless selected and recovered.
N733 - Acquisition of Ioppolo Road Bushland

Purchase of Part Swan Location 1371, being Lot 4 Ioppolo Road, Muchea. This area of 163.5 Ha offers protection to Chandala Nature Reserve and provides a representation of the vegetation catena from Lake Chandala through sandplain up to a gravel ridge. It includes a population of endangered flora 'Chamelaucium sp. Gingin' and a threatened Banksia attenuata community.
Supporting Community Driven ICM in the Swan Catchment

Provide targeted training to Integrated Catchment Management ( ICM) groups and catchment coordinators. Produce and distribute The Swan Newsletter which promotes cooperative natural resource management. Make available to the community and local government, up to date display materials on regionally important environmental issues and solutions Provide access to relevant maps, information and software for the public, community groups, local government and students. Provide developing community and ICM groups with professional support to help them understand their issues, involve other stakeholders, develop achievable goals, develop catchment management plans, access resources to implement these plans, and implement the onground works necessary to restore and protect the environment within the catchment. Provide a mechanism through which small community and 'Friends of ~' groups can link to more productively address common issues. Provide support for the Catchment Coordinators Network. Provide a mechanism for the
Promotion of Techniques to Improve Urban Water Quality

To promote techniques to improve water quality in urban areas and thereby reduce adverse impacts on downstream environments. Develop a marketing strategy targeting the key audience groups of engineers, councillors, planners, environmental officers, community coordinators and agency staff. Promote techniques to improve water quality. The promotion will include three workshops on the techniques in the Urban Stormwater Quality Management Manual, preparation of a brochure, targeted media coverage and a display to increase awareness and promote implementation of the techniques.
Swan Region Threatened Flora Recovery Plan (preparation)

To research and produce a recovery plan for all threatened flora for the Swan Region of CALM. It will include recovery objectives and crieteria for each species of endangered flora as well as identifiying costed recovery actions. It also allows clarification of the status of poorly know species that are thought to be at risk due to development pressures around Perth.

To establish a regional seed bank of locally indigenous species. The seedbank will house seed processing equipment that may be accessed by accredited community group members. A constant-temperature seed storage facility will be established adjacent to the seed processing shed. Three seed collection kits will be made available for community group site usage. Training will be provided in best practice seed collection and processing techniques. A seed collection co-ordinator will be employed full time to develop a database of banked seed to national standard as proposed by Flora Bank. They will track the destination of seed to ascertain onground results. The co-ordinmator will lead a minimum 30 community seed collection days p.a. The project will result in an enhancement of bioregional mgmt, as quality seed in useable quantities will become available for revegetation and seed orchard development.
Supporting Community Driven ICM in the Swan Catchment (NRC)

Provide targeted training to Integrated Catchment Management ( ICM) groups and catchment coordinators. Produce and distribute The Swan Newsletter which promotes cooperative natural resource management. Make available to the community and local government, up-to-date display materials on regionally important environmental issues and solutions. Provide access to relevant maps, information and software for the public, community groups, local government and students. Provide developing community and ICM groups with professional support to help them understand their issues, involve other stakeholders, develop achievable goals, develop catchment management plans, access resources to implement these plans, and implement on-ground works necessary to restore and protect the environment within the catchment. Provide a mechanism through which small community and 'Friends of ..' groups can link to more productively address common issues. Provide support for the Catchment Coordinators Network and provide a mechanism for t
N739 - Creating and managing a new protected area - Lowlands.

The owners of Lowlands Conservation Estate seek to protect in perpetuity the 1200 ha of remnant woodland and riverine habitat on Perth's highly developed Swan Coastal Plain. The proposal seeks to establish legal protection over the property and to then develop and maintain a plan of management over the land. The area is the most significant parcel of private land managed for nature conservation on the Swan Coastal Plain. The proposal has a high community benefit beyond nature conservation extending to research, education and involvement. There is a the high degree of organisation of visitors and associated visitor management, and consequently assistance with salaries for a manager to develop, coordinate and establish the required links with the various stakeholders and appropriate committees and friends groups is recommended. The facilitator has been identified to workshop the content of the covenant. The rates have been reduced by half to the amount indicated as the property is now zoned for nature conservat
N751 - Purchase of part Victoria Location 10825

Under this project the WA Department of CALM and the Rural Adjustment and Finance Corporation will negotiate and purchase part Victoria Location 10825 for addition to the National Reserve System. The area proposed for purchase lies within the Geraldton Sandplains IBRA bioregion, a bioregion of moderate priority for the acquisition of land to add to the reserve system. The land consists of the vegetation type, shrublands, scrub-heath on lateritic sandplains. Only 5% of the vegetation type is protected in conservation reserves. The land supports Declared Rare Flora and Priority Flora. Purchase and reservation will protect the land from the immediate threat of clearing.
East Metropolitan Regional Environmental Strategy Perth, Western Australia

This project will promote a co-ordinated approach to the protection and management of the environment within the Eastern Metropolitan Region of Perth and will encourage the community and local government to take a Regional approach to environmental management. This project will enhance earlier outputs by developing a more comprehensive approach to community consultation, so that any claims made on community opinion in the Regional Environmental Strategy (RES) report, are broad ranging within the community (including the Aboriginal community) and are representative of the community within the Region. This project also builds on the original project by undertaking further promotional work for the RES by media releases, advertisements, newsletters and fliers, to educate and encourage greater community involvement in this important and innovative project.
Perth Urban Bushplan Site 48 (Kensington Bushland) - Fencing Installation

The project aims to protect, maintain and enhance the natural conservation value of Kensington Bushland, a Bushplan site of regionally signficant vegetation. The project will implement one of the high priority recommendations of the Kensington Bushland Management Plan - installation of fencing to prevent access to the bushland, especially of off-road vehicles and domestic animals, thus allowing re-vegetation of tracks, and the bushland itself.
Allen Park Coastal Bushland 2000 Regeneration Project

The project represents the continuation of bushland regeneration undertaken in successive annual increments since 1997 within 35ha of coastal dune shrubland and woodland/forest terrain. The regeneration strategy essentially involves weed removal and planting using only species native to this site, and cultivated from material located closest to the site. Matting and mulching are used in fragile zones. Brushing of trample tracks is proposed. Minor dune repair is scheduled by the city of Nedlands and Department of Defence. Systematic investigations of bird and reptile species is intended. Weed control and plant survival rate will be monitored by quadrants.

This project aims to build on the significant achievements of the Wooroloo Brook LCDC over the past decade. It continues the work of revegetating saline and waterlogged areas; and also introduces new strategies to achieve a greater level revegetation of recharge areas. These strategies include agroforestry, direct seeding and protection of existing remnant vegetation. The project concept arises from the key issues and objectives developed through a catchment planning process that the group has undertaken as part of the Swan Mundaring Community Catchment Project.
N766 - Purchase of high conservation value land between Wannamal and Mogumber Nature Reserves

To purchase Swan Location 2135 and portions of Swan Locations 2150, 2858 and 2897 at Mogumber for addition to the National Reserve Systme. This propety sits on the boundary between the Swan Coastal Plain (high priority), and Jarrah Forest (low priority) IBRA Regions. The 230 hectares of remnant egetation supports seven vegetation communities, and significant populations of two species of endangered flora and three species of Priority flora. The clay based wetlands, as well as being rare in their own right, are considered suitable sites for the translocation of the critically endangered Western Swamp Tortoise. Acquisition of the remnant and protectgion in the conservation reserve system is consistent with the State's Salinity Action Plan which identifies the protection of remnant vegetation as an important strategy for controlling salinisation.
Creation of Essential Wetland Habitat at the Eric Singleton Bird Sanctuary, Bayswater

Create essential habitat through planting large banks of indigenous sedges/reeds to act as essential habitat for wetland bird species. They will be efficient bio-filters for the stripping of the nutrients and reducing euthrophication effectively increasing the size of the areas available to wildlife. The sanctuary is the last wetland on the Bayswater Main Drain (BMD) and offers the last hope for nutrients that enter the sanctuary from the BMD to be removed before they enter the Swan River. As part of the BMD catchment, we are working in partnership with the BICM program to recreate the catchment as a regional strategy.

The Perth Biodiversity Project aims to develop regional partnerships, conserve biodiversity and facilitate on-ground activities that improve the linkages between, and the quality of, locally significant bushland areas in the Perth Metro Region. This will require coordination, information exchange and support between Local Government, State Government and regional bodies. The Project Officers will assist Local Governments to address the lack of appropriate data for defining and managing biodiversity at the Local Government level, ensure a consistent approach to the development and implementation of local biodiversity plans and facilitate the implementation of strategic on-ground works in locally significant bushland sites throughout the metro region. Through a devolved grants process WAMA will be in a position to ensure strategic allocation of funds to participating Local Governments and community groups in order to achieve significant improvements in the linkages between locally significant and regionally sig
Phase I - Catchment Wide Rehabilitation in Bayswater

This projects intends to achieve awareness raising catchment wide (popn 70 000), commitment by management authorities to rehabilitate the whole drain and catchment, including revegetate all open sections of the drain (17km) and maintain them as conservation sites, expert direction on mechanisms for mechanical filtering of drainage water (195 km pipe drain), a participating community, evaluation of the effectiveness of the program, local area plans for drain rehabilitation, community involvement and awareness raising for all tributaries of the drain. Why? Because BICM is a completely cleared catchment, a whole of catchment program not a single site group, the most polluted urban source to the Swan River, & BICM has built up a very strong base of demonstrated drain rehabilitation, public awareness raising, community landcare, volunteers, support by management authorities, from which to now step into whole of catchment rehabilitation.
Actions for Recovery of the Endangered Carnaby's Black Cockatoo

A Recovery Plan has been produced for the endangered Carnaby's Black-Cockatoo and a Recovery Team established. Under the plan, important initial work is to locate a number of priority breeding areas within which conservation actions will be undertaken and the outcomes monitored. Birds Australia (WA Group) will employ a Project Officer to implement this work which will involve a wide cross-section of community groups within the species' range, as well as volunteers from Birds Australia.
N768 - Acquisition of Part Swan Location 5433, Shire of Gingin

This project aims to secure for ongoing nature conservation purposes 515 hectares of privately owned remnant vegetation within the Shire of Gingin, Western Australia. The property lies within the Swan Coastal Plain IBRA region. A region of high priority for the acquisition of further lands to add to the national reserve system. The area supports both Declared Rare and Priority flora. The predominant vegetation type is 'Mosaic: Shrublands; scrub-health / Shrublands; dryandra heath'. This complex is endemic within a 15km radius with only 1% of this vegetation type located within a secure conservation reserve. The vegetation of the property is in near printine condition and is part of the Environmental protection Authority System 6 recommendations. Purchase of the remnant is consistent with the objectives of the State's Salinity Strategy.
Demonstration Bushland Restoration through Effective Weed Management in Swan-Avon Catchment/Moore River Catchment

The project seeks to build on the findings of the NHT project of the past 3 years, by compiling a manual on weed control, suitable for use by land managers, community groups and local government. We will conduct workshops for local government workers and community groups on best practice bush regeneration through effective weed control. We will work together with Agriculture WA to seek approval from the National Registration Authority for the registration of herbicides suitable for use in bushland. Continue to provide technical support to community and catchment groups. Ensure that specific case studies are published in appropriate journals and on our web site.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Ageing, upon notice, on 6 June 2002:

question.para: (1) Did the Minister see the Australian Bureau of Statistics report titled “Australian Social Trends 2002” released on 4 June 2002 that revealed that Australia's fertility rate could fall from the present rate of 1.7 babies per woman to 1.3 babies per woman by 2012.
(2) What are the implications for Australia if the fertility rate falls to 1.3 babies per woman by 2012.
(3) What is the Government doing to address this issue.

talker.name: Andrews, Kevin, MP
Mr Andrews
talker.role: Minister for Ageing

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Health and Ageing has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) I am aware of the ABS Report predicting a fall in Australia's fertility rate, possibly to a rate as low as 1.3 babies per woman by 2012.

(2) Members of this House will be aware that birth rates are declining in most countries around the world, in response to changing economic conditions, declining rates of mortality, and changing social expectations.

This Government has already signalled, through the Intergenerational Report, that it is aware of the future implications of changing Australian fertility. Falling birth rates will contribute to the ageing of the Australian population, which will place a greater economic burden on working age Australians, not least in relation to health service provision and aged care services.

We are also aware that the social pressures for fewer children and for delayed childbearing can have additional implications. For example, with smaller families, today's children have less opportunity to learn the parenting and socialisation skills that they will need when they in turn become parents. Furthermore, as potential parents delay childbearing, there is an age-related increase in rates of infertility. If older men and women decide to have children at an age when they are less fertile, this creates additional demand for IVF services and other expensive technologies. Even so, some of these potential parents will not succeed in having a child.
(3) This Government is reviewing the social, biological and economic factors that affect fertility in Australia, as well as the social and economic consequences of falling fertility rates.

The Government will promote public debate and discussions to inform future policy. Discussion around falling fertility rates will be set within the broader context of discussion about family policy, parenting, economic incentives and targets, and national population policy.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 6 June 2002:

question.para: (1) What assessments has the Government received in respect of the environmental and health consequences of possible hostilities involving nuclear weapons between India and Pakistan.
(2) Did these assessments include estimates of potential health and environmental effects on the Australian mainland and the Territories of Christmas Island and the Cocos Islands.

(3) What Departments or agencies provided health or environmental assessments to the Government and were the Australian Radiation Protection and Nuclear Safety Agency, the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation, the Bureau of Meteorology or the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation involved in the provision of any assessments.

(4) What are the estimated health and environmental consequences of a nuclear exchange in South Asia on (a) India, (b) Pakistan, (c) the countries of South East Asia and (d) the countries of North East Asia.

(5) What are the estimated health and environmental consequences of a nuclear exchange in South Asia on (a) northern Australia, (b) southern Australia and (c) the Australian Territories of Christmas Island and the Cocos Islands.

talker.name: Downer, Alexander, MP
Mr Downer
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) & (3) It is unhelpful to speculate about the consequences of a possible nuclear exchange in South Asia, particularly given encouraging signs that sustained diplomatic activity has led to a reduction in tensions between India and Pakistan. However, the Government has received assessments on the possible environmental and health consequences of nuclear hostilities between India and Pakistan, including initial damage from weapons use, and subsequent radiological effects from fallout. These assessments have been prepared by the Australian Radiation Protection and Nuclear Safety Agency (ARPANSA), the Bureau of Meteorology, the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation (ANSTO) and the Australian Safeguards and Non-Proliferation Office (ASNO).
(2) Yes.

(4) (a) & (b) The effects of a nuclear exchange between India and Pakistan would depend on a range of factors, including the number of detonations, their yields, the height of detonation above ground level, the location and type of targets, and the meteorological conditions in the region at the time of, and following, the detonations. Therefore, predictions of consequences can only be indicative.

Damage from a nuclear detonation would be in the form of blast, heat and radiation. This would be severe near ground zero, but fall off rapidly with distance. Depending on wind speed, highly radioactive fallout could also occur up to several kilometres down wind from ground zero. Based on experience from Hiroshima and Nagasaki, and assuming weapons of similar yield were used, the immediate effects of a hypothetical 15 kiloton explosion over a city of 15 million people could cause 150,000-900,000 fatalities. In addition, there would be several hundreds of thousands of people suffering injuries or burns, many of whom would be expected to die without prompt medical aid. The effects of the breakdown of essential services and medical services would likely increase casualties.

(c) & (d) Neighbouring countries would not be affected by the blast, heat or immediate radiation from a nuclear detonation in India or Pakistan. The resulting plume would contain radioactive material, which would decay rapidly over hours to days and would be transported and dispersed by the weather. This could produce some fallout in Bangladesh within one day, or Nepal and Sri Lanka within several days, depending on the location of the detonation and weather conditions. In these countries, doses from the initial fallout deposit could be comparable with those due to natural background, although possibly higher for immediately neighbouring countries in the event of a detonation close to the border. In food-growing areas, food subsequently produced could concentrate fallout materials and become contaminated.

Radioactive debris could reach North East Asia and the northern parts of South East Asia within several days, and reach Europe within 1-2 weeks. Dose rates from fallout in these areas would be significantly less than background dose rates.

(5) (a), (b) & (c) Radioactive fallout would be largely restricted to the northern hemisphere. Atmospheric transport of material between hemispheres is very slow. Based on Northern Hemisphere atmospheric weapons tests conducted last century, fallout in Australia and its territories would be negligible for at least 3 months and possibly much longer. The concentration of radioactivity from the initial explosion would therefore have been significantly reduced by radioactive decay and atmospheric dispersion. The risk to the Australian public from fallout would be extremely low. Although detectable, it would pose a very small health risk to the Australian population. However, caution would have to be exercised when importing foods and commodities from contaminated regions in South Asia.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Education, Science and Training, upon notice, on 6 June 2002:

quote.para: (1) How many people residing in the electoral division of Hasluck are currently enrolled in tertiary studies.
(2) How many of these students reside in each postcode area within the electoral division of Hasluck.
(3) How many of these students have an outstanding or accumulated HECS debt.
(4) How many students with an outstanding or accumulated HECS debt reside in each postcode area within the electoral division of Hasluck.
(5) How many people not currently enrolled in tertiary studies have an outstanding or accumulated HECS debt.

talker.name: Nelson, Dr Brendan, MP
Dr Nelson
talker.role: Minister for Education, Science and Training

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) Information on tertiary students is only available by postcode, not by electoral boundaries. As four suburbs in the electorate of Hasluck have the same postcode as suburbs that are outside the electorate, it is not possible to provide data on the number of people residing only in the electorate of Hasluck who are enrolled in tertiary studies.
(2) Numbers of students enrolled in tertiary studies in each postcode in the electorate of Hasluck
Tertiary students includes students who are enrolled at universities and students who are enrolled in vocational education and training at institutions such as TAFE.
* There are suburbs included in these postcodes that are not in the electoral boundaries of Hasluck.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Ageing, upon notice, on 6 June 2002:

question.para: (1) How many medical services provided a bulk billing service in the electoral division of Hasluck in (a) 1996, (b) 1997, (c) 1998, (d) 1999, (e) 2000, (f) 2001 and (g) 2002.
(2) How many medical services were there in the electoral division of Hasluck in (a) 1996, (b) 1997, (c) 1998, (d) 1999, (e) 2000, (f) 2001 and (g) 2002.

talker.name: Andrews, Kevin, MP
Mr Andrews
talker.role: Minister for Ageing

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Health and Ageing has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) Information is available on the basis of individual practitioners rather than medical practices. The number of general practitioners and other practitioners (specialists, optometrists, etc.) who provided a bulk-billing service in the electoral division of Hasluck in (a) 1996, (b) 1997, (c) 1998, (d) 1999, (e) 2000, (f) 2001 and (g) 2002 (March Quarter) is detailed in the following table:

(2) The number of medical services provided by practitioners, including pathology providers, located in the electoral division of Hasluck in (a) 1996, (b) 1997, (c) 1998, (d) 1999, (e) 2000, (f) 2001 and (g) 2002 (March Quarter) was as follows:
Notes

The above statistics relate to providers of services and services provided on a `fee-for-service' basis, in the nominated region, for which Medicare benefits were processed by the Health Insurance Commission in the periods in question.

In compiling statistics in relation to (1), all practitioners whose predominant Schedule Fee income in the last quarter of the year was from unreferred attendances were considered to be general practitioners. All other practitioners are included in `other'. To the extent that some practitioners have more than one active provider number, there will be some multiple counting of practitioners.
In compiling statistics in response to (1), each practitioner was assigned to his/her principal practice postcode in the last quarter of the year, having regard to service volumes.

Medicare statistics are captured at the postcode level. Since some postcodes overlap Federal electoral division boundaries, statistics by servicing provider postcode were mapped to electorate using data from the Census of Population and Housing showing the proportion of the population in each postcode in the electoral division in question.

In relation to (1), caution should be exercised in interpreting bulk-billing statistics by electorate of provider. Since the statistics relate to providers of at least one service for which Medicare benefits were paid and there are a large number of relatively low activity providers under Medicare, some of whom move between active and inactive etc. each year, significant variations in the number of practitioners and the number of practitioners bulk-billing can occur from year to year. Similarly, since the statistics on bulk-billing relate to providers of at least one bulk-billed service, volatility can occur in bulk-billing numbers.

In relation to (2), caution should be exercised in interpreting Medicare statistics by provider region for areas of the Medicare Benefits Schedule, such as pathology. Changes in arrangements for the provision of such services can result in a significant variation in apparent service provision in the one region from year to year. Similarly, electorates/regions containing major hospitals and health facilities and electorates that encompass major regional centres will have higher rates of service provision.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations, upon notice, on 17 June 2002:

quote.para: (1) What is the current progress of International Labour Organisation treaties in respect of occupational health and safety that have been ratified by (a) the Federal Government and (b) State Governments.
(2) Is the Federal Government giving further consideration to ratifying any other ILO treaties in respect of occupational health and safety; if so, what is the progress of that consideration.

talker.name: Abbott, Tony, MP
Mr Abbott
talker.role: Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) ILO treaties (which are called Conventions) are not open to ratification individually by the Federal and/or State Governments. The Federal Government alone has Constitutional responsibility to ratify ILO Conventions, and it has been usual practice not to consider ratification until the State and Territory Governments have advised that their law and practice complies with the provisions of the relevant Convention, and also that they have provided formal agreement to ratification.

Australia has ratified one ILO Convention dealing with occupational health and safety (OHS) issues, i.e. Convention 27, Marking of Weight (Packages transported by vessels), 1929, which was ratified in 1931. Australia's most recent report to the ILO on the implementation of this Convention was in 1998, and it indicated that its provisions were applied by Marine Orders Part 32 (Cargo Handling Equipment) under the Navigation Act 1912. The ILO supervisory body reports by exception. As it did not comment on Australia's implementation of Convention 27, it is taken that Australia fully meets the obligations under that Convention.

(2) The Federal Government is not presently considering ratifying any ILO OHS Conventions. This is because the ILO will be considering a process to review all ILO OHS Conventions at its annual Conference in June 2003, and it would be premature for Australia to ratify an OHS Convention when its status is under review.

Both the Commonwealth and the State Government funded all Capital Grants projects for government schools in these postal areas. In non-government schools, Commonwealth funding complemented funding provided by the schools themselves, school systems and/or the State Government.
