talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Ageing, upon notice, on 17 June 2002:

quote.para: (1) Is the drug Evista (Raloxifene hydrochloride) on the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS).
(2) Is Evista effective in preventing bone fractures in women diagnosed with osteoporosis.
(3) Is Evista only available on the PBS after the patient has suffered a fracture resulting from osteoporosis.
(4) What other treatments on the PBS are available to women suffering from osteoporosis who are unable to take hormone replacement therapy due to medical complications.

(5) Will the Minister recommend that Evista be made available on the PBS for women diagnosed as being susceptible to fractures from osteoporosis, in order for them to receive treatment without first having to endure a fracture.

talker.name: Andrews, Kevin, MP
Mr Andrews
talker.role: Minister for Ageing

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Health and Ageing has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: (1) Yes.

(2) Evista has been approved by the Therapeutic Goods Administration, the body responsible for assessing the efficacy and safety of medicines for use in Australia, for use in the prevention and treatment of osteoporosis in post-menopausal women.

(3) Yes. Evista is currently PBS listed only for the treatment of established osteoporosis in post-menopausal patients who have had a fracture due to minimal trauma where the fracture has been demonstrated radiologically.

(4) Several medicines are available on the PBS for those women unable to take hormone replacement therapy who have osteoporosis associated with a fracture due to minimal trauma. These are: alendronate sodium (Fosamax®), disodium etidronate and calcium (Didrocal®), risedronate sodium (Actonel®), and calcitriol (several brands). However, where there has been no fracture, only calcium tablets are available on the PBS for this patient group.

(5) All requests for listing medicines on the PBS are considered by the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee (PBAC), an independent expert group whose membership includes doctors, health scientists and other health professionals. Under the National Health Act 1953, a medicine cannot be subsidised via the PBS unless the PBAC makes a positive listing recommendation.

In assessing an application for listing, the Committee is legally required to take into account the medical effectiveness, cost-effectiveness and safety of the preparation proposed for listing compared with other available treatments for the condition being treated.

To date the PBAC, taking into account all of the above factors, has not been provided with sufficient evidence to support a recommendation for the listing of Evista® for the preventive treatment of osteoporotic fracture.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 17 June 2002:

quote.para: (1) What regional assistance will the Government provide to those regions that are economically depressed with rising unemployment as a result of the Ansett demise.
(2) In particular, what assistance will the Government provide the communities within the electoral divisions of Burke and Calwell.

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
Mr Anderson
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) The Federal Government is committed to ensuring a strong and resilient regional Australia. The Department of Transport and Regional Services offers a number of programmes to assist communities dealing with economic or social structural adjustment. These include the Regional Assistance Programme, the Regional Solutions Programme and the Rural Transaction Centres Programme. Under these programmes the Government provides assistance based on applications received.

(2) Officers of the Department of Transport and Regional Services have been liaising with the three Area Consultative Committees (ACCs) in the electorates of Burke and Calwell to develop approaches to minimise the impact of the collapse of Ansett. ACCs work with the regions and Government to harness opportunities for job creation, skills development and small business success and are the key network for the Commonwealth Government to co-ordinate responses to local economic issues.

The ACCs involved are the Central Victorian ACC, Melbourne West ACC and the Northern ACC. The executive officers from these ACCs are meeting with Local Government shortly to discuss a strategy to mitigate the employment losses from the closure of Ansett.
Programme funding provided to the electorates of Burke and Calwell include:
Proponent: Macedon Ranges Shire Council
Location: Woodend
Purpose: Appointment of Field Office to Develop Business Plan
Electorate: Burke
Proponent: Melton Shire Council
Location: Melton Plains
Purpose: Development of a Strategic Plan for the Equine Industry
Electorate: Burke.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, upon notice, on 17 June 2002:

quote.para: What funding from the Natural Heritage Trust has been provided to projects within the electoral division of Burke since the Trust's inception and what are those projects.

talker.name: Kemp, Dr David, MP
Dr Kemp
talker.role: Minister for the Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: As at 4 June 2002, a total of $1,162,584 in funding has been directed to 16 projects of the Natural Heritage Trust and related programs within the electoral division of Burke. A list of projects is attached.

The term “related programs” refers to programs existing prior to the establishment of the Trust. Funds budgeted for these programs were additional to the Natural Heritage Trust, with delivery and administration of the programs undertaken through the Trust.

entry.para: Restoring the vegetation balance on Bolinda Creek source farms
Introduce whole farm planning and revegetation methods to farmers owning land situated between the Mount Macedon ranges and the township of Romsey.
Revegetation of Riparian Area in Trentham District
To re-establish viable clusters of indigenous species in riparian areas by removing pest species of plants and animals, fencing and seeding/planting.
Protection and Restoration of Riparian Vegetation along Kororoit Creek, Melton

The project will involve fencing to protect remnant vegetation and revegetation programs on selected farms on Kororoit Creek, Melton, using locally harvested native grass seed and native tree and shrub seed.
Green's Creek - Water, Revegetation and Habitat Protection
The project aims to exclude stock from portions of Green's Creek and do extensive revegetation of five sites with local native seedlings. The areas will be permanently fenced by landowners/occupiers.

Continue to employ a landcare coordinator for three Landcare groups. The project aims to develop awareness of sustainable agricultural techniques and land management expertise within a local community situated at an urban rural interface; improve the coordination of the group's onground activities which include revegetation projects, seed collection and propagation, pest plant and animal control programs, erosion and salinity controls; develop an integrated approach to land management in the area cognisant of all the cultural and environmental aspects of the landscape; improve links between local government, state government agencies, research institutions, relevant commercial industry and landholders.
Remnant Vegetation Enhancement - Jacksons Creek Escarpment

To halt the threatening processes to a remnant escarpment and riparian zone, thus allowing natural regeneration and improvements to the wildlife corridor. The area will be fenced with a rabbit proof fence; pest species and weeds controlled; and the area revegetated.
To demonstrate sustainable production techniques for addressing soil acidity; to raise awareness of soil acidification in farming communities; and to encourage adoption of soil conservation methods.
HELP for the Campaspe River (Healthy Environmental Landcare Project)
To improve the health of the Campaspe River by education, awareness campaigns, Landcare membership involvement in programs that address environmental problems within the Upper Campaspe Catchment.
Fencing and revegetation of degraded steep escarpment land to reverse land degradation. Use of indigenous species will result in biodiversity gains and improved water quality..

The project will fence & revegetate the steep escarpment of Jacksons Creek to link existing vegetation, enhance biodiversity & improve water quality in an area supporting platypus populations. It will result in 131 ha of steep land excluded from grazing.

Community driven & coordinated integrated project to create viable wildlife corridors, protect & enhance remnant vegetation. This is a priority location for these works and there is no agency with waterway mangement responsibilty to assist the community with riparian and waterway management. This project will also contribute to improving catchment health & water quality.
Werribee River Rescue - riparian remnant protection & enhancement

Greening Australlia Victoria is applying for NHT funds on behalf of a number of groups and landholders who have submitted site works plans. The project will enhance the remnant vegetation and link remnants within the Werribee River catchment in the peri-urban area west of Melbourne. It will support an NLP project to develop a Landcare network within the catchment, similar to the successful network in the neighbouring Maribyrnong River Catchment.
Valuing Native Grasslands as a Public and Private Land Management Asset

This project aims to increase community recognition of grasslands as an asset for sustainable land management, promoting the ability of undisturbed grasslands to resist weed invasion and the value of native grasses for animal production as well as a valuable resource for restoration of degraded land in the area. Through promotin of its values to the community including developers, planners, land owners and managers, farmers, road maintenance crews this project aims to address the continuing incremental loss of grasslands and grassy woodlands. These aims will be achieved through a combination of improved strategic planning, demonstration of onground works and extension and training activities coordinated by a local government based facilitator together with active community members. The facilitator will seek opportunities to protect further remnant sites through a fencing incentive scheme and developing interest in covenanting and management agreements.
Planning and Profile (Pentland Hills Landcare Group)

This project aims to establish corridors of vegetation between the Cobaw and Macedon Ranges by linking existing remnants in the Shire. It is the first step towards implementing the Action Plan developed under the Shire's Natural Environment Strategy. A devolved grant approach will be used, with the Shire contacting landowners and expecting an active uptake of the offered incentives. It will employ a part-time person to manage the process for identifying priority sites for plant, fencing materials.

Seeking funds to use ATCV and materials to combat gully erosion at 4 selected high priority sites. funds are for earthworks, planting and fencing to reduce the impact of the erosion on the wider catchment processes.
N441 - Acquisition of a 430ha Montane Grassland/Grassy woodland property, Buchan, Victoria

This project aims to purchase a Montane Grassland/Grassy Woodland property in the South East Corner IBRA for addition to the NRS. Native grassland have been substantially cleared and modified through southeastern Australia and are priority ecosystem for addition to Victoria's protected area system, in accordance with NRS criteria.

(3) What is the (a) location and (b) activity of each of the Work for the Dole projects during (i) 1997, (ii) 1998, (iii) 1999, (iv) 2000, (v) 2001 and (vi) 2002 in (A) Victoria and (B) the electoral divisions of (I) Scullin and (II) McEwen.

(4) How many (a) males and (b) females are or were employed on each Work for the Dole project during (i) 1997, (ii) 1998, (iii) 1999, (iv) 2000, (v) 2001 and (vi) 2002 in (A) Victoria and (B) the electoral divisions of (I) Scullin and (II) McEwen.

(5) What are the number of participants aged (a) 16 years, (b) 17 years, (c) 18 years, (d) 19 years, (e) 20 years, (f) 21 to 25 years and (g) 26 years and over, that were employed on each Work for the Dole project during (i) 1997, (ii) 1998, (iii) 1999, (iv) 2000, (v) 2001 and (vi) 2002 in (A) Victoria and (B) the electoral divisions of (I) Scullin and (II) McEwen.

talker.name: Brough, Mal, MP
Mr Brough
talker.role: Minister for Employment Services

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: The information requested for the Electorates of Scullin and McEwen has been extracted and collated for the honourable member. However, the information sought is not readily available and staff resources required to extract and collate the data cannot be justified to provide a complete answer for the remainder of the State of Victoria.

Some of these activities may have been funded to take place in multiple locations and therefore may be located in more than one electorate. Details of activities are provided in 5 separate Tables: Table 1 provides details of Work for the Dole (WFD) activities funded that are located in the McEwen Electorate; Table 2 of WFD activities funded that are located in the McEwen and other electorates; Table 3 of WFD activities funded that are located in the McEwen, Scullin and other Electorates; Table 4 of WFD activities funded that are located in the Scullin Electorate and Table 5 of WFD activities funded that are located in the Scullin and other Electorates. Within each table activities are grouped into the year they commenced.

The location and a description of each activity that was provided at the time the activity was approved are included in Tables 1 to 5. Activities identified to take place in multiple locations may not take place in all locations listed as placements made can be dependant on where a job seeker lives.

Under the Work for the Dole 2000 Services contract, Work for the Dole activities are recommended to the Department of Employment and Workplace Relations by Community Work Coordinators (CWCs) who are contracted to develop and manage activities in geographical areas called Employment Service Areas (ESAs). ESAs do not align with electorate boundaries. The following table details ESAs that fall either partially or wholly within the electorates of McEwen and Scullin and the postcodes within them.

quote.para: Specifically, the answer is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Refer to Tables 1 to 5 for details.

(2) Under the Work for the Dole 2000 Services contract, a Community Work Coordinator (CWC) is contracted by the Commonwealth to develop and manage activities. They may, with the agreement of the department, subcontract the management of an activity to a sponsor organisation. Where this is the case the name of both the CWC and sponsor is provided. See Tables 1 to 5 for details.
(3) Refer to Tables 1 to 5 for details.
(4) Refer to Tables 1 to 5 for details.
(5) To be eligible for the Work for the Dole programme, a participant must be aged 18 years or older. Refer to Tables 1 to 5 for details.

subdebateinfo.title: Family and Community Services: Child Care Benefit
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 521)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Children and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 17 June 2002:

question.para: On the most recent data, what sum in child-care assistance per child per annum was allocated to (a) family, (b) private long and (c) community long day care in (i) Australia, (ii) Victoria and (iii) the postcode areas of (A) 3074, (B) 3075, (C) 3076, (D) 3082, (E) 3083, (F) 3087, (G) 3088, (H) 3089, (I) 3090, (J) 3091 and (K) 3752.

talker.name: Anthony, Larry, MP
Mr Anthony
talker.role: Minister for Children and Youth Affairs

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) For the 2000/01 financial year the average annual amount of Child Care Benefit paid as fee reductions to:

(a) (i) a child in a family in Australia varied according to the number of children in care. The table below shows the average amount of Child Care Benefit paid to families by the number of children in care.
Amount of CCB paid in 2000/01 per child, by number of children in the family

(ii) a child in a family in Victoria also varied according to the number of children in care. The table above shows the average amount of Child Care Benefit paid to families in Victoria by the number of children in care.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, upon notice, on 17 June 2002:

question.para: (1) In each of the last six financial years, how many prosecutions has his Department launched under sections 229 or 230 of the Migration Act and in each case (a) against whom were the prosecutions launched and (b) what was the outcome.

(2) In each of the last six financial years, how many infringement notices were imposed under paragraph 504(1)(j) of the Migration Act in lieu of the penalty for breach of the provisions under sections 229 or 230 of the Act and in each case (a) against which airline carrier were the breaches imposed and (b) how much was the penalty against each carrier.

talker.name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
Mr Ruddock
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) In the last six financial years there have been no prosecutions carried out by the Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs (DIMIA) under sections 229 or 230 of the Migration Act.
(2) The number of infringement notices served under paragraph 504(1)(j) of the Migration Act is listed in Table A below.
(a) See Table B below.
(b) Penalty for a carrier found to contravene section 229 or 230 of the Migration Act is:
· up to June 1999, $2,000 for each infringement
· 1 July 1999 to 30 June 2000, $3,000 for each infringement
· from 1 July 2000, $5,000 for each infringement.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, upon notice, on 17 June 2002:

question.para: (1) For each of the last six financial years, how many people have arrived by ship as stowaways and of these stowaways (a) how many applied for protection in Australia, (b) what was the citizenship of each applicant and (c) how many were successful.

(2) For each of the last six financial years, what was the cost of processing the stowaways in detention, including the cost of processing protection applications, and was any of the cost of handling such unauthorised sea arrivals recovered from the shipping company; if not why not.

talker.name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
Mr Ruddock
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Until 2000, there was no separate statistical data on stowaways and they were included in the overall unauthorised arrivals statistics. In October 2000 the Department put in place new procedures for recording stowaways in a separate data base. The following number of stowaways have been recorded over the last 2 financial years:
(a) Of the 29 stowaways recorded during the 2000/2001 financial year, 13 applied for protection visa (PV) in Australia.
(b) Of these, 3 are from Iran, 2 from PRC, 2 from Congo, 2 from Cote D'Ivoire, 1 from North Korea, 2 from Burundi and 1 from Yemen.
(c) Of the 13 PV applicants, 4 have been successful, 2 are still being processed and 7 have been refused.
(a) Of the 23 stowaways record during 2001/2002 financial year (to 31/5/02), 10 have applied for PVs in Australia.
(b) Of these, 5 are from Iraq, 2 from Congo, 2 from Burundi and 1 from Somalia.
(c) Of the 10 PV applicants, 3 have been successful, 4 are still being processed and 3 have been refused.

(2) The Department does not keep separate costs associated with the processing of stowaways in detention including the cost of processing PV applications. Costs vary considerably depending on the time taken to process an application. The average cost of keeping an unlawful non-citizen in a detention centre in 2000-2001 was around $134 per day. The average cost of processing a PV applicant in detention in 2001/2002 was around $3,500. While the Department infringes shipping companies for bringing stowaways without reporting them on arrival, it does not recover the cost of detention and processing of stowaways who seek protection and make PV applications on arrival. However, shipping companies are responsible for removing stowaways whose PV applications have been unsuccessful.

subdebateinfo.title: World Trade Organisation: General Agreement on Trade in Services
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 528)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Trade, upon notice, on 18 June 2002:

question.para: (1) In relation to the World Trade Organization negotiations on the General Agreement on Trade in Services (GATS), will the Government make public its specific
(a) requests to other governments which are due on 30 June 2002; if not, why not and
(b) responses to requests from other countries which are due on 30 March 2003; if not, why not.
(2) Will the Government support the exclusion of all public services from the GATS, including, public health services, public education services, postal services and water services; if not, why not.

(3) Will the Government support the exclusion of cultural services from the GATS, so that Australia can continue to have laws which limit foreign ownership in the media and which require local content in film and television; if not, why not.
(4) Will the Government oppose any proposals which would remove the right to regulate levels of foreign investment in any industry; if not, why not.
(5) Will the Government oppose any proposals which would open up the funding of public services to privatisation; if not, why not.

(6) Will the Government oppose any proposals which would reduce the right of governments to regulate services, including the application of a “least trade restrictive” test to regulation; if not, why not.
(7) Will the Government submit all policies on GATS to full parliamentary debate and a parliamentary vote before commitments are made; if not, why not.

talker.name: Vaile, Mark, MP
Mr Vaile
talker.role: Minister for Trade

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) (a) The Government will release as much general information as practicable, including on sectoral and country coverage and the nature of the commitments sought, where this would be consistent with any commercial confidentiality and does not compromise our negotiating interests.
(b) The Government will consult widely on any requests received by Australia in the GATS negotiations and will consider its position on the public release of its offers closer to the due date.

(2) Australia ratified the General Agreement on Trade in Services in 1995; the treaty excludes those services supplied in the exercise of governmental authority. The Government supports the exclusion of such services under the GATS.

(3) The Government has indicated that it would always take cultural policy objectives and issues relating to the maintenance of cultural diversity into account in any trade negotiation, and this remains its policy.

(4) The Government supports the right of all WTO Members to regulate the supply of services, including those delivered through the establishment of a commercial presence in their territory through foreign direct investment.

(5) The GATS treaty features no obligation for governments to privatise or open up public services to competition, nor does it dictate any specific role for the public and private sectors. These issues remain matters for individual WTO Members in their domestic policy contexts.

(6) The GATS explicitly recognizes the right of members to regulate and introduce new regulations on the supply of services in order to meet national policy objectives. This “right to regulate” was explicitly re-affirmed in the WTO (Doha) Ministerial Declaration of 14 November 2001 by all members including Australia. Under the GATS, there is a mandate to develop multilateral disciplines to ensure that licensing requirements, technical standards and qualification requirements and procedures do not constitute unnecessary barriers to trade, but this would not derogate from the right to regulate or compromise the ability to maintain a required level of protection.
(7) The Government will apply the existing policy on treaty review to any amendments that are ultimately proposed to Australia's schedule of commitments under GATS.

subdebateinfo.title: Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service: Expenditures
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 530)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, upon notice, on 18 June 2002:

question.para: (1) What were the budgeted and actual expenditures for AQIS during the 38th and 39th Commonwealth Parliaments?

(2) Have cost cutting measures implemented during the 38th and 39th Parliaments impacted upon border protection activities of AQIS; if not, has it been able to maintain or enhance its pre-38th Parliament service levels and operational strength?

talker.name: Truss, Warren, MP
Mr Truss
talker.role: Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Attached is a table that identifies the budgeted and actual expenditures for AQIS during the 38th and 39th Commonwealth Parliaments. If you take into account the functions and associated funding transferred to other parts of AFFA during the middle years in the table, you will note that there has been an increase of about $60 million in expenditure funding provided to AQIS to maintain Australia's strict quarantine arrangements between the two periods.

(2) No cost cutting measures have been applied to the border protection activities of AQIS. Service levels and operational strength have been substantially enhanced since the pre-38th Parliament levels.
Attachment A

para.inline: Total Expenditure for AQIS during 38th and 39th Parliaments

answer.para: Notes

These amounts are sourced from AQIS Internal Management Reports. They do not directly align to the estimates provided in the Portfolio Budget Statements statements due to the difference in definition between AQIS as a Business Unit and the Quarantine and Inspection Output.

1 in 1999/00, responsibility for the Chief Veterinary Officer and Chief Plant Protection Officer transferred to a different area of AFFA (Product Integrity). The total budget transferred was around $10.0m.

2 in 2000/01, responsibility for a major portion of the Policy & International Division was transferred to a different area of AFFA (Market Access and Biosecurity). The total budget transferred was around $14.5m.
3 in 2000/01, DoFA applied a 1.3% reduction to all appropriation funding to reflect expected savings through the removal of wholesale sales tax.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Ageing, upon notice, on 18 June 2002:

quote.para: (1) Did the 2002-2003 Budget contain an increase in the price of medicine prescriptions; if so, what is that increase.

(2) What steps, if any, is the Minister taking to ensure that prescription prices remain static and within reach of the most vulnerable members of our society, including (a) pensioners, (b) the unemployed and (c) those on lower incomes.

talker.name: Andrews, Kevin, MP
Mr Andrews
talker.role: Minister for Ageing

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Health and Ageing has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: (1) The Government's Budget measure provided for the co-payment for concessional beneficiaries under the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS) to be increased by $1 per prescription from $3.60 to $4.60 and the maximum co-payment for general beneficiaries to be increased by $6.20 per prescription from $22.40 to $28.60.

(2) The changes proposed to patient charges have been carefully targeted and considerable protection would remain for those who qualify for concession cards and those requiring large amounts of medicines. For example, through the operation of the safety-net arrangements, the maximum increase in payments which concessional patients could face in 2003 would be $52, equivalent to $1 per week over the whole year.

The co-payment changes were scheduled to take effect from 1 August of this year. However, the necessary enabling legislation for the changes has recently been rejected in the Senate and the Government is considering its position.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations, upon notice on, 18 June 2002:

quote.para: (1) How many associates are engaged to work in the Australian Industrial Relations Commission with presidential and non-presidential members of the Commission.
(2) How many are employed on contracts.
(3) What is the length of each contract.
(4) How many are employed under (a) Australian Workplace Agreements and (b) certified agreements.

talker.name: Abbott, Tony, MP
Mr Abbott
talker.role: Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) 67* employees are currently engaged to work as Associates to Members (Presidential and non-Presidential) of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission.
* Figure does not include Associates on long term leave.
(2) 19 of the 67 Associates are engaged on contracts (i.e. they are non-ongoing employees, as opposed to on-going employees).
(3) 12 Associates are engaged on a contract for a period of 12 months.
2 are engaged for a period of 18 months.
1 is engaged for a period of 30 months.
1 is engaged for a period of 68 weeks.
1 is engaged for a period of 36 weeks.
1 is engaged for 21 weeks.
1 is engaged for 3 months.
(4) (a) 20 Associates are employed under approved Australian Workplace Agreements, which comprise both on-going and non-going employees.
(b) The remaining 47 Associates are covered by the Registry's certified agreement, and these also comprise both on-going and non-going employees.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Ageing, upon notice, on 18 June 2002:

quote.para: (1) Is epilepsy recognised as a cause of death.
(2) What measures is the Government taking to ensure that epileptic seizure is identified as both a direct and indirect cause of death.
(3) Does the Government have a strategy for raising public awareness regarding the impact of epilepsy on individuals and the community.
(4) What funds have been, or will be, allocated to this task.
(5) What measures is the Government taking to promote research into the causes, management and prevention of epilepsy.

talker.name: Andrews, Kevin, MP
Mr Andrews
talker.role: Minister for Ageing

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Health and Ageing has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: (1) Epilepsy is recognised as a cause of death within the International Classification of Diseases. This Classification is used in Australia's mortality system. The broad term `Epilepsy' is divided into a number of separate conditions which include the better known conditions of Grand mal and Petit mal. Other forms of epilepsy include idiopathic and other syndromes.

(2) Epilepsy has been recorded in the Australian death statistics as an underlying (direct) cause of death since the early 1900s. The latest available data (2000) show there were 245 deaths (141 males and 104 females) directly attributed to epilepsy. For deaths since 1997, a system has been put in place to record other factors contributing to death - these are known as multiple causes of death (indirect). In 2000 there were 839 deaths (361 males, 478 females) which identified epilepsy as a factor contributing to death.

(5) The National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) is the principal funder of health and medical research in Australia. The NHMRC funds health and medical research, across a wide range of disciplines, mainly on the basis of excellence, significance of achievement, approach and feasibility of the proposed research, and on the record of the applicants, as judged by a rigorous system of peer review.

Although the Government does not specifically promote research into the causes, management and prevention of epilepsy, the NHMRC will provide almost $3.7 million for epilepsy related research in 2002.

In addition, the majority of NHMRC research funding is directed towards basic research in the biomedical sciences, and it is likely that a number of other research projects have the potential to benefit those suffering from a range of conditions, including epilepsy.

subdebateinfo.title: Department of Industry, Tourism and Resources: Energy and Environment Division Funding
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 538)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Industry, Tourism and Resources, upon notice, on 18 June 2002:

quote.para: (1) What was the original appropriation for the Energy and Environment Division for 2001-2002 and what is the likely actual outcome.
(2) How close did his Department get to the amount of funding requested for the Division for 2001-2002.
(3) Have there been any retrenchments within the Division in 2001-2002; if so, how many and how has this impacted on the Division.

talker.name: Macfarlane, Ian, MP
Mr Ian Macfarlane
talker.role: Minister for Industry, Tourism and Resources

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) $9.942m. Also see the answer to question (2) below.
(2) Following an internal reorganisation the revised 2001-02 appropriation for the Division was $9.929m. Energy and Environment Division is anticipating expenditure of around $10.692m.
(3) There were no retrenchments within the Division following the Departmental reorganisation on 6 May 2002.

subdebateinfo.title: Department of Industry, Tourism and Resources: International Energy Branch Structure
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 539)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Industry, Tourism and Resources, upon notice, on 18 June 2002:

question.para: (1) In relation to two Departmental structure charts, dated 24 January 2002 and 26 February 2002, respectively, which appeared on the Department's website, why was a branch called International Energy included in the January chart but not included on the February chart.
(2) What resources had been available to the International Energy branch and what was the funding provision for the first six months of 2001-2002.
(3) How long had the branch been in place.
(4) What sort of work do the officers of the branch actually do and was it involved in the Prime Minister's recent visit to China to try to sell Liquid Natural Gas produced on the North West Shelf.

talker.name: Macfarlane, Ian, MP
Mr Ian Macfarlane
talker.role: Minister for Industry, Tourism and Resources

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The International Energy Branch was transferred to another Division.
(2) $1.2m was made available for the 2001/02 financial year. Expenditure to 31 December 2001 was $0.593m.
(3) The international energy functions that form the core of the activities of the branch came together into one branch in 1995-96.

(4) The Branch is responsible for managing Australia's bilateral relationships with key trading partners in the energy and minerals sector, including through regular consultations involving senior government officials and industry. The Branch organised and participated in the Australia-China bilateral dialogue on resources cooperation, held in Beijing on 4 April 2002. The Branch was not directly involved in the Prime Minister's visit to China.

subdebateinfo.title: Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation: Energy Review Project
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 540)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Industry, Tourism and Resources, upon notice, on 18 June 2002:

quote.para: (1) What input, if any did his Department have in terms of the CSIRO Energy Review Project, dated 8 April to 3 May 2002.
(2) How far away is the industry from achieving near zero emissions and what will be the economic cost of reaching that goal for Australia's coal industry.
(3) Is it his Department's view that near zero emissions are an essential element of the sustainable use of coal.

talker.name: Macfarlane, Ian, MP
Mr Ian Macfarlane
talker.role: Minister for Industry, Tourism and Resources

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) The Energy and Environment Division provided the CSIRO Energy Review Project with an overview of the domestic and international energy situation and policy issues, indicating where some research priorities might be most productive.

(2) Recent advances in clean coal technologies and the bringing together of various energy research and development streams may well mean that Zero Emissions Technologies could be feasible, but we do not have the technical skills to make an informed judgement on this.
(3) Substantially lower or near zero emissions would significantly assist the sustainable use of coal.

subdebateinfo.title: Department of Industry, Tourism and Resources: Petroleum and Electricity Division
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 541)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Industry, Tourism and Resources, upon notice, on 18 June 2002:

question.para: (1) What was the original appropriation for the Petroleum and Electricity Division for 2001-02 and what is the likely actual outcome.
(2) What were the staffing levels for the Division in 2001-02 and were there staff cuts of approximately 10% around January/February.
(3) If there were staff cuts, how did the cuts impact on the Division, and what is the projected impact going forward.

talker.name: Macfarlane, Ian, MP
Mr Ian Macfarlane
talker.role: Minister for Industry, Tourism and Resources

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The original operating budget allocated to the Petroleum and Electricity Division for the 2001-02 year was $6.667m. Following structural changes announced by the former Secretary of the Department of Industry Science and Resources, the Division was restructured to the Petroleum and International Energy Division effective from 10 January 2002.

The structural changes resulted in the Electricity and Gas Reform Branch of the Petroleum and Electricity Division being transferred to the Energy and Environment Division and the International Energy Branch of the Energy and Environment Division being transferred to the Petroleum and Electricity Division. The Division was renamed the Petroleum and International Energy Division with effect from 10 January 2002.

With the transfer of functions, resources were also transferred between the two Divisions to reflect the change in responsibilities. After the part year adjustment to funding between the two Divisions, the Petroleum and International Energy Division had an operating budget allocation of $7.076m.
It is envisaged that the Petroleum and International Energy Division expenditure during 2001-02 will be on budget.

(2) The Average Staffing Level (ASL) or the Petroleum and Electricity Division for 2001-02 was 60.2. After the restructure of the Division to the Petroleum and International Energy Division the ASL was revised to 61.6 taking account of the part year effect of the previous structure.
(3) There were no staff cuts to the functions under either Division resulting from the divisional restructure that took effect on the 10 January 2002.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, upon notice, on 18 June 2002:

quote.para: (1) How much extra renewable energy is being generated since legislation was passed in 2000 requiring commercial energy consumers to source some of their energy needs from renewable sources.
(2) Who is producing renewable energy in Australia and by what means.
(3) Of the $264 million allocated for the Renewable Remote Power Generation Program, what is the break down for each project within the program.
(4) What sum of the $264 million has been spent so far and what projects have started as a result of the program.
(5) What are the details of each project, including time frames.
(6) How much additional renewable energy has been generated in remote areas since the start of the program.

talker.name: Kemp, Dr David, MP
Dr Kemp
talker.role: Minister for the Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) As at 12 July 2002, 1,081,284 valid or potentially valid renewable energy certificates have been created under the Renewable Energy (Electricity) Act 2000. While this does not represent all generation that has occurred because there are no time limits placed upon generators for creating their certificates, it is safe to say over one million MWh of additional electricity has been generated above 1997 baselines or displaced by solar water heaters since the legislation was passed.

Note: Valid certificates include those fully registered certificates able to be traded and surrendered against a liability. Potentially valid certificates are those still pending registration and may be yet to be audited or are awaiting payment of the registration fee. These certificates reflect additional renewable energy generation and electricity displaced by the installation of eligible solar water heaters.

(2) While not all renewable energy generators have elected to seek accreditation under the Renewable Energy (Electricity) Act 2000, the Office of the Renewable Energy Regulator has accredited 155 power stations as at 12 July 2002. All certificates have been created in respect of the output of these accredited power stations, six small generation units and the installation of eligible solar water heaters.
A list of accredited power stations is available at www.rec-registry.com. The list, as at 12 July 2002, is reproduced below.

entry.para: Lucas Heights I & II LFG Power Plant
Tea Tree Gully LFG Power Plant
Wingfield I & II LFG Power Plant
Wood Waste, Municipal Solid Waste Combustion
Wood Waste, Municipal Solid Waste Combustion
Lake William Hovell Hydro-Electric Power Station
Lord Howe Island Solar Power Station

quote.para: (3) RRPGP administered funds have been allocated for the following State and Territory Sub-Programs.

To the end of May 2002, 716 systems have been approved under these Sub-Programs which will result in the installation of over 906 kW of photovoltaic generation, 86 kW of wind generation, 2 kW of other renewable generation and associated inverters, batteries and other essential enabling equipment. This is expected to displace almost two million litres of diesel consumption per year in remote parts of Australia
To the end of May 2002, there are six major projects (defined as those applying for a rebate greater than $500,000) that are in the stages of being assessed or approved.
To the end of May 2002, under the Industry Support component of the RRPGP there are two proposals that have been approved by the Commonwealth and six that are being assessed.

From the component of the RRPGP that the Australian Greenhouse Office directly administers, there are two programs that have been approved. The Indigenous Renewable Energy Services Program, which is being implemented by a joint venture of the Australian Cooperative Research Centre for Renewable Energy (ACRE) and the Centre for Appropriate Technology, known as Bushlight. The other approved program is the National Renewable Energy Demonstration program which has funded a renewable energy feasibility study for the Cocos (Keeling) Islands.
(4) To the end of May 2002, $13.687 million.
(5) See answer to question 3. More detailed information on major projects will be available after settlement of contractual arrangements and after they have been publicly announced.
(6) See answer to question 3.

subdebateinfo.title: Department of Industry, Tourism and Resources: Coal and Minerals Industries Division
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 543)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Industry, Tourism and Resources, upon notice, on 18 June 2002:

question.para: (1) What was the original appropriation for Coal and Minerals Division for 2001-02 and what is the likely actual outcome.
(2) What were the staffing levels for the Division in 2001-02 and have there been any staff cuts during the year.
(3) If there were staff cuts, (a) what were they, (b) how did this impact on the Division and (c) what functions were cut, reduced or relocated

talker.name: Macfarlane, Ian, MP
Mr Ian Macfarlane
talker.role: Minister for Industry, Tourism and Resources

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The original operating budget allocated to the Coal and Minerals Industries Division was $6.446m. With the change to the Administrative Arrangements Order in 2001 the science function of the Division, being the areas responsible for the rehabilitation of Maralinga test site and the National Radioactive Waste repository was transferred to the Department of Education, Science and Training (DEST).

With the transfer of science function to DEST resources were also transferred, which reduced the Division's operating budget for 2001-02 to $6.057m. It is envisaged that the likely outcome for the Coal and Minerals Industries Division budget be a small operating surplus.

(2) The Average Staffing Level (ASL) for the Division for 2001-02 was 47. Consistent with the Administrative Arrangement Orders the ASL was reduced to 40 after the transfer of the responsibility for the British Atomic Test site for Maralinga and Radioactive Waste Management to the Education, Science, and Training portfolio.
(3) There was no further staffing reduction to the Coal and Minerals Industries Division other than the staff who were transferred to Department of Education, Science and Training portfolio.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Industry, Tourism and Resources, upon notice, on 18 June 2002:

quote.para: (1) How much of the $5 million for the Regional Minerals Program has been spent and on what has it been spent?
(2) Have the recommendations of the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics review of the Regional Minerals Program been implemented; if so, what outcomes have been achieved?
(3) Has there been a drop in the level of gold exploration in recent years; if so, what action is being taken to arrest the decline in new gold exploration?
(4) What was the level of gold exploration in Australia over the past financial years relative to the past five years?
(5 What funding has his Department allocated towards work in this area?

talker.name: Macfarlane, Ian, MP
Mr Ian Macfarlane
talker.role: Minister for Industry, Tourism and Resources

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) A $5 million grant was provided under the Commonwealth's Regional Minerals Program to support infrastructure projects in the North West of Tasmania. To date, $0.81 million has been spent on preparation of the Port Latta site for rezoning as an industrial area and $3.14 million on the digitisation of Tasmanian geological data project.

entry.para: Digitisation of Tasmanian geological data project

quote.para: (2) Yes. The Department of Industry, Tourism and Resources has implemented the key findings of the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics (ABARE) evaluation of the Regional Minerals Program.
Only two key findings of the ABARE review required Commonwealth action:
· to include a mechanism to review study recommendations and monitor their implementation within the study regions:

The Department wrote to relevant States and Territories in March 2001 requesting, inter alia, information in relation to the implementation (short, medium and longer term) of recommendations of studies funded through the Regional Minerals Program. In addition, recipients of program funding are now contractually required to provide annual reports for three years after project completion, detailing progress towards implementation of study recommendations.
· the ability of the RMP to streamline approval processes was assessed as weak:

The Department agreed with this finding, noting the inability of an RMP study to achieve this objective and streamlining approval processes was closely aligned to the activities of Invest Australia. ITR removed this as a program objective.
(3) The real level of gold exploration expenditure and the relative importance of gold to total exploration expenditure have been declining steadily from the level reached in 1996-97.

entry.para: Gold Exploration Expenditure as a Percentage of Total Exploration Expenditure

quote.para: Source: ABS Catalogue No 8412.0, Australian Commodity Statistics 2001

The fall in the level of gold exploration has closely followed the decline in mineral exploration overall, both in Australia and overseas. One of the major reasons behind the decline is poor metal prices resulting from over supply. Future levels of gold exploration will depend heavily on movements in the gold price. The Government is continuing to provide the sector with significant support through Geoscience Australia to encourage exploration.
(4) See answer to previous question. Data for the current financial year is not yet available.

(5) The Government, through Geoscience Australia, is undertaking programs to provide high quality pre-competitive geoscientific information to mineral explorers, especially gold exploration companies. This data plays an important role in reducing the exploration risk to companies and attracting investment in under-explored areas with significant mineral potential.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Industry, Tourism and Resources, upon notice, on 18 June 2002:

question.para: (1) Has his department acted on the recommendations made in The Light Metals Action Agenda report; if so, in what way.
(2) On what basis was the Australian Magnesium Corporation (AMC) awarded financial assistance by the Government.
(3) What were the details of this arrangement.
(4) What was the basis of denying the South Australian Magnesium Corporation financial assistance
(5) What is the status of the AMC project as far as his Department is concerned.

talker.name: Macfarlane, Ian, MP
Mr Ian Macfarlane
talker.role: Minister for Industry, Tourism and Resources

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Recommendations are all being progressed by the Department, industry, and/or other areas of government as appropriate under the general direction of the steering committee.
(2) It was demonstrated that the development of the project would generate significant net economic benefits for Australia.

(3) In November 2000, the Commonwealth Government provided a loan to the CSIRO to further develop the Australian Magnesium process technology, jointly owned by the CSIRO and AMC. In 2001, the Commonwealth Government provided a loan guarantee to AMC.
(4) SAMAG did not meet the Strategic Investment Coordination (SIC) criteria.

(5) The Commonwealth entered into an indemnity agreement (loan guarantee) with AMC in October 2001. Before a guarantee can be executed under the agreement a number of conditions must be met by AMC. It is expected that the conditions will be satisfied.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Ageing, upon notice, on 18 June 2002:

quote.para: How many Easyclaim or other Medicare claiming facilities are located in the electoral division of Scullin, and what is the (a) location and (b) name of each participating pharmacy.

talker.name: Andrews, Kevin, MP
Mr Andrews
talker.role: Minister for Ageing

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Health and Ageing has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: There are no Easyclaim facilities located in the electorate of Scullin. There are now over 1,000 Easyclaim facilities distributed across Australia in locations where improved access to Medicare claiming has been a priority. The bulk of these facilities are located in rural or remote communities, and there are 60 in metropolitan areas that are close to former Medicare Offices. A Medicare Office is located at Greensborough which is just outside the Scullin electorate but accessible to most Scullin constituents.

subdebateinfo.title: World Trade Organisation: Multilateral Agreement on Investment
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 554)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Trade, upon notice, on 18 June 2002:

question.para: (1) Does he support further negotiations on a multilateral agreement on investment?

(2) Is he aware of any discussions taking place within the World Trade Organisation (WTO) to recommence negotiations on a multilateral agreement on investment; if so, what role is the Australia Government playing in such negotiations?

talker.name: Vaile, Mark, MP
Mr Vaile
talker.role: Minister for Trade

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) In the WTO Ministerial Declaration adopted in Doha, on 14 November 2001, Ministers agreed “that negotiations will take place (on Trade and Investment) after the Fifth Session of the Ministerial Conference on the basis of a decision to be taken, by explicit consensus, at that Session on modalities of negotiations.” Ministers agreed further that, “In the period until the Fifth Session, further work in the Working Group on the Relationship Between Trade and Investment will focus on the clarification of: scope and definition; transparency; non-discrimination; modalities for pre-establishment commitments based on a GATS-type, positive list approach; development provisions; exceptions and balance of payments safeguards; consultation and the settlement of disputes between Members”. The Fifth Session of the WTO Ministerial Session has been scheduled for September 2003 in Cancun, Mexico.

(2) Australia supported this multilateral consensus at Doha and is working constructively towards the development of balanced rules on investment, which can provide greater certainty and predictability for Australian outward investment while at the same time preserving the integrity of Australia's foreign investment policy regime.

talk.start.para: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 19 June 2002:

question.para: (1) Has his attention been drawn to (a) a report written by Chris Griffith titled “MP demands update on Colston's `fatal' cancer” which appeared on page 3 of TheCourier-Mail dated 15 June 2002 and (b) an editorial titled “Colston matter not resolved” which appeared on page 10 of TheCourier-Mail dated 17 June 2002.

(2) Further to the replies to questions No. 2145 (Hansard, 26 February 2001, page 24454), No. 2376 (Hansard, 22 May 2001, page 26749), No. 2662 (Hansard, 25 September 2001, page 31446) and No.56 (Hansard, 14 May 2002, page 2030) and in light of The Courier-Mail's reports of 15 and 17 June 2002, will he now have Dr Mal Colston immediately examined by appropriately qualified expert medical specialists who have never previously examined Dr Colston with regard to establishing Dr Colston's capacity of standing trial on the twenty-eight charges of defrauding the Commonwealth through travel rorts; if not, why not.

talker.name: Williams, Daryl, MP
Mr Williams
talker.role: Attorney-General

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Yes.
(2) No. The DPP has indicated previously that the DPP would, if necessary, review the matter in the future.

subdebateinfo.title: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation: Recommendation
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 564)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Education, Science and Training, upon notice, on 20 June 2002:

question.para: (1) Did the UNESCO General Conference on 2 November 2001 adopt a revised recommendation concerning Technical and Vocational Education.
(2) Did the Conference recommend that Member States bring this recommendation to the attention of the authorities concerned with Technical and Vocational Education.
(3) What steps has he taken to bring the recommendation to the attention of the authorities.

talker.name: Nelson, Dr Brendan, MP
Dr Nelson
talker.role: Minister for Education, Science and Training

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Yes.
(2) Yes.

(3) The revised UNESCO Recommendation was launched in Australia by a UNESCO representative at the Canberra Institute of Technology on 26 June 2002. I have written to State and Territory Ministers informing them about the adoption of the recommendation.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, upon notice, on 20 June 2002:

question.para: (1) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to the dissenting report in the Senate, Environment, Communications, Information Technology and the Arts Legislation Committee report into the Broadcasting Services Amendment (Media Ownership) Bill 2002; if so, does the report state that (a) the main beneficiaries of the Bill will be the major media corporations and their shareholders, (b) submissions to the inquiry contained no support from the members of the general public, staff associations or consumer groups, with almost all support for the Bill coming from media proprietors only and (c) evidence presented to the inquiry overwhelmingly showed that ownership of media organisations is a critical factor in editorial decision-making, and that diversity of ownership is fundamental to delivering diversity, independence and quality in media content.

(2) In view of the identified threats to the public interest and Australia's democracy by the Broadcasting Services Amendment (Media Ownership) Bill 2002, will the Government abandon the legislation; if not, why not.

talker.name: McGauran, Peter, MP
Mr McGauran
talker.role: Minister for Science

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) The Minister is aware of the dissenting report, which contained a number of assertions. The Committee has recommended that the Bill be agreed to subject to four recommendations concerning: disclosures on cross-media holdings; extension of the requirements for local news and information; limiting media companies to cross-ownership in only two of the three generic categories of newspapers, radio and television in regional areas; and consideration being given to providing incentives for local content for regional markets.

(2) No. The Government made an election commitment to reform Australia's outdated media ownership laws. Without reform, the current media ownership laws will limit the Australian media sector to an outdated structure with little or no capacity for new players, improved competition, or the ability to respond to a rapidly evolving and converging international media environment.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, upon notice, on 20 June 2002:

quote.para: (1) Is the Minister aware that a number of Australian writers believe that the proposal by the Howard Government to withdraw the Educational Lending Right (ELR) payment will have a detrimental effect on their capacity to earn an adequate living; if not, why not.
(2) Will the Minister re-consider the Government's decision to withdraw the ELR payments to Australian writers in 2004; if not, why not.
(3) Will the Minister consider making the ELR payment a permanent means of recompense to Australian writers; if not, why not.
(4) Does parallel importation disadvantage poorly remunerated Australian authors in favour of large, foreign owned multinational corporations; if so, how; if not, why not.

talker.name: McGauran, Peter, MP
Mr McGauran
talker.role: Minister for Science

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: (1) to (3) Educational Lending Right (ELR) is one element of the four year Book Industry Assistance Plan and will be funded from 2000-01 to 2003-04.
ELR makes payments to eligible Australian creators and publishers whose books are held in educational lending libraries.

The Government is pleased at the very positive reception ELR has received from the writing community and the benefits which the payments have brought to a sector which contributes significantly to Australian culture.
In common with all programs introduced for a specific period of time, the continuation of ELR after 30 June 2004 will need to be considered by the Government in a future budget context.
(4) Parallel importation is unlikely to disadvantage Australian authors in favour of publishers; including large, foreign owned multinational corporations.
This is because:
· the suggested scenario for lesser returns to Australian authors is unlikely,
· the demand for Australian titles is likely to remain high,
· there are incentives for Australian writers to use Australian-based publishers where Australia is their biggest market,

· the New Zealand case of parallel importation since 1998 has provided no evidence of parallel importation influencing foreign rights sales and it has been found that multinationals are one of the major beneficiaries of the current arrangements (as opposed to unrestricted parallel importation).

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 24 June 2002:

quote.para: (1) Is he able to say how many members of Afghanistan's Loya Jirga are from the Hazara community and which regions they represent?
(2) What percentage of the Loya Jirga does this represent?
(3) What percentage of the Afghan population are identified as Hazara?

talker.name: Downer, Alexander, MP
Mr Downer
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs

talk.start.para: —The following is the answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: (1) and (2) No reliable data were compiled on the number of Hazara who participated in Afghanistan's Loya Jirga.
(3) The Hazara are estimated to comprise 19 per cent of Afghanistan's population.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Industry, Tourism and Resources, upon notice, on 24 June 2002:

question.para: (1) Were all the successful recipients in NSW of Federal funding grants under the Regional Tourism Program, announced on 13 June 2002, recommended by Tourism NSW; if not, why not.

(2) Is it a condition of the grants that recommendations and support be submitted by local tourist organisations, regional tourist organisations and Tourism NSW, or the equivalent body in other States and Territories.
(3) Is it true that no recommendation was received from Tourism NSW for the (a) Australian Hotels Associations submission or (b) Tourism Task Force submission.
(4) What confidence can organisations like Cowra Tourism and its Japanese Garden project have in the selection process for grants under the Regional Tourism Program.

talker.name: Macfarlane, Ian, MP
Mr Ian Macfarlane
talker.role: Minister for Industry, Tourism and Resources

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) No. The Department consults with State and Territory government tourism bodies during the assessment process and takes their views into consideration when making the final decision.
(3) This is a matter for Tourism NSW.

(4) Proponents under the Regional Tourism Program can have every confidence in the rigour of the selection process. The Regional Tourism Program is a highly competitive program. Each year all proposals are considered on merit. If unsuccessful, proponents are invited to contact the Department for feedback on their proposal if they wish to resubmit it in the next round.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, upon notice, on 24 June 2002:

question.para: (1) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to a report titled “Alston rules out Media Bills split” which appeared on page 17 of The Canberra Times on 20 June 2002.

(2) In light of the very serious public interest issues identified in the dissenting report to the Senate Inquiry into the Broadcasting Services Amendment (Media Ownership) Bill 2002 as reported in The Canberra Times, will the Minister now re-consider supporting Labor's measures to separately ease foreign ownership restrictions on the Australian media; if not, why not.

talker.name: McGauran, Peter, MP
Mr McGauran
talker.role: Minister for Science

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) Yes.
(2) No. The Government is committed to reforming Australia's media ownership laws, in a manner that will both encourage competition and ensure that diversity of opinion and information is maintained.

Without reform, the current media ownership laws will limit the Australian media sector to an outdated structure with little or no capacity for new players, improved competition, or the ability to respond to a rapidly evolving and converging international media environment.
Removal of foreign ownership restrictions and changes to cross-media laws are both necessary to improve the regulatory environment and increase competition.

subdebateinfo.title: Brand Electorate: Defence Integrated Distribution System
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 575)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 24 June 2002:

question.para: (1) What Defence stores or maintenance facilities in the electoral division of Brand are being considered for outsourcing under the Defence Integrated Distribution System (DIDS) project.
(2) How many people are currently employed in those facilities under consideration for outsourcing.
(3) If included in the DIDS project, what obligations are there on new owners for existing employees.
(4) What obligations will there be on new owners to keep those facilities in the areas and suburbs where they now operate.

talker.name: Vale, Danna, MP
Mrs Vale
talker.role: Minister for Veterans' Affairs and Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) Supply Services at HMAS Stirling on Garden Island, Rockingham, are being considered for outsourcing.
(2) As at 10 July 2002, there are 8 permanent and 2 temporary Australian Public Service staff, and 34 labour hire staff.
(3) None.

(4) HMAS Stirling is an optional site. That is, the DIDS operator is required to provide the specified supply services to customers on base but is not required to use the existing Commonwealth facilities.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, upon notice, on 24 June 2002:

quote.para: (1) At what points on the mainland of Australia have boats containing illegal immigrants who are asylum seekers made landfall since 1991.

(2) On which of the islands newly to be excised under the Government's Migration Legislation Amendment (Further Border Protection Measures) Bill 2002 have illegal immigrants who are asylum seekers made landfall since 1991.
(3) How many illegal immigrants, who have made landfall on the Torres Strait Islands, have applied for asylum status since 1991.

talker.name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
Mr Ruddock
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) There have been illegal landings by unauthorised boat arrivals at the following points on the mainland since 1991:
Western Australia - Montague Sound, Broome, Coral Bay, Cape Leveque (two vessels), Hall Point, Wallal Downs and Exmouth.
Northern Territory - Darwin, Coburg Peninsula, Malay Bay and Nhulunbuy.
Queensland - Doughboy River, Townsville and Cairns (two vessels).
NSW - Scott's Head.

(2) There have been illegal landings by unauthorised boat arrivals at the following islands identified for excision under the Government's Migration Legislation Amendment (Further Border Protection Measures) Bill 2002:
Saibai Island (five vessels), Mabuag Island, Duan Island, Tudu Island, Hammond Island, Kerr Island, Boigu Island and Yam Island.
In addition, three vessels were detected and prevented from landing at Bathurst Island.

(3) Of the 252 unauthorised boat arrivals who made landfall in the Torres Strait since 1991, 40 persons were assessed at providing information or making claims which, prima facie, may engage Australia's protection obligations and were assisted to apply for protection visas. The remaining 212 persons were assessed as not, prima facie, engaging Australia's protection obligations and were removed from Australia.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, upon notice, on 25 June 2002:

quote.para: (1) Is it a fact that Telstra provides two telephone numbers for directory assistance - 12455 and 1223 - in the Perth telephone directory.
(2) Is it a fact that the 12455 number is billed, but the 1223 number is free; if so, why is the charged number for directory assistance listed first.
(3) Will the Government approach Telstra to offer an uncharged service only.

talker.name: McGauran, Peter, MP
Mr McGauran
talker.role: Minister for Science

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: (1) Telstra has advised that there are two numbers listed in the White Pages (including the Perth White Pages) that provide access to Telstra's Directory Assistance service, namely 1223 and 12455.

(2) Telstra has advised that the 1223 number and the 12455 number are free for residential, payphone and charity customers. Business, Government and mobile customers are charged for calls to these numbers. The difference between the two services is that customers calling 12455 can choose “call connect”, where they are directly connected to the number they are seeking. Customers are advised during the call (to 12455) that a fee applies to this additional service.
(3) The current arrangements already ensure an uncharged directory assistance service for residential, payphone and charity customers.

talker.name: Abbott, Tony, MP
Mr Abbott
talker.role: Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: The table below shows relevant activity conducted by my department and State Government agencies contracted to provide federal compliance services on the Commonwealth's behalf in Queensland (from 1 July 1998), South Australia (from 1 October 1998), Western Australia (from 1 July 1998), and Tasmania (from 8 December 1999).

It should be noted that legal action is only instigated after every reasonable effort has been made to obtain voluntary compliance, which occurs in the vast majority of cases. It should also be noted that an individual court action may involve more than one claimant and more than one breach of a federal award or agreement. For example, in relation to the outstanding actions in 2001-02, one relates to five claimants, another to four claimants and the third to 26 claimants.

entry.para: Number of claims investigated where at least one federal award or certified agreement breach detected

Successful. In addition, 222 employees were given relevant information to help them to recover their entitlements in the appropriate small claims court; the department does not monitor these outcomes.
Lost on appeal. In addition, 366 employees were given relevant information to help them to recover their entitlements in the appropriate small claims court.
In addition, 289 employees were given relevant information to help them to recover their entitlements in the appropriate small claims court.

Three cases were successful and one was settled out of court. In addition, 255 employees were given relevant information to help them to recover their entitlements in the appropriate small claims court.

Two cases were successful, two were settled out of court and one is still before the courts. In addition, 265 claimants were given relevant information to help them to recover their entitlements in the appropriate small claims court.

One case was successful and the other three are either still before the court or yet to be heard. In addition, 215 claimants were given relevant information to help them to recover their entitlements in the appropriate small claims court.

Mr Abbott

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: There are (11) eleven Job Network organisations that operate from (15) fifteen sites with postcodes matching those in the question by the Hon Mr Jenkins. Refer to Table 1.
TABLE 1:

entry.para: Lalor Park Primary School, Lindak Ave

quote.para: Services under the Job Network contract are allocated by Labour Market Regions and Employment Service Areas.
The postcode areas in question are all mapped to the Employment Services Area of North Melbourne that falls within the Labour Market Region of Melbourne.
· In this Employment Service Area there are 34 Job Network Sites including the fifteen mentioned above with matching postcodes. Refer to Table 2.
· A site can be:
- a permanent full-time site (F/T), which as a minimum would operate from Monday to Friday from 9 am to 5 pm daily;
- a permanent part-time site (P/T), at which there is a regular weekly presence, with hours of operation that are less than a full-time site;

- an outreach site (OUT), at which there is a regular presence - for example, operating on a monthly, seasonal or on an “as the need arises” basis, that may operate at a local library, school or other location;
- `other' site (OTH), which covers any other method of providing services to jobseekers, such as receptionist only sites, telephone servicing and long distance education.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 25 June 2002:
