(3) Will he direct Airservices Australia to implement fully the LTOP for Sydney Airport forthwith; if not, why not.

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
Mr Anderson
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1)-(3) I have dealt with these matters exhaustively in response to questions previously asked by the Honourable member.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, upon notice, on 25 June 2002:

quote.para: (1) Will he allow children and young people held in Villawood Detention Centre to receive a quality education at local public schools or TAFE colleges as appropriate; if not, why not.
(2) What is the average cost per person per day of holding an asylum seeker in an Australian detention centre.
(3) Will he consider replacing the policy of mandatory detention of asylum seekers to one similar to the safe haven program provided to Kosovar asylum seekers; if not, why not.

(4) Will he consider replacing the policy of mandatory detention of asylum seekers with a community-based alternative, allowing enough time to make the relevant checks, which may be both more cost effective and more humane; if not, why not.

talker.name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
Mr Ruddock
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) Yes. Agreement has recently been reached with the NSW Department of Education and Training for some school age detainee children at Villawood Immigration Detention Centre to access some NSW public schools in accordance with their needs and abilities and the need to maintain detention requirements.

(2) The average cost per day for a detainee in immigration detention, in the 2000-2001 financial year, was approximately $120. The costs include payments made under the contract for managing the detention centres as well as Departmental expenses such as those for employees, travel, motor vehicles, telephones, interpreting costs, depreciation and other administrative costs. This figure does not include departmental head office corporate costs, capital costs or those for detainees located in state correctional facilities.

(3) Australia does not have a policy of detaining asylum-seekers but does detain unlawful non-citizens, including unauthorised arrivals. Mandatory detention is the result of being in Australia unlawfully, not the seeking of asylum. The policy of mandatory detention will continue, as this is the only way the Government can ensure that unlawful non-citizens remain available for the processing of any claims to remain in Australia and ensure that people remain available for removal if they have no grounds to remain in Australia. The Kosovar safe haven program was a specific Government response as part of broader international response to the crisis in that region. The Kosovars arrived lawfully under the safe haven visa class.

(4) No. The majority of asylum-seekers currently in Australia entered with a valid visa and are free in the community while they pursue their claims. The Immigration Detention Standards which were developed in consultation with the Ombudsman, and which form part of the detention services contract, ensure that conditions in Immigration Detention Centres are humane, safe and secure.

Within the detention framework and consistent with the Migration Act 1958, the Department takes innovative approaches to respond to the needs of particular groups, such as women and children and unaccompanied minors. These include alternative detention arrangements outside detention facilities which may be established on a formal or case-by-case basis. The successful Woomera Residential Housing Project which enables a group of women and children to live in family style accommodation supervised by Services Provider staff in the Woomera township is one such formal arrangement.

Other arrangements are in place to facilitate the accommodation of some children in alternative detention locations. These have been implemented in response to the particular circumstances facing a child or a detention facility. For example, individual children have been placed in foster care arrangements in consultation with State child welfare agencies.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 25 June 2002:

question.para: (1) What funding is to be made available and in which financial years for the construction of a Multi User Depot in Ballarat.
(2) When was the funding first announced.
(3) What was the estimated size of the functional area of the building in August (a) 2000 and (b) 2001.
(4) According to the recent Single Entitlement Document review, what will the Multi Purpose Depot be required to house.

(5) Will sufficient funds be made available to build a facility (a) of the size assessed in August 2001 functional area analysis and (b) that meets the organisational requirements of the 7th/8th Battalion as outlined in the recent Single Entitlement review.
(6) When is Multi User Depot construction scheduled to commence.
(7) What sum did the Government realise on the sale of the Ranger Barracks at Curtis Street and is this funding to contribute to the cost of the Multi User Depot.
(8) Will the Government sell the Broodseinde Barracks at Russell Street; if so, is this funding to contribute to the cost of the Multi User Depot.

talker.name: Vale, Danna, MP
Mrs Vale
talker.role: Minister for Veterans' Affairs and Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) Financial Year 2001/2002 - $0.040 million and in Financial Year 2002/03 - $5.790 million.

(2) The funding was first announced in the Portfolio Budget Statements 2001/2002 dated 17 May 2001 at $5.6 million. The funding was later increased to $5.8 million and appeared in the Portfolio Additional Estimates Statements 2001/02 dated 13 February 2002.
(3) (a) The area of the building had not been determined in August 2000.
(b) Estimated to be 2000 square metres.
(4) 60 Australian Regular Army Personnel, 292 General Reservists of 8/7 Battalion Royal Victoria Regiment, 300 Regional Cadet Unit, and 425 Squadron Australian Air Force Cadets.
(5) (a) and (b) Yes.
(6) November 2002.
(7) $590,000. The funding will not contribute to the cost of the Multi User Depot.
(8) Defence plans to sell Broodseinde Barracks. The funding will not contribute to the cost of the Multi User Depot.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Children and Youth Services, upon notice, on 26 June 2002

quote.para: (1) Is he aware that many families in the electoral division of Ballarat have been unable to obtain child care due to a lack of long day care, family day care, occasional care and out of school hours care places.
(2) How many families are currently on waiting lists for child care places in the electoral division of Ballarat.
(3) When was he advised of the state of the child care waiting lists in the electoral Division of Ballarat.

(4) Is he aware of advice from his Department that because the City of Ballarat is a regional township it is ineligible for assistance to (a) undertake a study to determine the extent of the demand for child care, (b) compile and provide information to potential child care providers and (c) apply for other incentive programs to attract potential child care providers to establish or expand child care places in the City of Ballarat

talker.name: Anthony, Larry, MP
Mr Anthony
talker.role: Minister for Children and Youth Affairs

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) The period since the Government came to office has seen unprecedented growth and expenditure on child care services. In its recent Budget the Government allocated $8 billion to child care over the four years to 2005-06. Despite these significant achievements, there is still unmet demand in some areas. The Department of Family and Community Services is working with the child care sector to manage the existing supply of places as effectively as possible, to ensure that the greatest number of children are able to make use of the very large number of places already available.

(2) The Department does not collect information on waiting lists. Child care places for family day care, outside school hours care and in-home care are allocated by the Department to areas identified through the child care national planning system. There is no limit on the number of long day care centre places.
(3) See response to (2).
(4) (a) The Department does not provide specific funding for organisations to undertake studies to determine the extent of demand for child care.

(b) The Department does not provide specific funding for organisations to compile and provide information to potential child care providers. Potential child care operators are encouraged to contact the Department for advice on any identified need for child care and on the matters to take into account before establishing new child care services.

(c) The Government has in place targeted incentives, such as the Private Provider Incentive for child care providers to establish in rural and remote areas. The Private Provider Incentive is directed to areas where there are no existing child care services. Ballarat currently has 1743 approved child care places that are divided between fourteen long day care, four family day care, eighteen out of school hours care and one occasional care service. Child care services in Ballarat are also eligible to seek different types of assistance through a range of other child care programs.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 26 June 2002:

quote.para: (1) What are the current entry-level knowledge and skills requirements regarding migration procedure that must be met by applicants for registration as a migration agent.
(2) How many providers are currently approved to conduct programs of education to assist applicants to meet these requirements.
(3) Has any review been conducted into the adequacy of the requirements concerned; if so, what were the findings of any review and what action, if any, has the Government taken in response.

talker.name: Hardgrave, Gary, MP
Mr Hardgrave
talker.role: Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) Section 290(2)(b) of the Migration Act 1958 (the Act) requires an applicant for registration as a migration agent to either:

(a) hold a prescribed qualification and provide evidence of possessing an Australian law degree or being admitted to practice before the High Court or a State or Territory Supreme Court in Australia; or

(b) possess sound knowledge of migration procedure and provide certified evidence of a pass in the examination conducted by the Migration Institute of Australia, or successful completion of a course in migration/law procedure approved by the Migration Agents Registration Authority (MARA).
Pursuant to section 290(2)(h) of the Act, MARA also requires applicants to demonstrate competency in the English language.
(2) There are currently five providers that are approved to conduct sound knowledge courses.

(3) The Knowledge Requirement for Registration as a Migration Agent: A Review of Current Procedures (1998) examined the knowledge requirement for registration as a migration agent. The key recommendations were:
(a) applicants for registration as a migration agent must either hold a current practising certificate, undertake a mock file exam or a simulated interview, or complete a traineeship; and
(b) applicants must pass a written examination.

The Review of Statutory Self-Regulation of the Migration Advice Industry (1999) recommended MARA should develop strategies to provide a more consistent basis on which to assess sound knowledge requirements at entry to the profession.
The recommendations arising from both of these reviews have been implemented.

The 2001-02 Review of Statutory Self-Regulation of the Migration Advice Industry, which is currently being finalised, also examines the adequacy of the entry-level knowledge and skill requirements regarding migration procedure that must be met by applicants. The Government will consider these issues carefully once the Review reports.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 26 June 2002:

quote.para: (1) Has he indicated to the media that he became aware that some migration agents were charging potential migrants to visit him; if so, when did he first become aware of this practice and how many migration agents were allegedly involved in this practice.
(2) Has he lodged formal complaints against the agents concerned with the Migration Agents Registration Authority; if so, on what date did he do so and how many agents did he complain about?

talker.name: Hardgrave, Gary, MP
Mr Hardgrave
talker.role: Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) I have had reason to suspect some agents were charging potential migrants for appointments with parliamentarians and have received third-party reports suggesting this. Given the lack of evidence and being unable to verify specific instances of the practice occurring, no formal complaints were made. Because of the reluctance of clients to make formal complaints, I took the initiative to air my concern so that my parliamentary colleagues could be aware of these matters when approached by constituents and/or third parties.

(2) As no formal complaints were made to me I have not lodged these with MARA. However, I am exploring options for addressing my concerns in order to develop counter measures. Action being explored include specifically prohibiting charging for these introductions under the code of conduct and having the Migration Agents Registration Authority include reference to this on its website and promotional material so that clients are better aware that they do not need to pay to gain access to Members and Senators. I am also looking at what can be done to prepare a package of information material that would assist electorate staff in dealing with migration agents.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations, upon notice, on 26 June 2002:

quote.para: What are the names, addresses, and hours of operation of organisations that are part of the Job Network in the postcode areas of (a) 3145, (b) 3161, (c) 3162, (d) 3205, (e) 3206, (f) 3207, (g) 3182, (h) 3183, (i) 3184 and (j) 3185.

talker.name: Abbott, Tony, MP
Mr Abbott
talker.role: Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: There are two Job Network organisations that operate from sites with postcodes matching those in the question by the Hon Mr Danby. Refer to Table 1.
TABLE 1:
Services under the Job Network contract are allocated by Labour Market Regions and Employment Service Areas.
The postcode areas in question are mapped to two Employment Services Areas that fall within the Labour Market Region of Melbourne.
The breakdown is as follows:

· Postcode areas (b) and (d - j) fall into the Employment Service Area of Inner East Melbourne. In this Employment Service Area there are 45 Job Network Sites including the two mentioned above with matching postcodes. Refer to Table 2.
· Postcode areas (a) and (c) fall into the Employment Service Area of South Melbourne. In this Employment Service Area there are 31 Job Network Sites. Refer to Table 3.
· A site can be:
- a permanent full-time site (F/T), which as a minimum would operate from Monday to Friday from 9 am to 5 pm daily;
- a permanent part-time site (P/T), at which there is a regular weekly presence, with hours of operation that are less than a full-time site;

- an outreach site (OUT), at which there is a regular presence - for example, operating on a monthly, seasonal or on an “as the need arises” basis, that may operate at a local library, school or other location;
- `other' site (OTH), which covers any other method of providing services to jobseekers, such as receptionist only sites, telephone servicing and long distance education.
In summary, there are a total of 76 Job Network outlets delivering services to the postcode areas in question.
